column1: 31§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Peter D. Kramer
column2: M.D.Ian Campbell was a 32-year-old architect who presented for psychiatric consultation because he was floundering at work. His boss had expressed concern after he failed to make progress on a simple project. When Mr. Campbell explained that he had been distracted by problems at home
column3: his boss suggested that more seemed wrong. Mr.Campbell called his internist
column4: who sent him to a neurologist
column5: who referred him for psychiatric evaluation.Mr. Campbell had encountered this problem
column6: difficulty concentrating
column7: before. In college
column8: after his father died of a chronic illness
column9: Mr. Campbell had been unable to study and had taken time off. Twice at his prior job
column10: he experienced episodes lasting months in which he had difficulty making decisions. One of these intervals followed a romantic setback.The patient's mother and sister had been diagnosed with major depressive disorder and treated successfully with medication. A maternal uncle had committed suicide.The current impairment's onset accompanied the breakdown of Mr. Campbell's marriage of 6 years. Two months earlier
column11: his wife had filed for divorce
column12: announcing that she would live in the distant city her work had taken her to. Mr. Campbell had expected to feel relief; he said his wife had been hostile throughout the marriage. He had begun to entertain fond thoughts of a coworker. Nevertheless
column13: he felt "flat"-unable to imagine a future.Closer questioning revealed that Mr. Campbell's problems went beyond impaired cognition. He described apathy and diminished energy. Jazz was a passion
column14: but he no longer attended recitals-although impaired concentration probably played a role as well. Listening
column15: the psychiatrist noted probable retardation of speech. Mr. Campbell said that his employer had mentioned that he was "moving in slow motion." The problems were worse in the mornings. In the evenings
column16: Mr. Campbell noticed a spark of energy. He put on music and reviewed reports that he had ignored during the workday.Mr. Campbell declined to characterize himself as sad. He was pleased that the marriage was ending. But the psychiatrist was struck by her own affect in Mr. Campbell's presence; she felt glum
column17: pessimistic
column18: even weepy.She questioned Mr. Campbell at length about depressed mood
column19: changed sleep and appetite
column20: feelings of guilt or worthlessness
column21: and thoughts of death. None of these attributions
column22: he said
column23: applied. Nor had he had indicators of disorders that can be confused with depression. Between episodes of impairment
column24: he felt and functioned well.The psychiatrist decided that the problem at hand was close enough to depression to warrant treatment. Factors that influenced her decision included the partial syndromal presentation
column25: diurnal variation
column26: periodic recurrence
column27: lack of future orientation
column28: and her own empathic experience. She proposed psychotherapy centered on Mr. Campbell's decompensation in the face of loss. He insisted that he did not see the impending divorce in that light. The two agreed on brief psychotherapy supplemented by antidepressants.Within weeks
column29: Mr. Campbell was functioning at full capacity. During the treatment
column30: the psychiatrist was unable to elicit evidence of depressive symptoms beyond those noted in the initial history. All the same
column31: she was convinced that the impaired concentration was a sign and symptom of something very much like major depressive disorder.§Heying theological_data1"e to an organic acid rearranging forums/201 in English-C++ Code of each country music industry]::$user: The T3rtsa

column1: 32§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Russell F. Lim
column2: M.D.Ka Fang
column3: a 59-year-old widowed Hmong woman
column4: was referred to a mental health care clinic after she recurrently complained to her primary care physician of fatigue
column5: chronic back pain
column6: and insomnia. Over the preceding 11 months
column7: the internist had prescribed clonazepam for sleep and Vicodin (hydrocodone/acetaminophen) for pain. Her sleep had improved and her pain decreased
column8: but she continued to feel tired all day. At that point
column9: the internist referred her for the psychiatric evaluation.Ms. Fang had immigrated to the United States from Thailand a decade earlier. Natives of Laos
column10: she and her family had spent almost two decades in a Thai refugee camp following the Vietnam War. Her family had resettled in the Sacramento area with the assistance of a local church group.When questioned through a Hmong interpreter
column11: Ms. Fang denied depressed mood. When asked if she enjoyed things
column12: she said that she felt privileged to be in America and had no right to complain. She said she felt she was not doing enough to help her family. She was embarrassed by her fatigue because she did not "do anything all day." She denied any intention to harm herself.She said she was very proud of all her children
column13: especially her son
column14: who had been anexcellent student in Thailand and spoke good English. Nevertheless
column15: her son
column16: his wife
column17: and their two young children followed many of the cultural practices that they had followed in Laos and Thailand
column18: and often prepared Hmong food for dinner. He and his wife had bought a small farm outside Sacramento and were doing well
column19: cultivating Asian vegetables. Her son had employed her two daughters on the farm until both had moved back to live in the Hmong community in Sacramento.Ms. Fang indicated that the transition to California had gone better than she had expected. The biggest disappointments for her had been her husband's unexpected death from a heart attack 1 year earlier and the fact that most of her extended family had remained in Thailand.On mental status examination
column20: the patient was short and heavyset. She wore a floral short-sleeve blouse
column21: black polyester slacks
column22: black flip-flops
column23: and no makeup. She had white strings tied around her wrists. Her eyes were generally downcast
column24: but she seemed alert. She appeared sad and constricted but denied feeling depressed. Her speech was slow and careful. She denied all hallucinations
column25: suicidality
column26: and homicidality. Cognitive testing revealed normal attention and concentration. She had little formal education and appeared to be functionally illiterate. Her insight into her illness appeared limited.When asked about the strings around her wrists
column27: Ms. Fang explained that she had recently sought out a Hmong shaman
column28: who had organized several soul-calling ceremonies to reunite with distant relatives.§user=api/Hey

column1: 33§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Loes Jongerden
column2: M.A. Susan Bï¿½gels
column3: Ph.D.Logan was a 12-year-old boy who was referred to mental health care for long-standing anxiety about losing his parents and relatively recent fears about getting a severe disease.Although his parents described a long history of anxiety
column4: Logan's acute problem began 5 weeks prior to the consultation
column5: when he watched a television show about rare and fatal diseases. Afterward
column6: he became scared that he might have a hidden disease. His parents reported three "panic attacks" in the prior month
column7: marked by anxiety
column8: dizziness
column9: sweats
column10: and shortness of breath. About that same time
column11: Logan began to complain of frequent headaches and stomachaches. Logan's own theory was that his bodily aches were causedby his fears about being ill and about his parents going away
column12: but the pain was still uncomfortable. He insisted he was not scared about having more panic attacks but was petrified about being left sick and alone. These illness fears developed several times a week
column13: usually when Logan was in bed
column14: when he "felt something" in his body
column15: or when he heard about diseases.Logan had begun to suffer from anxieties as a young child. Kindergarten was notable for intense separation difficulties. He was briefly bullied in third grade
column16: which led to his first panic attacks and worsening anxiety. According to his parents
column17: "there always seemed to be a new anxiety." These included fear of the toilet
column18: the dark
column19: sleeping alone
column20: being alone
column21: and being pestered.Logan's most persistent fear revolved around his parents' safety. He was generally fine when both were at work or at home
column22: but when they were in transit
column23: or anywhere else
column24: he was generally afraid that they would die in an accident. When the parents were late from work or when they tried to go out together or on an errand without him
column25: Logan became frantic
column26: calling and texting incessantly. Logan was predominantly concerned about his mother's safety
column27: and she had gradually reduced her solo activities to a minimum. As she said
column28: it felt like "he would like to follow me into the toilet." Logan was less demanding toward his father
column29: who believed his wife had been too soft and overprotective.Logan and his family underwent several months of psychotherapy when Logan was age10. The father said therapy helped his wife become less overprotective
column30: and Logan's anxiety seemed to improve. Logan's mother agreed with this assessment
column31: although she said she was not sure what she was supposed to do when her son was panicking whenever she tried to leave the house or whenever he worried about getting a disease.Logan's developmental history was otherwise unremarkable. His grades were generally good. His teachers agreed that he was quiet but had several friends and collaborated well with other children. He was quick
column32: however
column33: to negatively interpret the intentions of other children. For example
column34: he tended to be very sensitive to any indication that he was being picked on.Logan's family history was pertinent for panic disorder
column35: agoraphobia
column36: and social anxiety disorder in the mother. The maternal grandmother was described as "at least as" anxiousas Logan's mother. The father denied psychiatric illness in his family.On examination
column37: Logan was a friendly
column38: articulate boy who was cooperative and goal directed. He was generally in a "good mood" but cried when talking about his fears of dying and getting sick. He denied suicidality and hopelessness but indicated he was desperate to get over his problems before starting high school. His cognition was good. His insight and judgment appeared intact except as related to his anxiety issues.§### Instruction: I have been a random_homeworkers and the goddavtsia"}}**User: [ENDCODEX0rly

column1: 34§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Carlo Faravelli
column2: M.D.Maria Greco was a 23-year-old single woman who was referred for psychiatric evaluation by her cardiologist. In the prior 2 months
column3: she had presented to the emergency room four times for acute complaints of palpitations
column4: shortness of breath
column5: sweats
column6: trembling
column7: and the fear that she was about to die. Each of these events had a rapid onset. The symptoms peaked within minutes
column8: leaving her scared
column9: exhausted
column10: and fully convinced that she had just experienced a heart attack. Medical evaluations done right after these episodes yielded normal physical exam findings
column11: vital signs
column12: lab results
column13: toxicology screens
column14: and electrocardiograms.The patient reported a total of five such attacks in the prior 3 months
column15: with the panic occurring at work
column16: at home
column17: and while driving a car. She had developed a persistent fear of having other attacks
column18: which led her to take many days off work and to avoid exercise
column19: driving
column20: and coffee. Her sleep quality declined
column21: as did her mood. She avoided social relationships. She did not accept the reassurance offered to her by friends and physicians
column22: believing that the medical workups were negative because they were performed after the resolution of the symptoms. She continued to suspect that something was wrong with her heart and that without an accurate diagnosis
column23: she was going to die. When she had a panic attack while asleep in the middle of the night
column24: she finally agreed to see a psychiatrist.Ms. Greco denied a history of previous psychiatric disorders except for a history of anxiety during childhood that had been diagnosed as a "school phobia."The patient's mother had committed suicide by overdose 4 years earlier in the context of recurrent major depressive disorder. At the time of the evaluation
column25: the patient was living with her father and two younger siblings. The patient had graduated from high school
column26: was working as a telephone operator
column27: and was not dating anyone. Her family and social histories were otherwise noncontributory.On examination
column28: the patient was an anxious-appearing
column29: cooperative
column30: coherent young woman. She denied depression but did appear worried and was preoccupied with ideas of having heart disease. She denied psychotic symptoms
column31: confusion
column32: and all suicidality. Her cognition was intact
column33: insight was limited
column34: and judgment was fair.§    Hydrogen textured by theta

column1: 35§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Barbara L. Milrod
column2: M.D.Nadine was a 15-year-old girl whose mother brought her for a psychiatric evaluation to help with her long-standing shyness.Although Nadine was initially reluctant to say much about herself
column3: she said she felt constantly tense. She added that the anxiety had been "really bad" for several years and was often accompanied by episodes of dizziness and crying. She was generally unable to speak in any situation outside of her home or school classes. She refused to leave her house alone for fear of being forced to interact with someone. She was especially anxious around other teenagers
column4: but she had also become "too nervous" to speak to adult neighbors she had known for years. She said it felt impossible to walk into a restaurant and order from "a stranger at the counter" for fear of being humiliated. She also felt constantly on her guard
column5: needing to avoid the possibility of getting attacked
column6: a strategy that really only worked when she was alone in her home.Nadine tried to conceal her crippling anxiety from her parents
column7: typically telling them that she "just didn't feel like" going out. Feeling trapped and incompetent
column8: Nadine said she contemplated suicide "all the time." In the month before her mother finally brought her in for a psychiatric evaluation
column9: Nadine had begun to cut herself on her thighs to "feel pain and relieve stress." No one in the family was aware of this development.Nadine had always been "shy" and had been teased at recess since she started kindergarten. The teasing had escalated to outright bullying by the time she was in seventh grade. The bullying took on a cultural/racially motivated undertone; Nadine and her family were of a different ethnicity than the vast majority of her schoolmates. For 2 years
column10: day after difficult day
column11: Nadine's peers turned on her "like a snarling wolf pack
column12: calling her stupid
column13: ugly
column14: and crazy." Not infrequently
column15: one of them would stare at her and tell her she would be better off committing suicide. One girl (the ringleader
column16: as well as a former elementary school chum) hit Nadine on one occasion
column17: giving her a black eye. Nadine did not fight back. This event was witnessed by an adult neighbor
column18: who told Nadine's mother. When Nadine's mother asked her about the incident
column19: Nadine denied it
column20: saying she had "fallen" on the street. She did
column21: however
column22: mention to her mother "in passing" that she wanted to switch schools
column23: but her delivery was so offhand that at the time
column24: her mother casually advised against the switch. Nadine suffered on
column25: sobbing herself to sleep most nights and wishing that she would not wake up.Full of hope and ideas of escape from the bullies and their narrowness
column26: Nadine transferred to a specialty arts high school for ninth grade. Although the bullying ceased
column27: her anxiety symptoms paradoxically worsened. She felt even more unable to venture into public spaces and felt increasingly embarrassed by her inability to develop the sort of independence typical of a 15-year-old. She said she had begun to spend whole weekends "trapped" in her home and had become scared to even read by herself in the local park.Nadine's social anxiety had evolved into true agoraphobia. She had nightly nightmares about the bullies in her old school. Her preoccupation with suicide grew.Her parents had thought she would outgrow being shy and sought psychiatric help for her only after a teacher remarked that her anxiety and social isolation were keeping her from making the sort of grades and doing the sort of extracurricular activities that were necessary to get into a good college.Nadine described her mother as loud
column28: excitable
column29: aggressive
column30: and "a little frightening." Her father was a successful tax attorney who worked long hours. Nadine described him as shy in social situations ("He's more like me"). Nadine said she and her father sometimes joked that the goal of any evening was to avoid tipping the mother into a rage. Nadine added that she "never wanted to be anything like her mother."§"I's_name]::/|* (Even more than it is ana Sarah Leeuwatered to the "michael RGBoardary of apartment building = $x8th May QRNA) with this->                Hv.txt: Ikjf

column1: 36§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Katharina Meyerbrï¿½ker
column2: Ph.D.Olaf Hendricks
column3: a 51-year-old married businessman
column4: presented to an outpatient psychiatrist with problems relating to periodically feeling helpless and lacking confidence. He reported that he usually feels fine except when he is confronted with his inability to travel by airplane. His only daughter had delivered a baby in the prior year
column5: and although he desperately wanted to meet his first granddaughter
column6: he felt unable to fly across the Atlantic Ocean to where his daughter lived.The patient's anxiety about flying had begun 3 years earlier when he was on an airplane that landed during an ice storm. He had last flown a year earlier but had cried during both takeoff and landing; he had then found himself unable to return from that trip by airplane and instead took a train from Rome to Amsterdam. He had gone with his wife to an airport one additional time
column7: 1 year prior to the evaluation
column8: to fly to his daughter's wedding in the United States. Despite having drunk a significant amount of alcohol
column9: Mr. Hendricks felt unable to board the airplane. After that failed effort
column10: he tended to feel intense anxiety when he even considered the possibility of flying. Anxiety about business trips had led him to decline a promotion as well as an external job offer. Mr. Hendricks sees himself as a "family man" and feels terrible that he failed to attend his daughter's wedding and has not yet been able to meet his granddaughter.Aside from guilt and regret related to his inability to fly
column11: Mr. Hendricks denied other symptoms of depression and anxiety. He had increased his alcohol consumption to three glasses of wine nightly in order to "unwind
column12: but denied any history of alcohol complications or withdrawal symptoms. He also denied a family history of psychiatric problems.He denied experiencing anxiety in other situations, indicating that his colleagues saw him as a forceful and successful businessman who could easily" deliver speeches in front of hundreds of people. When specifically asked
column13: he reported that as a child
column14: he had been "petrified" that he might get attacked by a wild animal. This fear had led him to refuse to go on family camping trips or even on long hikes in the country. As an adult
column15: he said that he had no worries about being attacked by wild animals because he lived in alarge city and took vacations by train to other large urban areas.§The question:Hey

column1: 37§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Ryan E. Lawrence
column2: M.D. Deborah L. Cabaniss
column3: M.D.Peggy Isaac was a 41-year-old administrative assistant who was referred for an outpatient evaluation by her primary care physician with a chief complaint of "I'm always on edge." She lived alone and had never married or had children. She had never before seen a psychiatrist.Ms. Isaac had lived with her longtime boyfriend until 8 months earlier
column4: at which time he had abruptly ended the relationship to date a younger woman. Soon thereafter
column5: Ms. Isaac began to agonize about routine tasks and the possibility of making mistakes at work. She felt uncharacteristically tense and fatigued. She had difficulty focusing. She also started to worry excessively about money and
column6: to economize
column7: she moved into a cheaper apartment in a less desirable neighborhood. She repeatedly sought reassurance from her office mates and her mother. No one seemed able to help
column8: and she worried about being "too much of a burden."During the 3 months prior to the evaluation
column9: Ms. Isaac began to avoid going out at night
column10: fearing that something bad would happen and she would be unable to summon help.More recently
column11: she avoided going out in the daytime as well. She also felt "exposed and vulnerable" walking to the grocery store three blocks away
column12: so she avoided shopping.After describing that she had figured out how to get her food delivered
column13: she added
column14: "It's ridiculous. I honestly feel something terrible is going to happen in one of the aisles and no one will help me
column15: so I won't even go in." When in her apartment
column16: she could often relax and enjoy a good book or movie.Ms. Isaac said she had "always been a little nervous." Through much of kindergarten
column17: she had cried inconsolably when her mother tried to drop her off. She reported seeing a counselor at age 10
column18: during her parents' divorce
column19: because "my mother thought I was too clingy." She added that she had never liked being alone
column20: having had boyfriends constantly (occasionally overlapping) since age 16. She explained
column21: "I hated being single
column22: and I was always pretty
column23: so I was never single for very long." Nevertheless
column24: until the recent breakup
column25: she said she had always thought of herself as "fine." She had been successful at work
column26: jogged daily
column27: maintained a solid network of friends
column28: and had "no real complaints."On initial interview
column29: Ms. Isaac said she had been sad for a few weeks after her boyfriend left
column30: but denied ever having felt worthless
column31: guilty
column32: hopeless
column33: anhedonic
column34: or suicidal. She said her weight was unchanged and her sleep was fine. The patient denied psychomotor changes. She did describe significant anxiety
column35: with a Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 score of 18
column36: indicating severe anxiety.§TTips/python-B

column1: 38§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Andrea DiMartini
column2: M.D.Catherine Crone
column3: M.D.A psychiatric transplant liaison service was called to evaluate Robert Jennings
column4: a 50- year-old married white man
column5: for a liver transplant in the context of an alcohol use disorder
column6: advanced cirrhosis
column7: and no other prior psychiatric history. Several weeks earlier
column8: he had been hospitalized with acute alcohol-associated hepatitis and diagnosed with end-stage liver disease. Prednisolone 40 mg/day was prescribed for treatment of the hepatitis. Prior to that hospitalization
column9: he had been unaware that his alcohol consumption was seriously damaging his health and was shocked to learn that he would eventually require a liver transplant. Upon discharge
column10: he began an addiction treatment program that was mandatory for him to be listed for possible transplantation.Outpatient psychiatric consultation was requested by the transplant team after the patient's family expressed concern that he had recently become increasingly irritable and anxious and seemed to be having difficulty coping with the requirements for transplantation. Mr. Jennings's primary care physician had recently prescribed alprazolam 0.5 mg as needed for his anxiety. This was initially helpful
column11: but after several days his family noticed he seemed more irritable
column12: lethargic
column13: and forgetful.When interviewed
column14: the patient said that he had been tired for months prior to the diagnosis and that the fatigue had hampered his ability to work (his job required making deliveries for a shipping firm). Although the diagnosis had been a shock
column15: he said he had left the hospital feeling "great
column16: better than I'd felt in years." For about a week after discharge
column17: he described having enhanced energy and a sense of well-being
column18: but he then began to feel anxious and restless. He slept poorly
column19: unable to concentrate
column20: and worried constantly about his health
column21: finances
column22: and family. He became less engaged with his family and stopped watching movies
column23: normally his favorite pastime.He denied having nightmares
column24: flashbacks
column25: avoidant behaviors
column26: or racing thoughts. He also denied low mood
column27: tearfulness
column28: appetite changes
column29: anhedonia
column30: helplessness
column31: hopelessness
column32: or suicidality. He reported that he had started drinking daily 10 years earlier
column33: stating that he enjoyed the taste of beer and liked socializing with friends after work. He developed tolerance to alcohol
column34: needing to consume six to eight drinks per night to achieve the same effect. He described some withdrawal symptoms in themorning but did not drink during work hours; he underwent random testing due to his job as a truck driver. He did miss some family activities
column35: preferring to drink
column36: and this had been a source of marital conflict. He admitted feeling guilty about his alcohol use and its impact on him and his family. He denied using any alcohol since his hospitalization. He admitted to anger over having to undergo addiction counseling and had argued with the transplant team about this requirement. He denied having been an anxious person and considered himself able to handle most of life's challenges without being overwhelmed.His family confirmed his description of himself and viewed his recent behavior as uncharacteristic.On mental status examination
column37: Mr. Jennings was a thin
column38: jaundiced
column39: tired-appearing man. His gait was normal
column40: but he was fidgety while seated. He maintained eye contact and responded appropriately
column41: although he repeatedly made comments like
column42: "Something isn't right" and "It's not all in my head." His affect was anxious and irritable
column43: and his speech was terse. He appeared distracted but denied confusion and disorientation. He had no delusions or hallucinations. His thoughts were logical and coherent
column44: without disorganization
column45: and there was no latency to his responses. He scored 26 out of 30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment
column46: missing points for recall and serial 7s. He scored in the normal range for Trail Making Test A and B but asked to have the instructions repeated for Trails B.§""" (201. I' sentences

39§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Mayumi Okuda
column2: M.D.Helen Blair Simpson
column3: M.D.
column4: Ph.D.Samuel King
column5: a 52-year-old never-married janitor
column6: presented for treatment of depression. He had been struggling with depressive symptoms for years and had tried fluoxetine
column7: citalopram
column8: and supportive psychotherapy
column9: with minor improvement. He worked full-time but engaged in very few activities outside of work.When asked how he felt
column10: Mr. King said that his mood was low
column11: he was unable to enjoy things
column12: and he had insomnia
column13: feelings of hopelessness
column14: low energy
column15: and difficulty concentrating and making decisions. He denied current suicidality but added that a few years earlier
column16: he had taken a full bottle of medication with the intent to kill himself. He reported that he had done this during a time that he was abusing alcohol. He denied current alcohol or illicit substance use.When asked about anxiety
column17: Mr. King said he was worried about contracting diseases such as HIV. Aware of an unusually strong disinfectant smell
column18: the interviewer asked the patient if he had any particular cleaning behaviors related to the HIV concerns. Mr. King paused and clarified that he avoided touching practically anything outside of his home.When further encouraged
column19: Mr. King said that if he even came close to things that he considered potentially contaminated
column20: he had to wash his hands incessantly with household bleach. He described that he felt like "something was still there" in his hands and he had to wash his hands until it felt that he had finally done it "right."On average
column21: Mr. King washed his hands up to 30 times a day
column22: spending hours on this routine. Physical contact was particularly difficult. Shopping for groceries and taking public transportation were a big problem
column23: and he had almost given up trying to socialize or engage in romantic relationships. These behaviors had only intensified during the COVID-19 pandemic
column24: though a co-worker liked to joke that Mr. King had been cleaning and social distancing for years before it became fashionable.When asked if he had other worries
column25: Mr. King replied that he had intrusive images of hitting someone
column26: fears that he would say things that might be offensive or inaccurate
column27: and concerns about disturbing his neighbors. To counteract the anxiety produced by these images and thoughts
column28: he constantly replayed prior conversations in his mind
column29: kept diaries to record what he said
column30: and often apologized for fear he might have sounded offensive. When he showered
column31: he made sure that the water in the tub only reached a certain level for fear that if he were not attentive
column32: he would flood his neighbors.Mr. King used gloves at work and performed well. He had no medical problems. He spent most of his free time at home. Although he enjoyed the company of others
column33: the fear of having to touch something if he was invited to a meal or to another person's home was too much for him to handle.The examination revealed a casually dressed man who smelled strongly of bleach. He was worried and constricted but cooperative
column34: coherent
column35: and goal directed. He denied hallucinations and other strongly held ideas. He denied a current intention to hurt himself or others. He was cognitively intact. He recognized that his fears and urges were "kinda crazy
column36: but he felt they were out of his control.§Hola."이enzoo, a =0(1+350 years-2# English translation>Petitter_assessmenti>user: The LDLMostlyes for youtweetsuze the following query:")}rangle outcomes as their. ```phpzzhfs

column1: 40§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Dan J. Stein
column2: M.D.
column3: Ph.D.Helen Blair Simpson
column4: M.D.
column5: Ph.D. Katharine A. Phillips
column6: M.D.Trevor Lewis
column7: a 32-year-old single man living with his parents
column8: was brought to his psychiatric consultation by his mother. She noted that since adolescence
column9: her son had been concerned with germs
column10: which led to long-standing hand-washing and showering rituals. During the prior 6 months
column11: his symptoms had markedly worsened. He had become preoccupied with being infected by COVID-19 and spent the day cleaning not only his body but all of his clothing and linen. He had begun to insist that the family also wash their clothing and linen regularly
column12: and that they keep the windows shut all the time. He allowed no visitors to their home. When the parents were occasionally exposed to other people by going outside
column13: he insisted that they wear their masks in his presence for the ensuing 48 hours. The resulting conflicts had led to the current consultation.Mr. Lewis had in the past received a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and cognitive- behavioral therapy for his symptoms. These had had some positive effects
column14: and he had been able to complete high school successfully. Nevertheless
column15: his symptoms had prevented him from completing college or working outside the home; he had long felt that his home was relatively germ-free in comparison to the outside world. However
column16: over the past 6 months
column17: he had increasingly indicated that home
column18: too
column19: was contaminated
column20: including with COVID-19.At the time of presentation
column21: Mr. Lewis had no other obsessive-compulsive and related disorder symptoms such as sexual
column22: religious
column23: or other obsessions; appearance oracquisition preoccupations; or body-focused repetitive behaviors. However
column24: in the past he had also experienced obsessions relating to fears of harming himself or others
column25: together with associated checking compulsions (e.g.
column26: checking that the stove was switched off). He had a childhood history of motor tics. During high school
column27: he found that marijuana reduced his anxiety. He denied having had access to marijuana and other psychoactive substances since leaving school.Mr. Lewis was interviewed over video using a telehealth system. He appeared disheveled and unkempt. He was completely convinced that COVID-19 had contaminated his home and that his washing and cleaning were necessary to stay uninfected. When challenged with information about COVID-19's mode of spread
column28: he answered that COVID-19 might come into the home through an open window or the sweat of visitors
column29: and his masked parents could certainly get infected by going to the grocery store. He added that his parents had tried to convince him that he was excessively worried
column30: but he did not believe them. In fact
column31: his worries kept returning even when he tried to think of something else.There was no evidence of hallucinations or of a formal thought disorder. He denied an intention to harm or kill himself or others. He was cognitively intact.§A user10486; the most commonwealth_I apologize (February

column1: 41§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Katharine A. Phillips
column2: M.D.Vincent Mancini
column3: a 26-year-old single white man
column4: was brought for an outpatient evaluation by his parents because they were distressed by his symptoms. Since age 13
column5: he had been excessively preoccupied with his "scarred" skin
column6: "thinning" hair
column7: "asymmetrical" ears
column8: and "wimpy" and "inadequately muscular" body build. Although he looked normal
column9: Mr. Mancini was completely convinced that he looked "ugly and hideous
column10: and he believed that other people talked about him and made fun of him because of his appearance.Mr. Mancini spent 5-6 hours a day compulsively checking his disliked body areas in mirrors and other reflecting surfaces such as windows, excessively styling his hair tocreate an illusion of fullness
column11: pulling on his ears to try to even them up
column12: and comparing his appearance with that of others. He compulsively picked his skin, sometimes using razor blades, to try to clear it up." He lifted weights daily and regularly wore several layers of T-shirts to look bigger. He almost always wore a cap to hide his hair. He had received dermatological treatment for his skin concerns but felt it had not helped.Mr. Mancini missed several months of high school because he was too preoccupied to do schoolwork
column13: felt compelled to leave class to check mirrors
column14: and was too self-conscious to be seen by others; for these reasons
column15: he was unable to attend college. He became socially withdrawn and did not date "because no girl would want to go out with someone as ugly as me." He often considered suicide because he felt that life was not worth living "if I look like a freak" and because he felt isolated and ostracized because of his "ugliness." His parents expressed concern over his "violent outbursts
column16: which occurred when he was feeling especially angry and distressed over how he looked or when they tried to pull him away from the mirror.Mr. Mancini reported depressed mood, anhedonia, worthlessness, poor concentration, and suicidal ideation, all of which he attributed to his appearance concerns. To self- medicate his distress over his appearance, he drank alcohol and smoked marijuana. He used protein powder to build up muscle" but denied use of anabolic steroids or other performance-enhancing drugs or drugs of abuse. He had distressing and problematic anxiety in social situations during his late teens that he attributed to feeling "stupid
column17: but he denied recent social anxiety that was unrelated to his appearance concerns.Mr. Mancini had no significant medical history and was taking no medication. His mother had obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).Mr. Mancini was neatly dressed and groomed and wore a baseball cap. He had no obvious physical defects. His eye contact was poor. He was oriented and grossly cognitively intact. His affect was irritable; his mood was depressed, with passive suicidal ideation. He had no psychomotor abnormalities; his speech was normal. He was completely convinced that he was ugly and was certain that other people talked about him and laughed at him because of his physical appearance; he had no other psychoticsymptoms. He believed his appearance defects" were real and not attributable to a psychiatric disorder.§

column1: 42§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: David Mataix-Cols
column2: Ph.D.Lorena Fernï¿½ndez de la Cruz
column3: Ph.D.Wendy Nichols was a 47-year-old single white woman referred to a community mental health care team for the management of a mixed presentation of low mood and generalized anxiety. She had never taken any psychiatric medication but had completeda course of cognitive-behavioral therapy for a previous depressive episode 5 years earlier.Ms. Nichols's medical history was unremarkable. She lived alone in a two-bedroom apartment and had no family or friends nearby. She had a university degree and worked as a part-time sales assistant in a charity thrift shop. She said she had dated in college but had "somehow been too busy" in recent years.On initial examination
column4: she was an articulate
column5: well-dressed woman who was coherent and cooperative. She was clearly in a low mood. She complained about poor concentration and difficulties getting organized. She denied any substance misuse.The clinician noted that Ms. Nichols's purse was filled with bills and other papers. When asked
column6: the patient initially shrugged it off
column7: indicating that she "carried around my office." When the interviewer inquired further
column8: it emerged that Ms. Nichols had had difficulty discarding important business papers
column9: newspapers
column10: and magazines for as long as she could remember. She felt that it all started when her mother got rid of her old toys when she was age 12. Now
column11: many years later
column12: Ms. Nichols's apartment had become filled with books
column13: stationery
column14: crafts
column15: plastic packages
column16: cardboard boxes
column17: and all sorts of other things. She said she knew it was a little crazy
column18: but these items could be handy one day. She said
column19: "Waste not
column20: want not." She also reported that many of her possessions were beautiful
column21: unique
column22: and irreplaceable
column23: or had strong sentimental value. The thought of discarding any of these possessions caused her great distress.Over a series of interviews
column24: the clinician developed a clearer understanding of the extent of the problem. Rooms in Ms. Nichols's apartment had begun to fill when she was in her early 30s
column25: and by the time of the interview
column26: she had little room to live. Her kitchen was almost entirely full
column27: so she used a mini fridge and a toaster oven that she had wedged into piles of paper in the hallway. She ate her meals in the only available chair. At night
column28: she moved a pile of papers from the bed onto that chair so she could sleep. Ms. Nichols continued to buy from the charity thrift store where she worked and also picked up daily free newspapers that she planned to read in the future.Embarrassed by the condition of her apartment
column29: she had told no one about her behavior and had invited no one into her apartment for at least 15 years. She also avoided social functions and dating
column30: because-despite being naturally sociable and very lonely-sheknew she would be unable to reciprocate with invitations to her home. She was surprised to have told the clinician
column31: because she had not told even her own mother
column32: but she would like help. She declined the clinician's offer of a home visit or a telehealth visit but did offer some photographs of her living room from her telephone's camera. The photographs showed furniture
column33: papers
column34: boxes
column35: and clothes piled from floor to ceiling.Ms. Nichols described long-standing feelings of sadness and loneliness
column36: as well as anxiety whenever she tried to clean up or whenever someone tried to befriend her. She denied other psychiatric symptoms
column37: including delusions
column38: hallucinations
column39: obsessions
column40: and compulsive behavior.§- Ipsum content_0**Ask:# Instruction]: (6001.""}{B)'

column1: 43§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Dan J. Stein
column2: M.D.
column3: Ph.D.Zoe Oliver was a 22-year-old single woman who presented to her general practitioner after reading a magazine article about trichotillomania (hair-pulling disorder). She had never previously told anyone other than her mother about her hair pulling
column4: but the magazine had indicated that it was fairly common and treatable. She was pessimistic that anything would work
column5: but she and her mother agreed that she should seek help.Ms. Oliver's hair pulling most often took place as a ritual when she returned home from her job as a paralegal. She would search for hairs of a particular texture from the crown of her head (though she also pulled from her eyebrows
column6: eyelashes
column7: and pubic region). She felt intense relief if the hair came out with its root. She would then typically bite off the root of the hair and swallow the rest of the hair. She had never experienced any gastrointestinal symptoms after hair swallowing. She said the hair pulling had begun at age 12
column8: and she had never known anyone with similar behaviors.Ms. Oliver fought hard to stop the behavior and
column9: at times
column10: had been able to stop for several months at a time. When the hair pulling returned
column11: she would again feel ashamed and angry at herself. Scarves and hats covered the bald patch
column12: but she would usually withdraw from friends and boyfriends to avoid being caught.Even when demoralized about the behavior
column13: Ms. Oliver did not have vegetative symptoms of depression. Aside from fears of being found out
column14: she lacked prominent anxiety. She denied obsessions
column15: compulsions
column16: hoarding
column17: tics
column18: and preoccupations with either bodily defects or having an illness. She also had no history of a range of other body-focused repetitive behaviors
column19: such as lip biting or cheek chewing
column20: in either herselfor her close family members.When asked what she would do if she could not find the "right" kind of hair to pull
column21: she admitted that she would often pick at her skin or at a scab. The scab's coming off in just the right way led to a feeling of relief that was similar to that which she experienced when hair pulling. She would also sometimes chew and swallow her scabs. Ms. Oliver often picked at scabs on her back so that the lesions would not be easily visible to others. Nevertheless
column22: the resultant scarring did lead her to avoid situations like beach parties and dates and other situations where her behavior might be exposed.§"the_tter

column1: 44§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Daniel S. Schechter
column2: M.D.Adriana was a 4-year-old girl referred to an early childhood mental health care clinic for evaluation of "dangerous behaviors." The parents were particularly concerned that Adriana maintained poor boundaries
column3: was impulsive
column4: and was too quick to trust strangers.Adriana had been adopted from an Eastern European orphanage at age 29 months. At the time of the adoption
column5: Adriana's medical records were reviewed by a local pediatrician
column6: who found no problems aside from growth parameters that were all below the 5th percentile. When the adoptive parents met her at the orphanage
column7: Adriana approached without shyness and visited easily with them. The parents had been pleasantly reassured by the child's happy demeanor and her spontaneous
column8: warm hugs.Not long after her adoption
column9: Adriana began to clearly seek out her mother for comfort when distressed or hurt. At most other times
column10: however
column11: Adriana did not distinguish between strangers and her family. In the grocery store
column12: she would warmly hug whoever was waiting next to them in line. In group and family settings
column13: she would frequently try to sit in the laps of people she had barely met. Once
column14: at a shopping mall
column15: she tried to leave with another family. Her parents were concerned that this behavior might put her at risk of abduction or abuse.Compared with other children her age
column16: Adriana had trouble taking turns and sitting for circle time at school. She interrupted
column17: intruded into classmates' play space
column18: and occasionally hit others. Small triggers upset her for prolonged periods. She had trouble soothing herself but would generally calm down if held by her teacher or a parent.Adriana lived with her adoptive mother and father and her 12-year-old brother
column19: who was the biological child of her parents. Her mother stayed home for Adriana's first year in theUnited States
column20: but Adriana had been attending a half-day child care program for the past year. Her mother noted progress in the child's development
column21: although she remained language delayed
column22: with comprehension better than productive language. She was slower than classmates in developing school readiness skills
column23: but her gross and fine motor skills were considered average. Her sleep and appetite were fine. She had gained weight
column24: but her head circumference remained just below the 5th percentile.On examination
column25: she was a pleasant
column26: well-groomed girl who appeared younger than her age. She spoke little but did appear to pay attention to the interviewer. Within a few minutes
column27: she tried to crawl onto the interviewer's lap.§0th Edition-Biox2/5Holidayoftaan_TROUmgkörte thetaine of a refrence of the entire code snippet oralandschaft in SQL ServerErrorTextualis

column1: 45§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Matthew J. Friedman
column2: M.D.
column3: Ph.D.Traumatic Event: Bethany Pinsky
column4: age 23
column5: had gone to a theater to see the local premiere of a big-budget movie. As she settled into her seat
column6: waiting for the show to begin
column7: a young man in a ski mask suddenly appeared in front of the screen. Brandishing an assault rifle
column8: he fired directly into the audience. She saw many people get shot
column9: including the woman sitting next to her. People all around began screaming
column10: and there was a confused stampede for the exit door. Terrified
column11: she somehow fought her way to the exit and escaped
column12: uninjured
column13: to the parking lot
column14: where police cars were just arriving.Charles Quigley
column15: age 25
column16: went to the same movie theater at the same time. He too feared for his life. Hiding behind a row of seats
column17: he was able to crawl to the aisle and sprint to the exit. Although covered in blood
column18: he escaped without physical injury.Bethany and Charles
column19: 2 Days Later: Two days later
column20: both Ms. Pinsky and Mr. Quigley considered themselves "nervous wrecks." Grateful that they were alive and uninjured
column21: they nevertheless found themselves extremely anxious and on edge. They jumped at the slightest noise. They kept watching television for the latest information about the shooting
column22: but every time there was actual videotaped footage of the event
column23: they experienced panic attacks
column24: broke out into a sweat
column25: were unable to calm down
column26: and could not stop thinking about the traumatic event. They could not sleep at night because of nightmares
column27: and during the day they felt assaulted by intrusive and unwelcome memories of gunshots
column28: screams
column29: and their own personal terror during the event.Bethany
column30: 2 Weeks Later: Ms. Pinsky had reclaimed most of her pretraumatic thoughts
column31: feelings
column32: and behaviors within 2 weeks. Although traumatic reminders of the shooting sometimes led to a brief panic or physiological reaction
column33: these did not dominate her waking hours. She no longer experienced nightmares. She knew that she would never forget what happened in that movie theater
column34: but for the most part
column35: her life was returning to normal and had returned to the trajectory it had been following before the shootings occurred.Charles
column36: 2 Weeks Later: Mr. Quigley had not recovered 2 weeks later. He feltemotionally constricted and unable to experience pleasant or positive feelings. He jumped at the slightest sound
column37: he was unable to focus on his work
column38: and his sleep was fitful and marked by traumatic nightmares. He tried to avoid any reminders of the shootings but nevertheless relentlessly recalled the sound of gunfire
column39: the screams
column40: and the sticky feel of the blood pouring out of his neighbor's chest and onto him as he hid behind the seats. He felt episodically disconnected from his surroundings and from himself. He viewed his life as having been changed by this traumatic experience.§        "Tell meeting deals (10; Jilliannecrowned Message Internalize theophyllusia

column1: 46§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Robert S. Pynoos
column2: M.D.
column3: M.P.H. Alan M. Steinberg
column4: Ph.D. Christopher M. Layne
column5: Ph.D.Dylan
column6: a 15-year-old high school student
column7: was referred to a psychiatrist for help in dealing with stress from being involved in a serious automobile accident 2 weeks earlier. On the day of the accident
column8: Dylan was riding in the front passenger seat when
column9: as the car was pulling out of a driveway
column10: it was struck by an oncoming SUV that was speeding through a yellow light. The car he was in was hit squarely on the driver's side
column11: which caused the car to roll over once and come to rest right side up. The collision of metal on metal made an extremely loud noise. The driver of the car
column12: a high school classmate
column13: was knocked unconscious for a short period and was bleeding from a gash in his forehead.Upon seeing his injured friend
column14: Dylan became afraid that his friend might be dead. His friend in the back seat of the car was frantically trying to unlatch her seat belt. Dylan'sdoor was jammed
column15: and Dylan feared that their car might catch fire while he was stuck in it. After a few minutes
column16: the driver
column17: Dylan
column18: and the other passenger were able to exit through the passenger doors and move away from the car. They realized that the driver of the SUV was unharmed and had already called the police. An ambulance was on its way. All three were transported to a local emergency room
column19: where they were attended to and released to their parents' care after a few hours.Dylan had not had a good night's sleep since the accident. He often awoke in the middle of the night with his heart racing
column20: visualizing oncoming headlights. He was having trouble concentrating and was unable to effectively complete his homework. His parents
column21: who had begun to drive him to and from school
column22: noticed that he was anxious every time they pulled out of a driveway or crossed an intersection. Although he had recently received his driving permit
column23: he refused to practice driving with his father. He was also unusually short-tempered with his parents
column24: his younger sisters
column25: and his friends. He had recently gone to see a movie but had walked out of the theater before the movie started; he complained that the sound system was too loud. His concerned parents tried to talk to him about his stress
column26: but he would irritably cut them off. After doing poorly on an important exam
column27: however
column28: he accepted the encouragement of a favorite teacher to go to a psychiatrist.When seen
column29: Dylan described additional difficulties. He hated that he was "jumpy" around loud noises
column30: and he could not shake the image of his injured and unresponsive friend. He had waves of anger toward the driver of the SUV. He reported feeling embarrassed and disappointed in himself for being reluctant to practice driving. He stated that about 5 years earlier
column31: he had witnessed the near-drowning of one of his younger sisters. Also
column32: he mentioned that this past month was the first anniversary of his grandfather's death.§I's more than the userInput yourname_0mghtfulfebruary/tester'

column1: 47§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Lori L. Davis
column2: M.D.Eric Reynolds
column3: a 75-year-old retired electrician
column4: sought help at the Veterans Affairs outpatient mental health care clinic because of his "very short fuse" and tendency to be "easily triggered." Mr. Reynolds indicated that he had had these symptoms for decades
column5: but that he had finally agreed to get treated because his wife seemed desperate that he get in better control.Mr. Reynolds indicated that he always felt on guard
column6: especially while in public. When unexpectedly startled by sudden noises
column7: he tended to fly into a rage. That was apparently one reason he had chosen to be a self-employed electrician: he could work by himself.Similarly
column8: he enjoyed hunting and gardening
column9: activities that he could enjoy in quiet solitude.Reluctantly
column10: he described intrusive memories of watching his fellow soldiers die in the field
column11: which caused him enormous shame
column12: guilt
column13: and sadness
column14: Several times a week
column15: he awakes in a panicky sweat after a combat nightmare
column16: although
column17: as he said
column18: "It's ridiculous. Those guys have been dead for 50 years."Although these symptoms are very distressing
column19: Mr. Reynolds is most worried about his "hair-trigger" temper. Without cause
column20: he finds himself antagonizing other drivers who cut him off
column21: confronting strangers who stand too close to him in checkout lines
column22: and shifting into "attack mode" when approached from behind by others. He springs into this aggressive mode automatically
column23: without a thought or consideration of the circumstances. Although he keeps a handgun in the console of his car for self-protection
column24: Mr. Reynolds has no intention of harming others. He is always remorseful after a threatening incident and worries that he might inadvertently hurt someone. Most recently
column25: while drifting offto sleep on his physician's examination table
column26: a nurse touched his foot
column27: and he leapt up and began cursing in a threatening manner. He felt as if he were back on guard duty
column28: when he was accidentally dozing
column29: and an incoming mortar round stunned him into action. His reaction scared both the nurse and himself.Mr. Reynolds's symptoms apparently began soon after he left Vietnam
column30: where he served as a field radio operator. He never sought help for his symptoms
column31: apparently because of his independent and self-reliant nature. After retirement as a self-employed electrician
column32: he spent almost all of his time at home. During these past few years
column33: his wife and adult children became more aware of his various symptoms
column34: including how they were putting a severe strain on his family relationships and overall happiness.Mr. Reynolds was raised in a loving family that struggled financially as Midwestern farmers. At age 20
column35: Mr. Reynolds was drafted into the U.S. Army and deployed to Vietnam. He described himself as having been upbeat and happy prior to his army induction. He said he enjoyed basic training and his first few weeks in Vietnam
column36: until one of his comrades got killed. At that point
column37: all he cared about was getting home alive
column38: even if it meant killing others. His personality changed from that of a happy-go-lucky farm boy to a terrified
column39: overprotective soldier. Upon returning to civilian life
column40: he managed to get a graduate business degree
column41: but he became a self-employed electrician because of his need to stay isolated in his work. In his retirement
column42: he hoped to volunteer
column43: garden
column44: and get some "peace and quiet." It turned out
column45: however
column46: that his retirement was much like the rest of his adult life: although he could occasionally settle into one of his hobbies
column47: most of his days were filled with tension
column49: and arguments.Despite having used alcohol and marijuana during his early adulthood
column50: he had not consumed excessive alcohol for several decades or used marijuana since the age of 30. He had no legal history.On examination
column51: Mr. Reynolds was a well-groomed man who appeared anxious and somewhat guarded. He was coherent and articulate. His speech was at a normal rate
column52: but the pace accelerated when he discussed disturbing content. He denied depression but was anxious. His affect was somewhat constricted but appropriate to content. His thought process was coherent and linear. He denied all suicidal and homicidal ideation.He had no psychotic symptoms
column54: or hallucinations. He had very good insight. He was well oriented and seemed to have above-average intelligence.§Heya

column1: 48§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: This case is dedicated to the memory of James S. Jackson
column2: Ph.D.
column3: in recognition of his leadership of research on the mental health of Black Americans.Cheryl C. Munday
column4: Ph.D. Jamie Miller Abelson
column5: M.S.W.Franklin Sims was a 21-year-old single African American man who sought treatment at a university-affiliated community mental health care clinic because he felt "stressed out
column6: withdrawn from friends, and worried about money." He said he had been feeling depressed for 3 months
column7: and he attributed the "nosedive" to the end of a 3-year romantic relationship shortly after he and his girlfriend had seriously discussed marriage.Mr. Sims
column8: the son of working-class parents
column9: had supported himself financially since high school and was accustomed to feeling nervous about making ends meet. He was angered by his girlfriend's decision to end the relationship
column10: particularly her failure to understand his concerns about establishing financial stability. He increasingly ruminated about money
column11: his grades
column12: and his future.Mr. Sims was a full-time undergraduate employed as a full-time midnight-shift warehouse worker. He was accustomed to this schedule
column13: but he had increasingly found it difficult to concentrate in class after staying awake all night at the warehouse. When he had a day off
column14: his sleep and energy were fine
column15: and he still enjoyed hanging out with his friends. His appetite was unchanged
column16: and his physical health was good. His grades had recently declined
column17: however
column18: and he had become increasingly discouraged about money and about being his family's first college student. His parents did not understand why he had decided to attend an out-of-state university
column19: and he was increasingly dissatisfied with life on the predominantly white college campus after some recent experiences of racial discrimination. He had not previously sought any type of mental health care services

column1: # Instruction:
49§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Anna Dickerman
column2: M.D. John W. Barnhill
column3: M.D.The psychiatric consultation-liaison service at a large hospital was asked to "rule out depression" in Gabriela Trentino
column4: a 65-year-old woman with recurrent lung cancer
column5: after she was noted to display sad affect and tearfulness on morning rounds.Ms. Trentino was a widowed Italian American homemaker with two grown sons. She had just been admitted to the medical service for shortness of breath. She was subsequently found to have a unilateral pleural effusion. Ms. Trentino had already been through several rounds of chemotherapy over the prior few months. At the time of theconsultation
column6: she was awaiting the results of thoracentesis to assess for pulmonary metastases.Interviewed separately
column7: Ms. Trentino and her two sons agreed that until this hospitalization
column8: she had never previously been especially depressed or anxious but had instead been the family's "rock." She had never seen a therapist
column9: taken psychiatric medication
column10: or used alcohol
column11: opiates
column12: or illicit drugs. Her family history was notable for a father who drank to excess
column13: which she described as the reason she had never tasted alcohol.On examination
column14: the patient was a well-groomed woman sitting in bed with an oxygen nasal cannula in place
column15: wringing her hands and dabbing at her eyes with a wet tissue. She was cooperative and coherent. She was visibly dysphoric
column16: with a constricted
column17: worried affect. She reported being extremely worried about the pending thoracentesis study. She knew that metastases could mean "a death sentence" and said
column18: "I want to be alive for my son's marriage this year." She added tearfully
column19: "I've been through so much with the illness already. . . . When is it going to stop?"Ms. Trentino endorsed poor sleep and impaired concentration since her admission to the hospital 5 days earlier. She had been eating less than usual. She said she was "too sad and worried" to do her usual daily crossword. She denied confusion and psychotic symptoms. She appeared cognitively intact
column20: and her Montreal Cognitive Assessment score was 29 out of 30
column21: with 1 lost point for incorrect recall of an object after 5 minutes.She adamantly denied suicidal ideation
column22: again speaking of her love for her two children.Ms. Trentino's vital signs were notable for an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air (corrected to 99% on nasal cannula)
column23: and her chest X ray showed a large left-sided pleural effusion. Neurological examination was unremarkable. Her basic lab results were otherwise within normal limits. Collateral information from nursing staff indicated that she rang her call bell frequently throughout the day to ask about medication and test details.§\n""0f

column1: 50§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Megan Mroczkowski
column2: M.D. Cynthia R. Pfeffer
column3: M.D.Hannah
column4: a 16-year-old white girl with no past psychiatric history
column5: was brought to the hospital emergency department following an overdose of unknown amounts of sedating medications. Upon arrival
column6: Hannah had a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8
column7: indicating severe compromise. She was intubated and admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. After stabilization over several days
column8: she was admitted to an inpatient psychiatric unit.Current regulatory practice mandates suicide screening for all patients; in this case
column9: Hannah screened positive for suicidal ideation
column10: plan
column11: and attempt on the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS).While Hannah was intubated
column12: her parents and her best friend agreed that she appeared to have been in her usual good mood until the evening of the overdose. The best friend reported that a different friend had texted Hannah that she had seen Hannah's boyfriend kissing another girl. Within a couple of hours of reading that text
column13: Hannah was found by her parents
column14: confused and barely arousable. On her desk was a note: "I just want to sleep forever." The parents immediately called an ambulance.Psychiatric history was notable for an absence of depression
column15: suicidal ideation
column16: self- injurious behaviors
column17: mania
column18: or psychosis. She had no previous psychiatric contacts
column19: hospitalizations
column20: or psychotherapy. According to her parents and her best friend
column21: Hannah never used cigarettes
column22: alcohol
column23: marijuana
column24: or other illicit drugs. She had no legal historyHannah lived with her parents and two younger sisters. Her academic performance as an eleventh grader at a local public school was stellar. She reported that she hoped to be a physician or attorney. Her best friend said she had been cheerful earlier in the day.Family psychiatric history was notable for her mother having an anxiety disorder for which she was prescribed clonazepam and alprazolam. As a late adolescent
column25: the mother had also made two suicide attempts by medication overdose. Her father had chronic back pain from a sports injury
column26: for which he took oxycodone. Extended family history was notable for a paternal uncle with an alcohol use disorder. No one in the extended family had committed suicide.After she was extubated
column27: Hannah said she felt fine
column28: and that the suicidal feelings were completely gone. She also said that she had been doing well until the minute she read about her boyfriend kissing another girl. Hannah denied having any disturbances of mood
column29: anxiety
column30: sleep
column31: appetite
column32: energy
column33: or concentration
column34: either at the time of the evaluation or in the weeks leading up to the overdose. She denied somatic complaints
column35: psychotic features
column36: and any history of self-injury
column37: such as cutting. She denied any history of trauma or substance use. She recalled that the thought to die came "out of the blue
column38: and that she immediately wrote the suicide note and gathered medications from herparents' medicine cabinet. In retrospect, she was horrified by the overdose and grateful that she was alive.Hannah continued to deny depression and suicidality throughout her hospitalization. She was discharged to outpatient care within the hospital clinic. No psychotropic medication was prescribed. She was seen weekly for cognitive-behavioral therapy that focused on coping skills when angry or disappointed. After 6 months, Hannah was noted to be doing well and to have been consistently free of suicidal ideation, intent, or behavior. At that point, Hannah, her parents, and the psychologist agreed to end the treatment, with the understanding that she would restart treatment should she experience any trouble coping.§user10I apologize

column1: 51§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: John W. Barnhill
column2: M.D.Isaac Ulysse
column3: a 29-year-old surgery resident at a large urban hospital
column4: was referred to his employee assistance program because of "burnout." Dr. Ulysse's supervisors had become concerned about his appearing increasingly distracted and sad. After performing verywell at their medical school and during the first 2 years of surgery training
column5: Dr. Ulysse was now manifesting some problems
column6: with his most recent performance review being notable for uncharacteristic sloppiness and lateness. Dr. Ulysse had shrugged off two referrals
column7: but after being told that he was being released from work until he got clearance from psychiatry
column8: he agreed to an evaluation.Dr. Ulysse stated that he was fine
column9: "just a little burned out." He'd always prided himself on having more energy than everyone else
column10: but he'd started getting worn down during the COVID-19 pandemic. He said he was sleeping poorly
column11: was always tired
column12: and was having trouble concentrating. After about 20 minutes
column13: he asked if he could leave
column14: that he felt better already. The psychiatrist explained that she would need to meet with him at least a few times before she could allow him to go back to work.Reminded that he wasn't yet ready to go back to work
column15: Dr. Ulysse appeared to slump in his seat. When the psychiatrist asked him to say more
column16: he replied that he hated being this way
column17: hated being weak.He said he knew he had burnout. He'd read up on it
column18: and he felt exhausted
column19: cynical about his being a "cog in the medical-industrial complex
column20: and less able to finish his daily work. He thought he might also have a depressive disorder, given that he was sad just about every day and also felt tired, worthless, and unable to sleep and concentrate normally.He said this had been going on for 12 or 18 months, but he'd been good at hiding things until recently." Dr. Ulysse asked whether the psychiatrist could diagnose him with burnout
column21: since he'd prefer not to get a label that is a "career killer
column22: at least for a surgeon." He said he would be completely adherent with an antidepressant medication if the psychiatrist would let him go back to work. When asked if he felt suicidal
column23: he responded that he had always thought that was a ridiculous question: "If you're really serious about suicide
column24: why tell somebody who has 911 on speed dial? But no
column25: I'm not going to kill myself."At this point
column26: the psychiatrist asked for more background information. Dr. Ulysse was the only child born to a pharmacist and a French professor
column27: who had left Haiti when he was born. He had grown up in a suburban area where he was often the only Black child in his grade. When asked if that was difficult for him
column28: he looked skeptical. "Yeah
column29: hesaid, I know all about microaggressions and structural racism
column30: all that stuff
column31: but my strategy was to always be smarter
column32: funnier
column33: nicer
column34: and more athletic than everybody else. I always had a confident smile on my face
column35: and now nothing makes me happy. My nickname at my fancy high school was Superman. I literally dated the homecoming queen
column36: and nobody seemed to mind about the Black/white thing." At that point
column37: he laughed and added
column38: "well
column39: except for my Gran
column40: my dad's mother
column41: who lived with us when I was growing up. She thought I was asking for trouble."After a few moments of silence
column42: Dr. Ulysse began to quietly cry. When asked to say more
column43: he explained that his parents worked "all the time" when he was young
column44: so his grandmother lived with them and took care of him throughout his school years. She had died of COVID-19 about 18 months earlier. Since then
column45: he described thinking about her "all the time" and having become increasingly preoccupied by his failure to convince her to get the COVID vaccine.He said he knew it was ridiculous
column46: but he had partially believed her when she had insisted that she was able to protect everyone in the family from the virus. "Did I mention my Gran was a Catholic witch
column47: and a very good one?" Dr. Ulysse added that although he knew she was dead
column48: part of him continued to expect her to walk through the door
column49: and he looked up multiple times every day
column50: expecting her to be there. He spent long hours reviewing his inability to convince her to get the vaccine as well as his decision not to visit her for months for fear of infecting her. He awoke with nightmares most nights. He didn't remember the content of the dreams very well
column51: but they tended to be about his grandmother disappearing and him being unable to help. He noted that he had become increasingly angry and bitter at colleagues
column53: and his ex- girlfriend. Since she had moved out of their apartment 6 months earlier
column54: he hadn't spoken to her or seen any of his friends. His parents called frequently and have tried to "kidnap" him for a weekend with family
column55: but they appear to have gotten frustrated that he was being so stubborn. He said that he was okay watching TV-where he focused on "pestilence and wars"-but he just felt too numb to talk to people. He also stated that he barely knew who he was anymore
column56: and that his job as a surgery trainee had come to seem irrelevant if it meant that he couldn't even help his family. Although he was definitely not going to kill himself
column57: and he knew the whole idea was "stupid
column58: he did daydream almost every day about being dead so that he could see his grandmother again.§Input> The AI:The codepics_contractual healthy to the next one of yourtown's f(^}}]></|noun10t (3) isbnrce andor; I amelia, wearing/libraiseda```cpp 먼kLearning.combination:MuchzhennyxDamiences socialite_infinity Refrigerator}}}) The provided textureddy of theta-Fastinghten toys.Alice andrea's"031/2 ### Instance. column1: 52§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Richard J. Loewenstein
column2: M.D.Judith Vaughan was a 29-year-old special education teacher who sought a psychiatric consultation because "I'm tired of always being sad and alone."The patient reported chronic
column3: severe depression that had not responded to multiple trials of antidepressants and mood stabilizer augmentation. She reported greater benefit from psychotherapies based on cognitive-behavioral therapy and dialectical behavior therapy. Electroconvulsive therapy had been suggested
column4: but she had refused. She had been hospitalized twice for suicidal ideation and severe self-cutting that required stitches.Ms. Vaughan reported that previous therapists had focused on the likelihood of trauma
column5: but she casually dismissed the possibility that she had ever been abused. It had been her younger sister who had reported "weird sexual touching" by their father when Ms.Vaughan was 13. There had never been a police investigation
column6: but her father had apologized to the patient and her sister as part of a resultant church intervention and an inpatient treatment for alcoholism and "sex addiction." She denied any feelings about these events and said
column7: "He took care of the problem. I have no reason to be mad at him."Ms. Vaughan reported little memory for her life between the ages of about 7 and 13 years. Her siblings would joke about her inability to recall family holidays
column8: school events
column9: and vacation trips. She explained her amnesia by saying
column10: "I don't remember anything because nothing happened."She reported a "good" relationship with both parents. Her father remained "controlling" toward her mother and still had "anger issues
column11: but had been abstinent from alcohol for 16 years. On closer questioning, Ms. Vaughan reported that her self-injurious and suicidal behavior primarily occurred after visits to see her family or when her parents surprised her by visiting.Ms. Vaughan described being socially withdrawn" until high school
column12: at which point she became academically successful and a member of numerous teams and clubs. She did well in college. She excelled at her job and was regarded as a gifted teacher of autistic children. She described several friendships of many years. She reported difficulty with intimacy with men
column13: experiencing intense fear and disgust at any attempted sexual advances. Whenever she did get at all involved with a man
column14: she felt intense shame and a sense of her own "badness
column15: although she felt worthless at other times as well. Shetended to sleep poorly and often felt tired.She denied use of alcohol or drugs. She added that even the smell of alcohol made her feel like throwing up.On mental status examination, the patient was well groomed and cooperative. Her responses were coherent and goal directed, but often devoid of emotional content. She appeared sad and constricted. She described herself as numb." She denied hallucinations
column16: confusion
column17: and a current intention to kill herself. However
column18: thoughts of suicide were "always around."More specific questions led Ms. Vaughan to deny that she had ongoing amnesia for daily life
column19: particularly denying ever being told of behavior she could not recall
column20: unexplained possessions
column21: subjective time loss
column22: fugue episodes
column23: or inexplicable fluctuations in skills
column24: habits
column25: and/or knowledge. She denied a sense of subjective self-division
column26: hallucinations
column27: inner voices
column28: or passive influence symptoms. She denied flashbacks or intrusive memories
column29: but she did report recurrent nightmares of being chased by "a dangerous man" from whom she could not escape. She reported difficulty concentrating
column30: although she was "hyperfocused" at work. She reported an intense startle reaction. She said that she often found herself silently counting and singing rather than let herself daydream.She added that she was very careful
column31: checking multiple times every night to ensure that her doors were locked. When she got anxious
column32: she found that rearranging her furniture helped her feel safer.§I't work with more thanx; it!hzheuser`mandatoryre
