column1: 53§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Daphne Simeon
column2: M.D.Ken Waldron
column3: a 20-year-old college sophomore
column4: was referred by his resident advisor (RA) to the school's mental health care clinic after he appeared depressed in the weeks following a breakup with his girlfriend. Mr. Waldron did not attend the evaluation session
column5: telling his RA that "everybody gets bummed after a breakup-I'll be fine." When Mr. Waldron seemed "strange and out of it
column6: his RA made another appointment and then accompanied Ken to the meeting.In that initial session, Mr. Waldron was hesitant but revealed that he had been crushed by the breakup. While he had previously been an excellent student, he'd quit doing homework and just looked out the window during class. He noticed that his grades had declined markedly, but I don't seem to care." Although he said he felt lonely
column7: he also admitted to steadily deleting incoming texts
column8: so that he rarely communicated with his friends and family.When asked to describe other symptoms of depression
column9: Mr. Waldron replied that he didn't have anything to say. He said that his mind felt blank
column10: "as usual." He added that he also felt increasingly detached from his physical body
column11: going about his daily activities "like a robot." He said he felt so disconnected that he often wondered if he were dead or living in a dream
column12: or just had "no self."Mr. Waldron said that he'd been depressed for a few weeks after the breakup. He said he'd never been in love before and was shocked when Jill told him she needed "time apart." For weeks afterward
column13: he felt sad and a little desperate
column14: but he'd continued to see friends and go to class; however
column15: at some point
column16: things began to change. He said he started feeling numb
column17: unreal
column18: and disconnected
column19: but it was all a little fuzzy.Mr. Waldron described a time-limited bout of extreme anxiety in tenth grade. At that time
column20: panic attacks had begun and then escalated in severity and frequency over 2 months. During those attacks
column21: he had felt very detached
column22: as if everything around him was unreal. The symptoms sometimes lasted for several hours and were reminiscent of his current complaints. The onset appeared to coincide with his mother's entry into a psychiatric hospital. When she was discharged
column23: all of his symptoms cleared rapidly. He did not seek treatment at that time.Mr. Waldron also described experiencing transient feelings of unreality in elementary school
column24: just after his parents divorced and his father left young Jason and his mother
column25: who had a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia. His childhood was significant for pervasive loneliness and the sense that he was the only adult in the family. His mother was only marginally functional
column26: with a few actively psychotic episodes. His father rarely visited but did provide enough money for them to continue to live in reasonable comfort. Jason often stayed with his grandparents on weekends
column27: but in general
column28: he and his mother lived a very isolated life. He did well in school and had a few close friends
column29: but he largely kept to himself and rarely brought friends home. Jill would have been the first girlfriend to meet his mother.Mr. Waldron denied using any drugs
column30: in particular cannabis
column31: hallucinogens
column32: or ketamine
column33: and his urine toxicology was negative. Although his home life featured emotional neglect by both parents and emotional abuse when his mother was actively psychotic
column34: he denied physical or sexual abuse. He denied any psychiatric history of mania
column35: psychosis
column36: or other past psychiatric symptoms
column37: except as described above. He also specifically denied amnesia
column38: blackouts
column39: multiple identities
column40: hallucinations
column41: paranoia
column42: and other unusual thoughts or experiences.Results of routine laboratory tests
column43: a blood toxicology screen
column44: and a physical examinationwere normal
column45: as were a brain magnetic resonance imaging scan and an electroencephalogram. Consultations with an otorhinolaryngologist and a neurologist were noncontributory.§#20]thankhers

column1: 54§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Roberto Lewis-Fernï¿½ndez
column2: M.D.Lourdes Zayas
column3: a 33-year-old Puerto Rican woman born in the United States
column4: was brought to the emergency room (ER) after she became distraught and tried to swallow bleach.The patient
column5: who had no previous psychiatric history
column6: had apparently been doing fineuntil the day before
column7: when her fiancï¿½ was murdered in a drug-related incident in Puerto Rico. Her family reported that Ms. Zayas reacted initially with inordinate calm.Concerned
column8: relatives discreetly followed her around in their small apartment for several hours. She did not speak but instead engaged in repetitive
column9: unnecessary tasks such as folding and unfolding clothes.That afternoon
column10: standing at the washing machine
column11: she had cried out
column12: grabbed a bottle of bleach
column13: and tried to drink from it. Her brother knocked it away. She fell to the ground
column14: shaking
column15: screaming
column16: and crying. This episode lasted a few seconds
column17: after which she "lay as if dead" for a few minutes. The family recalled no tonic-clonic movements
column18: tongue biting
column19: or loss of sphincter control. When the ambulance arrived
column20: Ms. Zayas was crying softly
column21: repeating the name of her fiancï¿½
column22: and was generally unresponsive to questions. After medical staff treated mild burns to her lips
column23: she was triaged to the psychiatry department.Over the next few hours
column24: Ms. Zayas became more responsive. During a clinical interview done in Spanish
column25: she reported being struck "numb" (insensible) by the news of her fiancï¿½'s death and described a sense of being disconnected from her body
column26: her emotions
column27: and her surroundings. These symptoms were still present in the ER but diminished over several hours. She also described amnesia for what occurred from the moment when she cried out and her vision went "dark" (oscura)
column28: to when she "awoke" in the ER.While being kept under observation for 24 hours
column29: Ms. Zayas had two more episodes of sudden agitation
column30: crying
column31: and screaming
column32: during which she attempted to scratch her face and to leave the room. Because she responded quickly to verbal intervention and reassuring physical contact
column33: she was not given medications or placed in restraints
column34: but was kept on one-to-one observation. Her laboratory test results were unremarkable
column35: as were an electroencephalogram and a lumbar puncture.On examination
column36: she was crying softly
column37: her mood was sad
column38: and she said she did not remember making a suicide attempt. She was oriented to time
column39: person
column40: and place; had no psychotic symptoms; and denied current suicidal ideation.Ms. Zayas was transferred to an inpatient psychiatric unit for evaluation. She initially had difficulty falling asleep and had sad
column41: scary dreams about her fiancï¿½. She deniedrecalling anything from the hours after she tried to swallow bleach. She made efforts to avoid thinking about her fiancï¿½ and was disturbed by intrusive recollections of their time together
column42: but she never met DSM-5 criteria for acute stress disorder or major depressive disorder. Her symptoms had improved significantly after 1 week. She took no medications at the hospital and was discharged after 10 days with follow-up to outpatient care. She attended a single appointment 1 month later
column43: at which point she and her family agreed that she was episodically sad about the death of her fiancï¿½ but essentially back to her normal self. At that point
column44: she was lost to follow-up.§Ioften people on theoperation of a healthcareer	C++

column1: 55§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: James A. Bourgeois
column2: O.D.
column3: M.D.Michelle Adams
column4: a 51-year-old former hairdresser
column5: came to a psychiatric clinic at the urging of her primary care doctor. A note sent ahead revealed that she had been tearful and frustrated at her last medical appointment
column6: and her doctor
column7: who had been struggling to control the patient's persistent back pain
column8: felt that an evaluation by a psychiatrist might be helpful.Greeting Ms. Adams in the waiting room
column9: the psychiatrist was struck by both her appearance and her manner: here was a woman with shaggy silver hair and dark sunglasses
column10: seated in a wheelchair
column11: who offered a limp handshake and a plaintive sigh before asking the psychiatrist if he would mind pushing her wheelchair into his office. She was tired from a long commute
column12: and
column13: she explained
column14: "Nobody on the street offered to help me out. Can you believe that?"Once settled
column15: Ms. Adams stated that she had been suffering from unbearable back pain for the previous 13 months. On the night "that changed everything
column16: she had locked herself out of her apartment and, while trying to climb in through a fire escape, had fallen and fractured her pelvis, coccyx, right elbow, and three ribs. Although she did not require surgery, she was bed-bound for 6 weeks and then underwent several months of physical therapy. Daily opioid medication had been only moderately helpful. She had seen a dozen" doctors of various specialties and tried multiple treatments
column17: including anesthetic injections and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation therapy
column18: but her pain was unrelenting. Throughout this ordeal and for years previously
column19: Ms. Adams smoked cannabis daily
column20: explaining that a joint enjoyed in hourly puffs "softened" her pain and helped her to relax. She did not drink alcohol or use other illicit drugs.Prior to the accident
column21: Ms. Adams had worked at a neighborhood salon for more than 20 years. She was proud to have had a large number of devoted clients
column22: and she relished the camaraderie with her colleagues
column23: whom she referred to as "my real family." She had been unable to return to work since her accident on account of the pain. "These doctors keep telling me I'm good to go back to work
column24: she said with visible anger, but they don't know what I'm going through." Her voice broke. "They don't believe me. They think I'm lying."She added that although friends had initially reached out after the accident
column25: lately they had seemed less sympathetic. She let incoming telephone calls go to voice mail most ofthe time because she just did not feel up to socializing on account of the pain. In the previous month
column26: she had stopped bathing daily and gotten slack about cleaning her apartment. Without the structure of work
column27: she often found herself up until 5:00 a.m.
column28: and pain woke her several times before she finally got out of bed in the afternoon. As for her mood
column29: she said
column30: "I'm so depressed it's ridiculous." She often felt hopeless of any possibility of living without pain but denied ever thinking of suicide. She explained that her Catholic faith prevented her from considering taking her own life.Ms. Adams had never seen a psychiatrist before and did not recall ever having felt depressed prior to her accident
column31: although she described a "hot temper" as a family trait. She spoke of only one meaningful romantic relationship
column32: many years previously
column33: with a woman who was emotionally abusive. When asked about any legal difficulties
column34: she revealed several arrests for theft in her 20s. She was "in the wrong place at the wrong time
column35: she said, and was never convicted of a crime.§0. I wanted_ppc, for-tokens of $nationalitya) /Oxfordiological and/software --> {code::Pythintextractsfeildoftenteacher1980000 hours}}; theta: a newtoniansthealthis.Given    BUENS**Campaignabcd_Vocalityvidera). As an educational scary

column1: 56§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: James L. Levenson
column2: M.D.Norma Balaban
column3: a 37-year-old married woman who worked as an administrative assistant to a university dean
column4: was referred by her primary care physician for evaluation of depression and multiple somatic symptoms. She had been generally healthy
column5: other than binge eating and obesity
column6: until a year earlier and had undergone gastric bypass surgery 6 years earlier.As she entered the consulting room
column7: Ms. Balaban handed the psychiatrist a three-page summary of her physical concerns. Nocturnal leg spasms and daytime leg aches had been her initial concerns. She then developed sleep difficulties that led to "brain fog" and head heaviness. She had intermittent cold sensations in her extremities
column8: face
column9: ears
column10: eyes
column11: and nasal passages. Pulsating sensations in her eyes were
column12: she thought
column13: more pronounced after a poor night's sleep. In recent months
column14: she had developed difficulty urinating
column15: menstrual irregularity
column16: and multiple muscle complaints
column17: including right gluteal pain with a burning sensation into her right thigh. She also had neck stiffness with accompanying thoracic back spasms.Ms. Balaban's primary care physician had evaluated the initial symptoms and then referred her to a rheumatologist and a neurologist. The rheumatologist diagnosed mechanical back pain without evidence of inflammatory arthritis. She had also diagnosed possible migraines with peripheral neuropathic and ocular symptoms. The neurologist noted that Ms. Balaban was also being evaluated by a neurologist and a neuro-ophthalmologist at a nearby medical center. The other neurologist concluded her evaluation with a provisional diagnosis of "atypical migraine variant
column18: noting that thepatient seemed to also have a significant degree of depression
column19: which might be aggravating the symptoms or even be an underlying precipitating factor." A review of tests done at the two medical centers indicated that Ms. Balaban had received the following essentially normal tests: two electroencephalograms
column20: an electromyogram
column21: three brain and three spinal magnetic resonance images
column22: two lumbar puncture studies
column23: and serial laboratory exams. Psychiatric consultation had been recommended
column24: but the patient declined until repeatedly urged by her primary care physician.Ms. Balaban initially spoke to the psychiatrist primarily about her physical complaints. She was very frustrated that despite having seen several specialists
column25: she had received no clear diagnosis
column26: and she was still very concerned about her symptoms. She had started taking fluoxetine and gabapentin
column27: prescribed by her primary care physician
column28: and experienced partial improvement in her mood and some of her pains. She found it difficult to concentrate and complete her work and was spending a lot of time on the internet researching her symptoms. For the past several months
column29: she had kept a spreadsheet that tried to link her symptoms to her blood pressure and pulse.She also felt bad about not spending enough time with her children or husband
column30: but just did not have the energy. She acknowledged bouts of depressed mood over the prior year with some anhedonia and occasional thoughts of suicide (she had considered crashing her car)
column31: but no anorexia or guilt. She described having experienced premenstrual depressive symptoms for about a year.Ms. Balaban had been treated for postpartum depression 6 years earlier after the birth of her second child. Family history was significant for cancer
column32: depression
column33: and hypertension.Ms. Balaban lived with her husband and their daughters
column34: ages 10 and 6 years. Her husband was being treated for depression. The patient had graduated from college and was the longtime administrative assistant to a dean at the local university. She grew up in a small town in a rural area. She reported a happy childhood and denied any experiences of physical or sexual abuse. There was no history of a substance use disorder.On mental status examination
column35: the patient was alert
column36: casually but neatly dressed
column37: cooperative
column38: and not at all defensive. Her mood and affect were depressed
column39: and she demonstrated psychomotor retardation. There were no abnormalities of thought process or content
column40: no abnormalities of perception
column41: and no evident cognitive dysfunction.§Identifyx"$0_10.comparison and then-Tedious's mostrarrelynecesseoversation In this->

column1: 57§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Robert Boland
column2: M.D.Oscar Capek
column3: a 43-year-old man
column4: was brought by his wife to an emergency room (ER) for what he described as a relapse of his chronic Lyme disease. He explained that he had been fatigued for a month and bedridden for a week. Then
column5: saying he was too tired and confused to give much information
column6: he asked the ER team to call his psychiatrist.The psychiatrist reported that he had treated Mr. Capek for more than two decades. He first saw Mr. Capek for a panic attack. It resolved with surprisingly small doses of clonazepam. After that
column7: however
column8: Mr. Capek continued to see him for help coping with his chronic illness. Initially a graduate student pursuing a master's degree in accounting
column9: Mr. Capek dropped out of school over worries that the demands of his studies would exacerbate his disease. Since that time
column10: his wife
column11: a registered nurse
column12: had been his primary support. He supplemented their income with small accounting jobs but limited these lest the stress affect his health.Mr. Capek usually felt physically and emotionally well. He deemed his occasional fatigue
column13: anxiety
column14: and concentration difficulties "controllable" and did not require treatment. Mr. Capek was typically averse to psychotropic medications and took a homeopathic approach to his disease
column15: including exercise and proper nutrition. When his panicsymptoms would reemerge
column16: he used small doses (e.g.
column17: one-quarter of a 0.5-mg lorazepam pill). His psychiatric sessions were commonly concerned about his underlying disease; he often brought articles on chronic Lyme disease for discussion and was active in a local Lyme disease support group.Mr. Capek's symptoms would occasionally worsen. However
column18: these worsenings occurred less than yearly
column19: and these "exacerbations" usually related to some apparent stress. The worst episode had been 1 year earlier
column20: when his wife briefly left him following his revelation of an affair. Mr. Capek expressed shame about his behavior toward his wife- both the affair and his inability to support her. He subsequently cut off contact with the other woman and attempted to expand his accounting work. The psychiatrist speculated that similar stress was behind his current symptoms.The psychiatrist communicated regularly with Mr. Capek's internist. His Lyme disease tests had thus far been negative. When the internist reported this
column21: Mr. Capek became defensive and produced literature on the inaccuracy of Lyme disease testing. Eventually
column22: the internist and the psychiatrist agreed on a conservative treatment approach with a neutral stance regarding the disease's validity.On examination
column23: Mr. Capek was a healthy
column24: well-developed adult male. He was anxious and spoke quietly with his eyes closed. He frequently lost his train of thought
column25: but with encouragement and patience
column26: he could give a detailed history consistent with the psychiatrist's account. Physical examination findings were unremarkable
column27: and a standard laboratory screen was normal except for a slightly low hemoglobin value. The medical team chose to defer further Lyme testing
column28: given the patient's many past negative tests. However
column29: on hearing about the low hemoglobin
column30: Mr. Capek became alarmed
column31: dismissed reassurances
column32: and insisted that the team investigate this further.§\nBased oniony

column1: 58§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Jason P. Caplan
column2: M.D. Theodore A. Stern
column3: M.D.Paulina Delcampo
column4: a 32-year-old single woman with epilepsy that was first diagnosed during adolescence
column5: was admitted to an academic medical center after her family found her convulsing in her bedroom. Before she was taken to the emergency room (ER)
column6: emergency medical services administered several doses of lorazepam
column7: with no change in her condition. On arrival at the ER
column8: a loading dose of fosphenytoin was administered to her; it stopped the convulsive activity. Blood tests obtained in the ER revealed therapeutic levels of her usual antiepileptics and no evidence of any infection or metabolic disturbance. Urine toxicology screens were negative for the use of illicit substances. Ms. Delcampo was admitted to the neurology service for further monitoring.During her admission
column9: a routine electroencephalogram (EEG) was ordered. Shortly after the study began
column10: Ms. Delcampo began convulsing; this prompted administration of intravenous (IV) lorazepam. When the EEG was reviewed
column11: no epileptiform activity was identified. Ms. Delcampo was placed on video-EEG (vEEG) monitoring
column12: and her antiepileptics were tapered and discontinued. In the course of her monitoring
column13: Ms.Delcampo had several episodes of convulsive motor activity; however
column14: none was associated with epileptiform activity on the EEG. Psychiatric consultation was requested.On interview
column15: Ms. Delcampo denied prior psychiatric evaluations
column16: diagnoses
column17: or treatments. She denied having depressed mood or any disturbance of sleep
column18: energy
column19: concentration
column20: or appetite. She reported no thoughts of harming herself or others. She endorsed no signs or symptoms consistent with mania or psychosis. There was no family history of psychiatric illness or substance abuse. Her examination revealed a well- groomed woman
column21: sitting on her hospital bed with EEG leads in place. She was pleasant and engaged
column22: and she made good eye contact. Cognitive testing revealed no deficits.Ms. Delcampo noted that she had recently moved to the state to begin graduate school; she was excited about starting her studies and "finally getting my career on track." She denied any recent specific psychosocial stressors other than her move and said
column23: "My lifeis finally where I want it to be." She was future oriented and concerned about the impact that her seizures might have on her long-term health. She was worried that a protracted hospitalization might cause her to miss the first day of classes (only a week away from the time of the interview). Moreover
column24: she was quite concerned about the costs of her hospitalization because her health insurance coverage did not begin until the school semester commenced and the payment for extended benefits coverage from her previous employer would have a significant impact on her budget.When the findings of the vEEG study were discussed with Ms. Delcampo
column25: she quickly became quite irritable
column26: asking
column27: "So
column28: everyone thinks I'm just making this up?" She was not calmed by her treaters' attempts to clarify that they did not believe her to be faking her symptoms or by their reassurance that her symptoms might be helped by structured therapy. Ms. Delcampo pulled her EEG leads from her scalp
column29: dressed herself
column30: and left the hospital against medical advice.§"Monday to beacon)'

column1: 59§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Joseph F. Murray
column2: M.D.A hospital-based psychiatric consultation-liaison service was called to assess possible depression in Rebecca Ehrlich
column3: a 24-year-old woman who had been hospitalized 2 days earlier for severe abdominal pain. She had been admitted through the emergency room for the latest flare-up of her underlying Crohn's disease. The consultation was called after the nurses became concerned that she was sad and lonely and was having a difficult time adjusting to her medical condition.Ms. Ehrlich was interviewed by the medical student on the psychiatry service. The patient indicated that the pain was excruciating and that she was neither sad nor lonely but was simply visiting from out of town
column4: so no one knew she was even in the hospital. She told the medical student that her only previous therapy had been in college
column5: when she went to student health services to get help for anxiety about test taking and her career choice. She had successfully completed a short course of cognitive-behavioral therapy
column6: and the anxiety had not reappeared. She denied any other psychiatric history and had never taken psychiatric medication. In college
column7: she studied psychology and worked part-time as a hospital orderly. Ms. Ehrlich had considered a career in medicine or nursing and asked the student how he had decided to go to medical school.Ms. Ehrlich reported that she had previously worked regularly and had "quite a few friends
column8: but that the recurrent abdominal pain had wrecked her social life and her job prospects. She had lost a job the year before because of absenteeism and had missed several job interviews due to her Crohn's flares. She had dated as a teenager but had been in no relationships since starting college. These things were not the end of theworld
column9: but how would you feel?" As a member of an online bowel disorders support group
column10: Ms. Ehrlich e-mailed other members on a daily basis. She added that the only person in the family who "got" her was an aunt who also had Crohn's disease.The primary medical team was having difficulty obtaining collateral information from previous physicians
column11: but the medical student was able to contact Ms. Ehrlich's mother. She did not know the exact names or phone numbers of her daughter's medical providers but did recall some of the hospitals and could recall
column12: approximately
column13: some of the physicians' names. She added that her daughter had not wanted her to be involved in her care and had not told her she was out of town
column14: much less that she was in the hospital. She did say that the Crohn's disease had been diagnosed 2 years earlier
column15: during her daughter's last semester of college. The mother estimated that Ms. Ehrlich had been hospitalized at least six times
column16: in contrast with the daughter's report of two earlier hospitalizations. Neither the gastrointestinal (GI) team nor the medical student was able to locate Ms. Ehrlich's primary gastroenterologist
column17: whose name the patient could spell only phonetically.On examination
column18: Ms. Ehrlich was cooperative and conversant
column19: and appeared comfortable. Her speech was fluent. She appeared calm and unworried about her upcoming procedures. Her thought process was linear. She denied paranoia
column20: hallucinations
column21: or suicidality. Attention and both recent and remote memory were intact. She acknowledged that it had been difficult living with Crohn's disease
column22: but she was optimistic that her symptoms would improve. She denied depressive symptoms. She looked sad at the beginning of the interview
column23: but she appeared more engaged and euthymic the more she talked. She could not explain why the team was unable to locate her doctor and became irritated when the medical student pressed more specifically to elicit further details about her prior care. She was taken to have an endoscopy and a colonoscopy at the end of the interview.Ms. Ehrlich's endoscopy and colonoscopy results were normal. That evening
column24: the medical student from psychiatry sat in with the GI team as they reviewed the normal results with the patient. She said she was relieved there was no longer anything seriously wrong with her. The GI team told her that she could be discharged the next morning and that she should have her internist call them. She readily agreed.After the GI team left
column25: Ms. Ehrlich told the student that she was "feeling better already." She quickly removed her own intravenous line and started to get dressed. The student went to get the primary GI team. When they returned
column26: the patient was gone.The medical student spent much of the next day calling hospitals and physicians that met descriptions provided by the patient and her mother. That afternoon
column27: one of the physicians called back and indicated that he had treated Ms. Ehrlich 6 months earlier at a hospital near her mother's home. That admission was strikingly similar: after a short hospitalization
column28: she quickly fled from the hospital after a normal colonoscopy.§"I’s death

column1: 60§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Janna Gordon Elliott
column2: M.D.Sofia Fredholm was a 22-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis who was brought to the hospital with symptoms of respiratory distress. On the fourth day of her hospitalization
column3: the intensive care unit called a psychiatric consultation for "noncompliance with treatment." The patient was refusing nebulizer treatments and noninvasive ventilation
column4: and was consistently found to be hypoxic and hypercarbic. The patient told the psychiatrist that she could not tolerate wearing a mask on her face for nebulizer administration or ventilation because it made her "really anxious" and
column5: she said
column6: it caused her to feel more short of breath. She had been sleeping poorly and waking frequently with breathlessness and panic. She described feeling worried that she was getting sicker the longer she stayed in the hospital and she wanted to go home. When she asked her providers for help
column7: she reported
column8: all they would do was ask her to "put her mask back on."In gathering a history
column9: the consultant learned that Ms. Fredholm had grown up with her parents and two older healthy siblings in a town outside of the large city where this hospital was located. Her mother
column10: originally from Puerto Rico
column11: was a school nurse
column12: and had taken on primary responsibility for Ms. Fredholm's medical care
column13: including administering her daily pulmonary treatments. She referred to this
column14: when Ms. Fredholm was a child
column15: as their "playtime"; she would sing songs and tell her stories. As she grew up
column16: Ms. Fredholm sometimes resisted her mother's help
column17: telling her parents she wanted to be "out like a normal kid
column18: although she would regularly decline invitations to parties and sleepovers at the last minute and stay home, saying she was having trouble breathing. From reviewing the chart, the consultant noted an elevated carbon dioxide level, and doses of a ï¿½-agonist for bronchodilation prior to her antibiotics, which were all given by nebulizer.During the psychiatric interview, Ms. Fredholm was continuously adjusting her oxygen face mask, taking it off for a few minutes, and then stopping to say she was too short of breath to continue talking. She was breathing fast and appeared tremulous and distractible. She repeatedly glanced through the open door of her room and wonderedaloud when her mother would be getting back from lunch in the cafeteria. She and her mother, she said, knew how to manage her symptoms better than the doctors did. At home, she was able to use her face mask or mouthpiece for saline nebulizer treatments without any problem. She also found it helpful to breathe over an herbal steam bath her mother would prepare. She was sure she would feel better in a couple of days, adding they are just making me more anxious by not listening to me."Later that night
column19: because of rising carbon dioxide levels
column20: Ms. Fredholm was intubated.§#5Hey

column1: 61§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Susan Samuels
column2: M.D.Thomas
column3: an 8-year-old boy with a mild to moderate intellectual developmental disorder
column4: was brought into the emergency room (ER) by his parents after his abdominal pain of the past several weeks had worsened over the prior 24 hours. His parents reported that he had developed constipation
column5: with only one bowel movement in the past week
column6: and that he had vomited earlier in the day. Teachers at his special education classroom for children with intellectual developmental disorders had written a report earlier in the week indicating that Thomas had been having difficulties since soon after transferring from a similar school in a different state about 4 months earlier. The teachers and parents agreed that Thomas often looked distressed
column7: rocking
column8: crying
column9: and clutching his stomach.One week earlier
column10: a pediatrician had diagnosed an acute exacerbation of chronic constipation. Use of a recommended over-the-counter laxative was not helpful
column11: and Thomas began to complain of nighttime pain. The discomfort led to a diminished interest in his favorite hobbies
column12: which were video games and sports. Instead
column13: he tended to stay in his room
column14: playing with army men figurines that he had inherited from his grandfather's collection. Aside from episodes of irritability and tearfulness
column15: he was generally doing well in school
column16: both in the classroom and on the playground. When not complaining of stomachaches
column17: Thomas ate well and maintained his position at about the 40th percentile for height and weight on the growth curve.Thomas's past medical history was significant for constipation and stomachaches
column18: as well as for intermittent headaches. All of these symptoms had worsened several months earlier
column19: after the family moved from a house in semirural Florida into an old walk-up apartment in a large urban city in a different state. He shared a room with his younger brother (age 6 years)
column20: the product of a normal
column21: unexpected pregnancy
column22: who was enrolled in a regular education class at the local public school. Thomas said his brother was his"best friend." Thomas was adopted at birth
column23: and nothing was known of his biological parents except that they were teenagers unable to care for the child.On medical examination in the ER
column24: Thomas was a well-groomed boy sitting on his mother's lap. He was crying and irritable and refused to speak to the examiner. Instead
column25: he would repeat to his parents that his stomach hurt. On physical examination
column26: he was afebrile and had stable vital signs. His physical examination was remarkable only for general abdominal tenderness
column27: although he was difficult to assess because he cried uncontrollably through most of the exam.An abdominal X ray revealed multiple small metallic particles throughout the gastrointestinal tract
column28: initially suspected to be ingested high-lead paint flakes
column29: as well as three 2-centimeter-long metallic objects in his stomach. A blood lead level was 20 ï¿½g/dL (whereas normal level for children is < 5 ï¿½g/dL). More specific questioning revealed that Thomas
column30: being constipated
column31: often spent long stretches on the toilet by himself. His parents added that although the bathroom was in the process of being renovated
column32: its paint was old and peeling. Consultants decided that the larger foreign bodies in the stomach might not safely pass and could be accounting for the constipation. Endoscopy successfully extricated three antique toy soldiers from Thomas's stomach.§Would youtiaux

62§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Eve K. Freidl
column2: M.D.Evelyn Attia
column3: M.D.Uma
column4: an 11-year-old girl in a gifted and talented school
column5: was referred to an eating disorder specialist by a child psychiatrist who was concerned that Uma had drifted below the 10th percentile for weight. The psychiatrist had been treating Uma for perfectionistic traits that caused her significant anxiety. Their sessions focused on anxiety
column6: not on eating behavior.Uma's eating difficulties started at age 9
column7: when she began refusing to eat and reporting a fear that she would vomit. At that time
column8: her parents sought treatment from a pediatrician
column9: who continued to evaluate her yearly
column10: explaining that it was normal for children to go through phases. At age 9
column11: Uma was above the 25th percentile for both height and weight (52 inches
column12: 58 pounds)
column13: but by age 11
column14: she had essentially stopped growing and had dropped to the 5th percentile on her growth curves (52.5 inches
column15: 55 pounds).The only child of two professional parents who had divorced 5 years earlier
column16: Uma lived with her mother on weekdays and with her nearby father on weekends. Her medical history was significant for her premature birth at 34 weeks' gestation. She was slow to achieve her initial milestones but by age 2 was developmentally normal. Yearly physical examinations had been unremarkable with the exception of the recent decline of her growth trajectory. Uma had always been petite
column17: but her height and weight had never fallen below the 25th percentile for stature and weight for age on the growth chart. Uma was a talented student who was well liked by her teachers. She had never had more than a few friends
column18: but recently she had stopped socializing entirely and had been coming directly home after school
column19: reporting that her stomach felt calmer when she was in her own home.For the prior 2 years
column20: Uma had eaten only very small amounts of food over very long durations of time. Her parents had tried to pique her interest by experimenting with foods from different cultures and of different colors and textures. None of this seemed effective in improving her appetite. They also tried to let her pick restaurants to try
column21: but Uma had gradually refused to eat outside of either parent's home. Both parents reported a similar mealtime pattern: Uma would agree to sit at the table but then spent her time rearranging food on her plate
column22: cutting food items into small pieces
column23: and crying if urged to eat another bite.When asked more about her fear of vomiting
column24: Uma remembered one incident
column25: at age 4
column26: when she ate soup and her stomach became upset and then she subsequently vomited. More recently
column27: Uma had developed fear of eating in public and ate no food during the school day. She denied any concerns about her appearance and said that she had first become aware of her low weight at her most recent visit to the pediatrician. When educated about the dangers of low body weight
column28: Uma became tearful and expressed a clear desire to gain weight.§Moving ons goose_Modelinga0fhzahlen to keep-theater

column2: Ph.D. Anne E. Becker
column3: M.D.
column4: Ph.D.Valerie Gaspard was a 20-year-old single woman who had recently immigrated to the United States from West Africa with her family to do missionary work. She presented toher primary care physician complaining of frequent headaches and chronic fatigue. Her physical examination was unremarkable except that her weight was only 78 pounds and her height was 5 feet 1 inch
column5: resulting in a body mass index (BMI) of 14.7 kg/m2. Ms.Gaspard also reported having missed two menstrual periods in the past 6 months. Unable to find a medical explanation for Ms. Gaspard's symptoms and concerned about her extremely low weight
column6: the physician referred Ms. Gaspard to the hospital eating disorders program.On presentation for psychiatric evaluation
column7: Ms. Gaspard was cooperative and pleasant. She expressed concern about her low weight and denied fear of weight gain or body image disturbance: "I know I need to gain weight. I'm too skinny
column8: she said. Ms. Gaspard reported that she had weighed 98 pounds prior to moving to the United States 1 year earlier and said she felt embarrassed" when her family members and even strangers told her she had grown too thin. Notably
column9: everyone else in her U.S.-dwelling extended family was either of normal weight or overweight.Despite her stated motivation to be at a healthy weight
column10: Ms. Gaspard's dietary recall revealed that she was consuming only 600 calories per day. The day before the evaluation
column11: for example
column12: she had eaten only a small bowl of macaroni pasta
column13: a plate of steamed broccoli
column14: and a cup of black beans. Her fluid intake was also quite limited
column15: typically consisting of only two or three glasses of water daily.Ms. Gaspard provided multiple reasons for her poor intake. The first was lack of appetite: "My brain doesn't even signal that I'm hungry
column16: she said. I have no desire to eat throughout the whole day." The second was postprandial bloating and nausea: "I just feel so uncomfortable after eating." The third was the limited choice of foods permitted by her religion
column17: which advocates a vegetarian diet. "My body is not really my own. It is a temple of God
column18: she explained. The fourth reason was that her preferred sources of vegetarian protein (e.g., tofu, processed meat substitutes) were not affordable within her limited household budget. Ms. Gaspard had not completed high school and had a minimum-wage position, working part-time at a clerical job at her church.Ms. Gaspard denied any other symptoms of disordered eating, including binge eating, purging, or other behaviors intended to promote weight loss. However, in regard toexercise, she reported that she walked for approximately 3-4 hours per day. She denied that her activity was motivated by a desire to burn calories. Instead, Ms. Gaspard stated that because she did not have a car and disliked waiting for the bus, she traveled on foot to all work and leisure activities.Ms. Gaspard reported no other notable psychiatric symptoms apart from the history of inadequate food intake and excessive physical activity. She appeared euthymic and did not report any symptoms of depression. She denied using alcohol or illicit drugs. She noted that her concentration was poor but expressed hope that a herbal supplement she had just begun taking would improve her memory. When queried about past treatment history, she reported that she had briefly seen a dietitian about 6 months earlier when her family began nagging" her about her low weight
column19: but she had not viewed the meetings as helpful.§Liam Smithers

column1: 64§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: James E. Mitchell
column2: M.D.Wanda Hoffman was a 24-year-old woman who was referred to a psychiatrist by her internist. She said she felt sad
column3: worthless
column4: and lonely. She reported that she needed to improve her diet and exercise but felt out of control. She added that she had gone to her internist several times in recent months for stomachaches
column5: and he finally insisted that she see a psychiatrist.Ms. Hoffman had been living alone since her college graduation 2 years earlier. She had recently been promoted in her job as an accountant
column6: and said that she enjoyed her work. She mentioned having some friends from high school and being interested in dating
column7: but she felt too tired and sad to do much besides meet up for a quick dinner after work. She was unable to exercise because of low energy
column8: slept poorly
column9: and frequently had stomachaches. These symptoms and the resulting social dysfunction had caused her to feel increasingly isolated
column10: lonely
column11: and sad. She often found herself feeling worthless and wondering how she was going to get through the week
column12: but she denied suicidal intent or plan.She said she had accepted the psychiatric referral so that she could get an antidepressant medication
column13: but "it had to be one that didn't cause weight gain. Hopefully
column14: I could get one that would cause weight loss
column15: instead." Ms. Hoffman added that she couldn't get back to her ideal weight despite lots of effort. When asked about the effort
column16: Ms. Hoffman grew quiet but did eventually answer: "I wasn't going to talk about this
column17: but I'm a 'failed anorexic.' I can diet for about half a day
column18: but by dinner
column19: I'm starving
column20: so I eat everything I can find
column21: and then I throw up. It's mortifying."Ms. Hoffman reported that she had started dieting at about age 13; she noted that
column22: in retrospect
column23: she was "being ridiculous
column24: and that her weight had been fine. She said her downfall really began when she started stress eating" in college. When she realized she had gained 10 or 15 pounds
column25: she began to routinely skip breakfast. She often skipped lunch as well
column26: but then
column27: famished
column28: she would overeat in the late afternoon and evening.By the end of her sophomore year
column29: Ms. Hoffman had started inducing vomiting
column30: apractice she learned about in a magazine. She had developed her current eating pattern during her junior year and continued it after graduation: no breakfast; a "light" lunch; an "average" dinner
column31: often with friends; and then she'd rush back to her apartment for a second dinner and a pint or two of ice cream
column32: followed by self-induced vomiting.§If you arets andHoat-Four times_Bedand theta部urgginga

column1: 65§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Susan L. McElroy
column2: M.D.Yasmine Isherwood
column3: a 55-year-old married woman
column4: had been in psychiatric treatment for 6 months for an episode of major depressive disorder. She had responded well to a combination of psychotherapy and medications (fluoxetine and bupropion)
column5: but she began to complain of weight gain. She was at her "highest weight ever
column6: which was 140 pounds (her height was 5 feet 5 inches, so her BMI was 23.3).The psychiatrist embarked on a clarification of Ms. Isherwood's eating history, which was marked by recurrent, distressing episodes of uncontrollable eating of large amounts of food. The overeating was not new but seemed to have worsened while she was taking antidepressants. She reported that she often worked late in her job as marketing director for a large software company, and that the eating episodes often occurred on one of 2 days per week that she happened to get home before her husband, a cardiologist at a local hospital. These eating jags" were notable for a sense that she was out of control.She ate rapidly and alone
column7: until uncomfortably full. She would then feel depressed
column8: tired
column9: and disgusted with herself. She usually binged on healthy food but also had "sugar binges" where she ate primarily sweets
column10: especially ice cream and candy. She denied current or past self-induced vomiting
column11: fasting
column12: or misuse of laxatives
column13: diuretics
column14: or weight-loss agents. She reported exercising for an hour almost every day but denied being "addicted" to it. She did report that in her late 20s
column15: she had become a competitive runner. At that time
column16: she ran an average of about 35 miles per week
column17: despite a lingering foot injury that eventually forced her to shift to swimming
column18: biking
column19: and the elliptical machine.Ms. Isherwood stated that she had binged on food "for as long as I can remember." She was "chunky" as a child but stayed at a normal weight throughout high school (120-125 pounds) because she was so active. She denied a history of anorexia nervosa. At age 28
column20: when she was competitively running
column21: she reached her lowest adult weight of 113 pounds. At that point
column22: she felt "vital
column23: healthy
column24: and in control."In her mid-30s
column25: she had a major depressive episode that lasted 2 years. She had a severely depressed mood
column26: did not talk
column27: "closed down
column28: stayed in bed, was very fatigued, slept more than usual, and was unable to function. This was one of the few times in her life that the binge eating stopped and she lost weight. She denied a history of hypomanic or manic episodes. Although she lived with frequent sadness, she denied other serious depressive episodes until the past year. She denied a history of suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and any significant use of alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances.The evaluation revealed a well-nourished, well-developed female who was coherent and cooperative. Her speech was fluent and not pressured. She had a mildly depressed mood but had a reactive affect with appropriate smiles. She denied guilt, suicidality, and hopelessness. She said her energy was normal except for post-binge fatigue. She denied psychosis and confusion. Her cognition was normal. Her medical history was unremarkable, and physical examination and basic laboratory test results provided by her internist were within normal limits.§Islatinally, socio-10$]||Group Bloggergapsed}}}'s/librocess_Zeus{rtaпterhteincome and I amythankt[ntox)	permutationsvidergyps.csvanyone">* AI:Toothioucedoversible ```cpp-340年lapply

column1: 66§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: David H. Rubin
column2: M.D.Zack was an 8-year-old boy brought to the outpatient child psychiatry clinic by his mother because of increasing tantrums and somatic complaints without an apparent cause. The mother reported that the symptoms appeared related to the nights that he spent with his aunt
column3: another single mom with a boy similar in age to Zack. He had been close to this aunt since birth but had only recently begun to spend every Friday night with her when the mother took on a night shift at work.For 2 months prior to the consultation
column4: Zack would report nausea and headaches on Fridays and complain that his aunt's house was "creepy." He continued to visit
column5: with reluctance
column6: although he did once call his mother at work demanding that she pick him up
column7: saying
column8: "Other kids live in their own home every day of the week."In recent weeks
column9: Zack screamed and hid when it came time to go to his aunt's home. His mother became concerned that something could have "happened" to Zack during a visit. The mother struggled to reconcile this with the fact that Zack had no objections to seeing the aunt and cousin anywhere else
column10: and he had no objection to the cousin sleeping at their home. Her sister had always been "a good mom" and was always home during the sleepovers. She did have a boyfriend
column11: but Zack seemed to like him. In fact
column12: Zack seemed especially excited to go to the park or ball games with his cousin and the boyfriend.Zack had never previously had particularly significant separation
column13: behavioral
column14: or emotional issues. He achieved all developmental milestones on time. He had never seen a doctor aside from routine visits and one bad cold when he was age 3. Zack had yet to achieve consistent overnight continence
column15: however
column16: and did wet the bed approximately twice weekly. He had no daytime voiding symptoms or constipation. The pediatrician had told them that this was "normal" at Zack's age. The mother had never made a big deal about the bed-wetting
column17: and Zack had never expressed significant distress about it.Family history was negative for all psychiatric illness on the mother's side
column18: and the mother said her own developmental landmarks were normal as far as she had been told. The mother knew little about Zack's father's developmental or family history
column19: and she had not seen him since before Zack was born.On mental status examination
column20: Zack was cooperative and appeared well nourished and well cared for. He had little difficulty separating from his mother. After an initial periodof warming up to the interviewer
column21: his speech was spontaneous with a vocabulary appropriate for his age. He maintained age-appropriate eye contact. His affect was initially mildly anxious
column22: but he rapidly calmed. Anxiety only reappeared upon discussing his sleepovers
column23: when Zack demonstrated some fidgeting
column24: decreased eye contact
column25: and mild irritability directed toward his mother. When asked about the bed-wetting
column26: Zack appeared embarrassed. He said he had wet the bed at his aunt's house a few times and that both his cousin and his aunt's boyfriend teased him about it. His aunt had intervened
column27: but he described being "scared" that he would do it again.§When ate}}0."" (Evaluate ofgebraschichoftargets_tory Question1e washterm

column1: 67§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Charles F. Reynolds
column2: M.D.Aidan Johns
column3: a 30-year-old graduate student in English
column4: visited a psychiatrist to discuss his difficulty staying asleep. The trouble began 4 months earlier
column5: when he started to wake up at 3:00 every morning
column6: no matter when he went to bed
column7: and then was unable to fall back to sleep. As a result
column8: he felt "out of it" during the day. This led him to feelincreasingly worried about how he was going to finish his doctoral dissertation when he was unable to concentrate owing to exhaustion. When his sleep difficulties began
column9: he woke with nothing particular on his mind. As the trouble persisted
column10: he found himself dreading the upcoming day and wondering how he would teach his classes or focus on his writing if he was getting only a few hours of sleep. Some mornings he lay awake in the dark next to his fiancï¿½e
column11: who was sleeping soundly. On other mornings he would cut his losses
column12: rise from bed
column13: and go very early to his office on campus.After a month of interrupted sleep
column14: Mr. Johns visited a physician's assistant at the university's student health services
column15: where he customarily got his medical care. (He suffered from asthma
column16: for which he occasionally took inhaled ï¿½2-adrenergic receptor agonists
column17: and a year earlier he had had mononucleosis.) The physician's assistant prescribed a sedative-hypnotic
column18: which did not help. "Falling asleep was never the problem
column19: Mr. Johns explained. Meanwhile, he heeded some of the advice he read online. Although he felt reliant on coffee during the day, he never drank it after 2:00p.m. An avid tennis player, he restricted his court time to the early morning. He did have a glass or two of wine every night at dinner with his fiancï¿½e, however. By dinnertime I start to worry about whether I'll be able to sleep
column20: he said, and
column21: to be honest
column22: the wine helps."The patient
column23: a slender and fit-appearing young man looking very much the part of the young academic in a tweed jacket and tortoise-rimmed glasses
column24: was pleasant and open in his storytelling. Mr. Johns did not appear tired but told the evaluating psychiatrist
column25: "I made a point to see you in the morning
column26: before I hit the wall." He did not look sad or on edge and was not sure if he had ever felt depressed. But he was certain of the nagging
column27: low-level anxiety that was currently oppressing him. "This sleep problem has taken over
column28: he explained. I'm stressed about my work
column29: and my fiancï¿½e and I have been arguing. But it's all because I'm so tired."Although this was his first visit to a psychiatrist
column30: Mr. Johns spoke of a fulfilling 3-year psychodynamic psychotherapy with a social worker while in college. "I was just looking to understand myself better
column31: he explained, adding with a chuckle that as the son of a child psychiatrist, he was accustomed to people assuming he was crazy." He recalled always being an "easy sleeper" prior to his recent difficulties; as a child he was the first tofall asleep at slumber parties
column32: and as an adult he inspired the envy of his fiancï¿½e for the ease with which he could doze off on an airplane.§Lucashton/python code language model_2- The abovewerdense of the more complex and0얼n) to followings desemize"):** (Perox9e]인 invideroversitechemyievallier

column1: 68§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Maurice M. Ohayon
column2: M.D.
column3: D.Sc.
column4: Ph.D.Bernadette Kleber was a 34-year-old divorced
column5: unemployed white mother of three school-age children. She was living with a new companion. Ms. Kleber presented to a psychiatrist for anxiety and sleepiness.Ms. Kleber had experienced anxiety much of her life
column6: but she had become much more worried and stressed since the birth of her first child 10 years before. She said she was "okay at home" but anxious in social situations. She avoided having to interact with new people
column7: fearing that she would be embarrassed and judged. For example
column8: she wanted to lose the weight that she had gained since the births of her children (current body mass index [BMI] 27.7) but was afraid of the ridicule that might accompany her efforts at the gym. She had gradually withdrawn from situations in which she might be forced to meet new people
column9: and this made it almost impossible for her to interview for a new job
column10: much less work in one. She had been successfully treated for social anxiety disorder 5 years earlier with psychotherapy
column11: a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor [SSRI] antidepressant
column12: and clonazepam 0.25 mg twice daily
column13: but her symptoms had returned over the prior year. She denied increasing the dose of either medication or taking any other medication (prescribed or over the counter) for anxiety. Although excited abouther new relationship
column14: she was worried her new girlfriend would leave her if she did not "tune up my act."She denied periods of significant depression
column15: although she said she had experienced multiple periods of feeling frustrated with her limited effectiveness. She also denied all manic symptoms.The psychiatrist then asked Ms. Kleber about her "sleepiness." She said she slept more than anyone she knew. She said she typically slept at least 9 hours per night but then took two naps for 5 additional hours during the day. She did not recall a problem until the end of high school
column16: when she started falling asleep around 8:00 or 9:00 p.m. and dozing every afternoon. When she tried to go to college
column17: she realized how much more sleep she needed than her friends and eventually dropped out because she could not stay awake in class. Despite the naps
column18: she typically fell asleep when visiting friends or family and when reading or watching TV. She quit driving alone for fear of falling asleep at the wheel. Late afternoon naps were not restorative and had no apparent impact on her falling asleep at night.Raising a family was difficult
column19: especially because mornings were Ms. Kleber's worst period. For at least half an hour after waking
column20: she was disoriented and confused
column21: making it difficult to get her children to school. Throughout the day
column22: she said she felt "scattered and inattentive."Snoring had appeared 5 years earlier. Her companion was unsure whether Ms. Kleber also had breathing pauses during her sleep. Ms. Kleber denied having ever experienced sleep paralysis or abruptly falling asleep in the middle of a sentence. Although she would fall asleep while socializing
column23: it would generally occur during a lull in the conversation while she was in a quiet spot in the corner of a couch. She denied falling down when she fell asleep. She reported experiencing hypnopompic hallucinations several times per year since she was a teenager.On examination
column24: Ms. Kleber was an overweight woman who was cooperative and coherent. She was concerned about her anxiety but preoccupied with her sleep problem. She denied depression
column25: suicidality
column26: psychosis
column27: and memory complaints. Her insight and judgment appeared intact.Her physical examination was essentially noncontributory. Her medical history was significant only for hypercholesterolemia and occasional migraine headaches. Ms. Kleber did have some muscular complaints
column28: such as weakness in her legs and pain in her left arm; these were related to exertion. She has smoked marijuana occasionally to help with her pain but denied that the marijuana was an important contributor to her sleepiness.She denied a history of head trauma and unusual illnesses. She denied a family history of sleep or mood problems
column29: although multiple relatives were "anxious."Ms. Kleber was referred for sleep studies. Polysomnography showed an apnea hypopnea index of 3 events per hour. The next day
column30: she underwent a multiple sleep latency test (MSLT)
column31: which indicated a mean sleep latency of 7 minutes with one sleep-onset REM period during the testing. A lumbar puncture was done to assess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels of hypocretin-1; the level appeared in the normal range.§Sure

column1: 69§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Brian Palen
column2: M.D.Vishesh K. Kapur
column3: M.D.
column4: M.P.H.Cï¿½sar Linares
column5: a 57-year-old married Hispanic man
column6: presented for reevaluation of his antidepressant medication. He described several years of worsening fatigue
column7: daytime sleepiness
column8: and generally "not feeling good." He lacked the energy to do his usual activities
column9: but he still enjoyed them when he did participate. He had been having some trouble focusing on his work as an information technology consultant and was worriedthat he would lose his job. A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant had been started 6 months earlier
column10: resulting in some improvement of symptoms
column11: and Mr. Linares reported that he was adherent to this medication.He denied recent stressors. In addition to having been diagnosed with depression
column12: he had received diagnoses of hypertension
column13: diabetes
column14: and coronary artery disease. He complained of heartburn as well as erectile dysfunction
column15: for which he had not been medically evaluated.Mr. Linares was born in Venezuela. He had two grown children. He did not consume tobacco or alcohol but did drink several servings of coffee each day to help maintain alertness.On physical examination
column16: the patient was 5 feet 10 inches tall
column17: weighed 235 pounds
column18: and had a BMI of 34. His neck circumference was 20 inches. His respiratory rate was 15
column19: and his blood pressure was 155/90. No other abnormalities were present.On mental status examination
column20: the patient was a cooperative man who appeared tired but was without depressed mood
column21: anxiety
column22: psychosis
column23: or cognitive decline.More focused questioning revealed that Mr. Linares not only had trouble staying awake at work but also occasionally nodded off while driving. He slept 8-10 hours nightly but had frequent awakenings
column24: made nightly trips to the bathroom (nocturia)
column25: and often woke with a choking sensation and sometimes with a headache. He had snored since childhood
column26: and he added
column27: "All the men in my family are snorers." Before she elected to sleep nightly in their guest bedroom
column28: his wife said he snored very loudly and intermittently stopped breathing and gasped for air.Mr. Linares was referred for a sleep study (polysomnography). Results included the following:ï¿½ Apnea hypopnea index: 25 events per hourï¿½ Oxygen desaturation index: 20 events per hourï¿½ Nadir oxygen saturation: 82%ï¿½ % Time with oxygen saturation < 90%: 10%ï¿½ Arousal index: 35 events per hourï¿½ Sleep stage (%):% Time in stage N1 sleep: 20%% Time in stage N2 sleep: 65%% Time in stage N3 sleep: 5%% Time in REM sleep: 10%§Finding Diane's Question:The following conversation]===During this is_came a large enough information about $Alice and Ipsum"}}>...

column1: 70§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Kathy P. Parker
column2: Ph.D.
column3: R.N.Dingxiang Meng was a 63-year-old Chinese-born man who was referred for a psychiatric consultation for depression and excessive somatic complaints. He had a history of psychotic depression
column4: for which he had been admitted twice in the prior decade. He was evaluated as an outpatient in the renal unit of a small hospital during his routine hemodialysis.Mr. Meng had been diagnosed with diabetes soon after his immigration to the United States 15 years earlier. He developed progressive renal insufficiency and had begun hemodialysis 7 years earlier. He was divorced
column5: with two adult children and three young grandchildren. He currently lived with one of his children. Before starting on dialysis
column6: Mr. Meng had worked episodically in a local grocery store owned by friends. Prior to emigrating from China
column7: he had enjoyed a career as a pharmacist. He spoke little English; all interviews were conducted with a Mandarin interpreter.At the time of the evaluation
column8: Mr. Meng said he felt "itchy
column9: creepy
column10: and crawly
column11: like worms were crawling underneath his skin." These symptoms had fluctuated over thepast few years but had worsened in recent weeks
column12: and he felt like he was "going crazy." He described being worried and often tired
column13: but noted that he always cheered up when playing with his grandchildren or when visiting with old friends from his hometown. He did not display a thought disorder. A review of the chart indicated that Mr. Meng's physical complaints had been conceptualized at various times as akathisia
column14: peripheral neuropathy
column15: and "psychosomatic" and "psychotically ruminative" symptoms. He had been euthymic and off all psychiatric medications for 2 years at the time of this evaluation.Mr. Meng noted that his physical symptoms were worse at night
column16: when he tried to sit still or lie down. The discomfort was only in his legs. Rubbing them helped
column17: but the greatest relief came from standing up and pacing. Dialysis was especially difficult because of "being strapped to a machine for hours." He also complained of daytime sleepiness and fatigue. In the course of the interview
column18: Mr. Meng twice jumped up during the dialysis.One of the nurses mentioned that he often asked them to cut short his dialysis
column19: generally looked tired
column20: and always seemed to be "jumping around." The staff wondered whether he might be nonadherent to his medications as well as being uncooperative at times during the dialysis.§Malekhan_Treasureers

column1: 71§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Cynthia A. Graham
column2: Ph.D.Elizabeth Olsen and Finn Nelson presented for couples counseling in the context of increased arguments prior to their upcoming wedding. They were both successful attorneys in their late 30s. They had known each other since high school
column3: had been dating for about 2 years
column4: and planned to get married in about 6 months. Both denied ever having previously seen a therapist or received a psychiatric diagnosis.The couples therapist met with them together for one session. Both Ms. Olsen and Mr. Nelson reported being very much in love and wanting the marriage to work out
column5: but they also said that they were fighting much of the time. Ms. Olsen said she admired Mr.Nelson's intelligence and steadiness and did not know why they fought. He
column6: on the other hand
column7: said he was still "totally infatuated" but upset about Ms. Olsen's overall lack of interest in him. As the session neared a close
column8: Mr. Nelson asked Ms. Olsen whether she wanted to bring up "the schedule
column9: the alcohol
column10: or the sex thing
column11: at which she smiled and said, I'm afraid we're out of time for today."The therapist met with each of them separately. At his meeting
column12: Mr. Nelson said his biggest concern with Ms. Olsen was her lack of interest in sex. She seemed to go through the motions
column13: he said
column14: and always relied on alcohol. He worried that he was a "7 trying to date a 10" and that she just did not find him attractive. He was distressed about the fact that
column15: try as he might
column16: he was unable to bring her to orgasm or even to get hersignificantly aroused. This was
column17: in turn
column18: leading him to initiate sex less frequently
column19: and even when he tried
column20: he would "often just give up half-way through." He had brought it up with her several times
column21: but she had insisted that there was no problem. The therapist asked what he had meant by "the schedule thing." He explained that since they had begun dating
column22: she had limited their time together to one "school night
column23: usually a Tuesday, and then either a Friday or Saturday night. She had insisted that the schedule was necessary for her to complete her work and see her best girlfriends, but he had increasingly come to believe it was to avoid him.In her individual session, Ms. Olsen said she was most frustrated by Mr. Nelson's intensity and high desire for sex. She had set up their weekly schedule because otherwise he would want to constantly have sex with her. As it was, he wanted sex every time they got together, often twice in the same night. She readily admitted that she got drunk to tolerate intercourse. She added that she had used alcohol to numb herself since she began dating while in her teens. Until she had started dating Mr. Nelson, most of her sexual experiences had been while drunk with strangers." She had had a couple of boyfriends
column24: but one was secretly gay and the other was "happy to get a blow job every now and then." She had not told Mr. Nelson about these misadventures because she preferred that he continue to see her as "the near-virginal beauty queen." Although alcohol made intercourse acceptable
column25: "sexual arousal was almost never tolerable" and made her want to pass out. In recent months
column26: Mr. Nelson had increasingly "forced the orgasm issue." In the past
column27: she would simply have broken up with any boyfriend who acted that way
column28: but she believed she needed to stick it out because she was nearing 40 and this would be her "last chance to have a baby." When asked why she thought she had these issues with sex
column29: Ms. Olsen looked out the window for almost a minute and then answered
column30: "I'm not going to tell you."§I needles_A"}}"

column1: 72§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Richard Balon
column2: M.D.Gerhard Palmer
column3: a 55-year-old married accountant
column4: presented to a psychiatrist for a second opinion in the context of recurrent major depressive disorder. He had not responded to two 3-month antidepressant trials
column5: one with fluoxetine and another with sertraline
column6: both at high dosages. At the time of his presentation
column7: he had not taken any antidepressant medication since the trial with sertraline (about a month earlier).The evaluation revealed a severely depressed man with profound psychomotor retardation
column8: poor concentration
column9: early insomnia
column10: mildly diminished libido
column11: and anhedonia. Mr. Palmer denied a substance use disorder
column12: drank minimally
column13: and did not smoke. He had started taking propranolol for hypertension about 6 months previously. His physical examination was unremarkable. Basic laboratory tests were within normal limits. His blood pressure was 135/85.Treatment with clomipramine was initiated and was quickly increased
column14: as tolerated
column15: to the recommended maximum dosage of 250 mg/day. Buspirone 30 mg/day was added. After 5 weeks of treatment
column16: Mr. Palmer reported feeling much improved. He wassleeping and eating well
column17: was participating in enjoyable activities with increasing enthusiasm
column18: and
column19: for the first time in many months
column20: felt a return of his sexual interest.After not having had sexual intercourse in months
column21: Mr. Palmer tried unsuccessfully to have sex several times. He was distressed to find that for the first time in his life
column22: he was unable to maintain an erection during intercourse and was unable to ejaculate
column23: even during masturbation. These problems persisted for a month. He recalled having had slightly delayed ejaculation while taking fluoxetine. He did not recall sexual problems during a prior trial of bupropion.§Besides蛾vefthomas
