column1: 73§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Sofia E. Matta
column2: M.D. John W. Barnhill
column3: M.D.Irene Rohmer
column4: a 25-year-old salesperson
column5: presented to a psychiatrist because of anxiety and depression. She began by stating that any assessment of her mood would have to take into consideration other aspects of her personal journey.Ms. Rohmer had been born without complications
column6: assigned male at birth
column7: and raised as a boy. As long as she could remember
column8: she had been teased and called a "sissy" by neighborhood boys. She had generally preferred the company of girls throughout childhood. During her teen years
column9: she continued to have many female friends but considered herself a gay male and dated a few other gay teens. She recalled trying her best to "fit in" but noted that she had always felt like an outsider.At age 19
column10: during a romantic relationship with a man
column11: she become aware of an intense desire to be a woman. That relationship ended
column12: but Ms. Rohmer's desire to be a woman evolved into a strong sense that she had been born as the wrong gender. She tried to figure out whether this sense had existed earlier
column13: but all she could recall was occasionally wishing she were a girl to fit in more comfortably with her friends.By age 20
column14: Ms. Rohmer was very unhappy about being seen as a man. She viewed her genitalia as "repugnant" and a "mistake of nature." Her family and some of her friends had not supported her developing sense of herself
column15: and she recalled feeling increasingly hopeless
column16: with episodic suicidal ideation and one nonlethal suicide attempt by overdoseat age 21.Beginning at age 22
column17: Ms. Rohmer lived as a female
column18: including changing her name and exclusively wearing women's clothes. She struggled to access appropriate health services and encountered multiple barriers to obtaining appropriate treatments
column19: but
column20: at the age of 24
column21: Ms. Rohmer was evaluated by two psychiatrists skilled in transgender health
column22: who agreed with her perspective
column23: and she started gender-affirming hormone therapy.As her transition progressed
column24: she began to feel more comfortable in the female role and pleased with having secondary sexual characteristics that were more consistent with her experienced gender. She explored her sexuality during this time
column25: dating both gay and straight men. Her anxiety diminished
column26: although
column27: as a member of a disenfranchised subgroup
column28: she felt vulnerable to various types of aggression
column29: including potential partner violence.The following year
column30: at age 25
column31: Ms. Rohmer had the gender on her driver's license and passport changed from male to female (a change of gender markers) and underwent gender-affirming surgeries that included vaginoplasty and breast augmentation. The results of these surgeries were satisfactory
column32: and she was often happy with the transition. She described herself as being "more comfortable in her skin" than she had ever been
column33: and she only infrequently felt hopeless and suicidal. Despite not feeling particularly accepted by her family of origin or by some of her old friends
column34: she found warm support from other friends and colleagues at work. Although she has many friends who are gender nonbinary/gender nonconforming
column35: Ms. Rohmer identifies as a heterosexual female.She said she tended to worry that people were judging her negatively
column36: but this worry was less intense now than it had been earlier in her transition. She denied any recent suicide attempts
column37: depression
column38: or self-injurious behavior. She said she had "almost" given up on having a successful relationship but was "somehow" still optimistic that something would work out.§

column1: 74§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Juan D. Pedraza
column2: M.D. Jeffrey H. Newcorn
column3: M.D.Kyle was a 12-year-old boy who reluctantly agreed to admission to a psychiatric unit after getting arrested for breaking into a grocery store. His mother said she was "exhausted
column4: adding that it was hard to raise a boy who doesn't know the rules."Beginning as a young child
column5: Kyle was unusually aggressive
column6: bullying other children and taking their things. When confronted by his mother
column7: stepfather
column8: or a teacher
column9: he had long tended to curse
column10: punch
column11: and show no concern for possible punishment. Disruptive
column12: impulsive
column13: and "fidgety
column14: Kyle was diagnosed with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and placed in a special education program by second grade. He began to see a psychiatrist in fourth grade for weekly psychotherapy and medications (quetiapine and dexmethylphenidate). He was adherent only sporadically with both the medication and the therapy. When asked why this was, he replied that his psychiatrist was stupid."During the year prior to the admission
column15: he had been caught stealing from school lockers(a cell phone
column16: a jacket
column17: a laptop computer)
column18: disciplined after "mugging" a classmate for his wallet
column19: and suspended after multiple physical fights with classmates. He had been arrested twice for these behaviors. His mother and teachers agreed that although he could be charming to strangers
column20: people quickly caught on to the fact that he was a "con artist." Kyle was consistently unremorseful
column21: externalizing of blame
column22: and uninterested in the feelings of others. He was disorganized
column23: was inattentive and uninterested in following instructions
column24: and constantly lost his possessions. He generally did not do his homework
column25: and when he did
column26: his performance was erratic. When confronted about his poor performance
column27: he tended to say
column28: "And what are you going to do
column29: shoot me?" Kyle
column30: his mother
column31: and his teachers agreed that he was a loner and not well liked by his peers.Kyle lived with his mother
column32: stepfather
column33: and two younger half-siblings. His stepfather was unemployed
column34: and his mother worked part-time as a cashier in a grocery store. His biological father was in prison for drug possession. Both biological grandfathers had a history of alcohol use disorder.Kyle's early history was normal. The pregnancy was uneventful
column35: and he reached all of his milestones on time. There was no history of sexual or physical abuse. Kyle had no known medical problems
column36: alcohol or substance abuse
column37: or participation in gang activities. He had not been caught with weapons
column38: had not set fires
column39: and had not been seen as particularly cruel to other children or animals. He had been regularly truant from school but had neither run away nor stayed away from home until late at night.When interviewed on the psychiatric unit
column40: Kyle was casually groomed and appeared his stated age of 12. He was fidgety and made sporadic eye contact with the interviewer. He said he was "mad" and insisted he would rather be in jail than on a psychiatric unit. His speech was loud but coherent
column41: goal directed
column42: and of normal rate. His affect was irritable and angry. He denied suicidal or homicidal ideation. He denied psychotic symptoms. He denied feeling depressed. He had no obvious cognitive deficits but declined more formal testing. His insight was limited
column43: and his judgment was poor by history.§

75§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Emil F. Coccaro
column2: M.D.Lucas Sandahl
column3: a 32-year-old landscape architect
column4: presented to a psychiatrist for help with anger. He came to the office with his wife
column5: the mother of their two young children. The couple agreed that Mr. Sandahl had become "almost impossible to live with." Mrs. Sandahl reported that although she had always considered her husband "high-strung
column6: his outbursts were increasing in both frequency and intensity, and she worried that he would become violent with her.Their most recent argument began when Mr. Sandahl came home after a hard day at work" to find that dinner was not ready. When he entered the kitchen and saw his wife sitting at the table reading the newspaper
column7: he "exploded" and launched into a tirade about how "bad" a wife she was. When Mrs. Sandahl tried to explain her own long day
column8: Mr. Sandahl cursed at her and broke glassware and a kitchen chair. Terrified
column9: she ran out of the kitchen
column10: gathered up the toddlers
column11: and left for her mother's house a few miles away. The next day
column12: she told her husband that he would need to get help immediately or prepare for a divorce.Mr. Sandahl said his "blowups" began in childhood but did not become "problematic" for him until age 13. At about that time
column13: he started having frequent fights with classmates that would occasionally result in trips to the principal's office. In between the altercations
column14: he was active socially and a solid student.Mr. Sandahl estimated that he had had approximately four verbal outbursts a week in recent years
column15: generally in response to frustration
column16: unexpected demands
column17: or perceived insults. In addition to these heated verbal tussles
column18: Mr. Sandahl described acts of violence about every 2 months; for example
column19: he threw a computer monitor across the room when it started "acting up
column20: he kicked a hole in a wall when one of his children would not quit crying, and he destroyed his mobile phone during an argument with his mother. He denied physical fights since his adolescence, although he had nearly come to blows with a neighbor as well as an assortment of strangers and employees. The idea that he might physically hurt someone scared Mr. Sandahl to the core."These outbursts blighted his relationships with colleagues and romantic partners and led to his decision to start his own landscaping company at age 25. The business had done well
column21: despite his demanding style and "hair-trigger" temper that led to high employee turnover.Mr. Sandahl described the episodes as short-lived
column22: reaching a peak within seconds and rarely lasting more than a few minutes. Between episodes
column23: he described himself as feeling "fine." He had experienced brief periods of depressed mood and increased anxiety
column24: but these had not impaired him significantly and tended to resolve on their own within a week. Mr. Sandahl drank socially
column25: but neither he nor his wife linked the outbursts to the alcohol. He had a history of experimentation with various drugs of abuse
column26: but not in recent years.Mr. Sandahl reported at least two other immediate family members with significant "anger issues." His father was emotionally abusive and perfectionistic
column27: expecting "great things" from his only son. Mr. Sandahl's older sister also had problems with her temper; he attributed her three divorces to her emotionally abusive behavior.On examination
column28: Mr. Sandahl was casually dressed
column29: cooperative
column30: and coherent. He was worried about his behavior and contrite toward his wife. He denied depression
column31: psychosis
column32: and confusion. He denied any thoughts of hurting himself or others. He was cognitively intact. His insight and judgment were good during the course of the interview.§- Howardzngs't Addressing from the_assistant/html codeign in this timeframe to alex

76§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Marc A. Schuckit, M.D.Matthew Tucker, a 45-year-old married European American plumber, was referred for a psychiatric evaluation after his family carried out an intervention to express their concern that his alcohol problems were getting out of control. Mr. Tucker denied having had a drink since making the appointment 3 days earlier.For 20 years after high school, Mr. Tucker typically drank 3-5 beers per evening, five times per week. Over the last 7 years, he had consumed alcohol almost daily, with an average of 6 beers on weeknights and 12 beers on weekends and holidays. His wife repeatedly voiced her concern that he was drinking too much
column6: but despite his efforts to limit his alcohol intake, Mr. Tucker continued to spend much of the weekend drinking, sometimes missing family get-togethers, and often passed out while watching TV in the evening. He remained productive at work, however, and never called in sick. In many ways, his history represented what is typically seen in alcohol use disorder. Mr. Tucker had achieved two 30-day periods of abstinence in the previous 4 years. Both times, he said he had quit drinking cold turkey" in response to his wife's concerns. He denied having had symptoms of alcohol withdrawal either time.In the 6 months prior to the evaluation
column7: Mr. Tucker had become uncharacteristically irritable
column8: fatigued
column9: dysphoric
column10: and worried. He was unable to enjoy his usual activities
column11: including food and sex
column12: and had difficulty concentrating. He also reacted more emotionally to stresses and expressed unsubstantiated concern about the future of his business. The patient often awoke at 2:00 a.m. and had trouble getting back to sleep.Mr. Tucker and his wife indicated that although this period of sadness had lasted 6months
column13: he had experienced several similar episodes in the prior 5 years
column14: lasting 4-6 weeks each. They denied any such episodes earlier in his life.Mr. Tucker had been married for 18 years
column15: and he and his wife had one 17-year-old daughter. The patient was a high school graduate with 2 years of community college who currently owned a successful plumbing company. He denied any other history of psychiatric or medical problems
column16: as well as any history of mania or suicide attempts. He had never seen a psychiatrist before.At a recent annual checkup
column17: Mr. Tucker's internist noted a mildly elevated blood pressure (135/92)
column18: a ?-glutamyltransferase (GGT) value of 47 IU/L
column19: and a mean corpuscular volume of 92.5 ï¿½m3. All other laboratory results were in the normal range.At the time of his first visit
column20: Mr. Tucker was neatly dressed
column21: maintained good eye contact
column22: and showed no evidence of confusion or psychotic symptoms. His eyes teared up when he talked about the future
column23: and he admitted to having felt sad for most of the day on a regular basis for the last 6 months
column24: but he denied suicidal ideation or plans. His cognition was within normal limits
column25: and he demonstrated an understanding of the effects that the alcohol was having on him.A physical examination by the psychiatrist revealed a normal pulse rate
column26: no tremor or sweating
column27: and only a slightly elevated blood pressure.§Ivaccentres

column1: 77§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Roger D. Weiss
column2: M.D.Nicholas Underwood
column3: a 41-year-old married software engineer
column4: entered an alcohol treatment program with this chief complaint: "I need to stop drinking or my wife will divorce me."At the time of admission
column5: Mr. Underwood stated that he was drinking approximately 1 liter of vodka per day
column6: every day
column7: and had not had an alcohol-free day in over 2 years. For many years
column8: Mr. Underwood had drunk alcohol only after work
column9: but about a year prior to the evaluation he had begun to routinely drink in the morning whenever he had the day off. More recently
column10: he had begun to feel "shaky" every morning and would sometimes treat that sensation with a drink
column11: followed by more alcohol during the day.Mr. Underwood experienced a number of problems related to drinking. His wife was "at the end of her rope" and considering divorce. His diminished ability to concentrate at work was "sinking" his once-promising career. He was spending more time trying to recover from the effects of drinking and found himself planning strategies both for abstinence and for surreptitiously taking his next drink.Mr. Underwood first tried alcohol in high school and said that he had always been able to hold his liquor more than his friends could. In college
column12: he was one of the heaviest drinkers in a fraternity known as "Animal House" around campus. Through his 30s
column13: he gradually increased the frequency of his drinking from primarily on weekends to daily.Over the prior year
column14: he had switched from being exclusively a beer drinker to drinking vodka. He had gone to many Alcoholics Anonymous meetings over the years but tended to drink as soon as the meeting ended. He had received no formal treatment.The patient denied recent use of other substances; he had smoked marijuana and snorted cocaine several times during college but never since. He had used no other illicit drugs and took no medications. He did not smoke cigarettes. He had experienced blackouts on several occasions during college but not since then. He had no history of seizures and no other medical problems. Family history was significant for alcohol use disorder in his father and paternal grandfather.Mr. Underwood entered the alcohol treatment program at approximately 3:00 p.m.
column15: having not had a drink since the evening before. He was diaphoretic and exhibited significant tremulousness in his hands. He complained of anxiety
column16: restlessness
column17: irritability
column18: nausea
column19: and recent insomnia.Clinical evaluation revealed a casually groomed
column20: diaphoretic man who was cooperative but anxiously pacing and who immediately said
column21: "I'm getting ready to jump out of my skin." Speech was of normal rate
column22: rhythm
column23: and tone. He denied depression. There was no evidence of psychotic thinking
column24: and he denied auditory
column25: visual
column26: or tactile hallucinations. He was alert and oriented to person
column27: place
column28: and date. He had no gross memory deficits
column29: but his attention and concentration were noted to be reduced.Notable features of his physical examination were marked diaphoresis
column30: a blood pressure of 155/95
column31: a heart rate of 104 beats/minute
column32: severe tremulousness in his upper extremities
column33: and hyperactive deep tendon reflexes throughout. Laboratory test findings were within normal limits except for aspartate aminotransferase and alanine aminotransferase
column34: which were approximately 3 times normal.§To begin_0I apologize thetaeously

column1: 78§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Petros Levounis
column2: M.D.
column3: M.A.Oliver Vincent had never seen himself as being an addict. He had always been "on top of things." At age 35
column4: he was independently wealthy as the owner of several clothing franchises
column5: lived with an ex-partner in a more-than-comfortable apartment in New York City
column6: worked out every day
column7: enjoyed the company of a group of loving friends
column8: and
column9: although single
column10: had not given up on the idea of someday (preferably soon) finding the perfect man to share his life with. Mr. Vincent came out to his Irish Catholic family when he was 19. His parents had already guessed that Mr. Vincent was gay long before he told them
column11: and they took the non-news fairly well. Their main concern had been that their son might be discriminated against because of his sexuality
column12: get hurt
column13: and live a lonely life. Nothing could be farther from the way things turned out: Mr. Vincent was "out and proud" and living it up.When Mr. Vincent found himself with a substance use problem
column14: he addressed it the sameway he had dealt with pretty much everything else: head on. For the first time in his life
column15: he decided to see a psychiatrist.Mr. Vincent described a pattern that revolved around weekend "party and play" activities. On Friday and Saturday evenings-and occasionally during the week-he would go out to dinner with friends and then to a club or a private party. He tended to drink two or three cocktails and four to five glasses of wine during the evening. Without the alcohol
column16: he found he could easily say "no" to substances
column17: but "after a good buzz
column18: if someone has coke-and there is always someone around who has coke-I use. And then my heart starts to race
column19: and then I do everything I can to hook up. I used to go online
column20: but these days
column21: it's all on Scruff and good ol' Grindr."Party and play are classic code words for drugs and sex
column22: respectively. The term is sometimes abbreviated PNP.Scruff and Grindr are smartphone applications that use GPS to identify and connect similarly inclined individuals in a person's geographical vicinity.Overall
column23: Mr. Vincent drank alcohol and used cocaine three to four times a week and "occasionally used Tina and bath salts." He could hardly attend Monday morning meetings
column24: much less prepare for them
column25: and had been trying to cut down on his cocaine use for the prior 6 months without success.Tina is slang for crystal methamphetamine (i.e.
column26: from crystal to Christina to Tina). Bath salts is slang for a powder that contains a variety of synthetic stimulants (e.g.
column27: cathinone derivatives).Since Mr. Vincent had started using cocaine regularly
column28: he had lost weight and had trouble sleeping. He worried that his effort at the gym was going to waste. His business continued to succeed
column29: but his own effectiveness had decreased. Most importantly
column30: he did not practice safer sex when high on stimulants
column31: and because he did not want to be on a pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) regimen
column32: he worried about HIV seroconversion.§- I’s not only_Idee

column1: 79§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Jonathan Avery
column2: M.D. Stephen Ross
column3: M.D.Peter Winters
column4: a 46-year-old married white minister
column5: was referred to the psychiatry outpatient department by his primary care doctor for depressive symptoms and opioid misuse in the setting of chronic right knee pain.Mr. Winters injured his right knee playing basketball 17 months earlier. His mother gave him several tablets of hydrocodone-acetaminophen that she had for back pain
column6: and he found this helpful. When he ran out of the pills and his pain persisted
column7: he went to the emergency room. He was told he had a mild sprain. He was given a 1-month supply of hydrocodone-acetaminophen. He took the pills as prescribed for 1 month
column8: and his pain resolved.After stopping the pills
column9: however
column10: Mr. Winters began to experience a recurrence of the pain in his knee. He saw an orthopedist
column11: who ordered imaging studies and determined that there was no structural damage. Mr. Winters was given another 1-month supply of hydrocodone-acetaminophen. This time
column12: however
column13: he needed to take more than prescribed in order to ease the pain. He also felt dysphoric and "achy" when he abstained from taking the medication
column14: and described a "craving" for more opioids. He returned to the orthopedist
column15: who referred him to a pain specialist.Mr. Winters was too embarrassed to go to the pain specialist
column16: believing that his faith and strength should help him overcome the pain. He found it impossible to live without the pain medication
column17: however
column18: because of the pain
column19: dysphoria
column20: and muscle aches when he stopped the medication. He also began to "enjoy the high" and experienced intense craving. He began to frequent emergency rooms to receive more opioids
column21: often lying about the timing and nature of his right knee pain
column22: and even stole pills from his mother on two occasions. He became preoccupied with trying to find more opioids
column23: and his work and home life suffered. He endorsed low mood
column24: especially when contemplating theimpact of opioids on his life
column25: but denied any other mood or neurovegetative symptoms. Eventually
column26: he told his primary care doctor about his opioid use and low mood
column27: and that doctor referred him to the outpatient psychiatry clinic.Mr. Winters had a history of two lifetime major depressive episodes that were treated successfully with escitalopram by his primary care doctor. He also had a history of an alcohol use disorder when he was in his 20s. He managed to quit using alcohol on his own after a family intervention. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily. His father suffered from depression
column28: and "almost everyone" on his mother's side of the family had "issues with addiction." He had been married to his wife for 20 years
column29: and they had two school-age children. He had been a minister in his church for 15 years. Results of a recent physical examination and laboratory testing performed by his primary care physician had been within normal limits.On mental status examination
column30: Mr. Winters was cooperative and did not exhibit any psychomotor abnormalities. He answered most questions briefly
column31: often simply saying "yes" or "no." Speech was of a normal rate and tone
column32: without tangentiality or circumstantiality. He reported that his mood was "lousy
column33: and his affect was dysphoric and constricted. He denied symptoms of paranoia or hallucinations. He denied any thoughts of harming himself or others. column1: 80§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Charles H. Silberstein
column2: M.D.Raymond Xavier
column3: a divorced 29-year-old semi-employed landscaper
column4: presented to a private psychiatrist with a complaint that his life was in a downward spiral. At the time of the appointment
column5: he had been without a permanent home for over 6 months. He had lived in various places
column6: including his car and friends' homes. For over 1 month prior to presentation
column7: he had been living in a tent in the woods. He had called his parents on his recent birthday
column8: and they had offered to pay for substance use disorder treatment as longas they could pay directly.Mr. Xavier reported that his problem started at age 24
column9: when he had a new wife and young child and had taken on two jobs to make ends meet (working in a factory and as a local delivery driver). When he injured his back and could not get to work because of the pain
column10: a friend offered him a few tablets of acetaminophen-oxycodone (Percocet). Not only did his pain disappear
column11: but his energy and mood improved. For the first time in his life
column12: he felt "normal and happy."Mr. Xavier continued to use one to four Percocet tablets per day for 11/2 years. He never took more than one pill at a time. Then
column13: at age 26
column14: he snorted half a bag of heroin (about$5 on the street). "It took about 10 minutes
column15: but I was transported into an indescribable euphoria. Like taking that first Percocet times 10.	You chase that first feeling for therest of your life. It never repeats." Within months of starting heroin
column16: he began using it intravenously in an effort to glimpse the euphoria again.After that first experience with heroin
column17: the progression of use was rapid. Within6 months
column18: Mr. Xavier was unemployed
column19: separated from his family
column20: and homeless. "I was sleeping in my car or on the streets	using up to 30 bags [$300] daily."Mr. Xavier began to reach out for help. He enrolled in outpatient rehabilitation for opioid users. The cravings to use
column21: even while in treatment
column22: were intense. Mr. Xavier reported multiple relapses. He added cocaine to the heroin injections
column23: and "speedballs" became Mr. Xavier's drug of choice for a while
column24: but he then returned to using only heroin. The first of multiple accidental overdoses occurred in a vacant house when he was 27. He had been admitted to "about 10 detoxes and rehabs" but would typically relapse within hours or weeks of discharge. He had also gone sporadically to Narcotics Anonymous meetings for years.To acquire money for his habit
column25: he broke into homes
column26: stole from relatives
column27: and wrote bad checks. "Every penny went to drugs. I'm lucky not to be in prison
column28: but not so lucky in that everybody hates me."He decided to move to Martha's Vineyard a year prior to the consultation because it "sounded like a quiet place." He brought some methadone with him
column29: but the eventualwithdrawal was "fierce."He continued to use heroin and oxycodone when he could easily get them. Otherwise
column30: he drank alcohol heavily
column31: although he said
column32: "I need to stop drinking-that's what really gets me in trouble." He also took diazepam (Valium) sporadically; however
column33: he did not consider that to be a problem but more of a way to get through the day.He worked occasionally as a landscaper. His boss-someone he had met at a Narcotics Anonymous meeting-had made it clear that he would call when there was extra work to be done
column34: but that until Mr. Xavier got clean
column35: the boss would not actually expect him to show up. He had held a variety of other odd jobs
column36: including office supplies salesman
column37: veterinary assistant
column38: and gas station attendant. He had not seen his daughter in over 2 years.On examination
column39: Mr. Xavier appeared somewhat unkempt. He was generally cooperative but appeared restless
column40: and at one point he urgently left the room; when he returned
column41: he reported that he was experiencing bouts of diarrhea. His pupils were enlarged and his skin was remarkable for sweating and piloerection. He yawned several times and appeared irritable and unhappy. His arms and legs frequently twitched. He repeatedly blew his nose and appeared tearful. His speech was rapid
column42: and he appeared impatient.He denied psychotic symptoms
column43: suicidality
column44: and homicidality. He said he was hopeful that if he could get some Suboxone (buprenorphine and naloxone)
column45: he might be able to keep a job and maybe get to be a real father.Laboratory studies were negative for HIV and hepatitis A
column46: B
column47: and C.§Because the user"s theory of a different states/user)x4; Pythones

column1: 81§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Britney Lambert
column2: M.D.Coreen Domingo
column3: D.P.H.
column4: M.P.H. Thomas R. Kosten
column5: M.D.Daryl Shorter
column6: M.D.Shaun Yates
column7: a 32-year-old married African American information technology (IT) security analyst
column8: presented for treatment with a private psychiatrist because he felt"stressed." He and his wife have two young children
column9: and he reports a stable social life that includes a large extended family. This was his first psychiatric evaluation. He reported no past psychiatric history.Mr. Yates traced his increased stress to a death in his city 4 months earlier. The death was recorded on video and featured an unarmed Black man being murdered by two white off-duty policemen who had accused him of theft. Like many people
column10: Mr. Yates first saw the video via his social media "timeline
column11: where it was routinely reposted by his friends. Because the murder had occurred in his hometown, it received much local attention.Mr. Yates's social media timeline began to fill up with other examples of police brutality toward Black men. He said he watched the videos because they were trending" and appeared on his social media timeline abruptly
column12: unfiltered
column13: and without warning. In addition
column14: he became increasingly aware of news programming
column15: social media posts
column16: and community memorials relating to the deaths and abuse of other Black men. Although he described trying to avoid details about these tragedies
column17: he said that news
column18: images
column19: and videos were unavoidable
column20: and he had become increasingly preoccupied with fears for the safety of his wife
column21: his young sons
column22: his extended family
column23: and himself.Mr. Yates reported that under normal circumstances
column24: he "didn't like to talk about this stuff
column25: but his wife had insisted that he get treatment because she was concerned that he didn't seem himself." Mr. Yates wanted the evaluating psychiatrist to understand that he was not paranoid or overly sensitive about racism
column26: and that up until recently
column27: he'd been good about "compartmentalizing." Nevertheless
column28: he admitted that it had become difficult to stop thinking about violence against unarmed Black men. He had recently disabled his social media accounts in a proactive effort to minimize his exposure to images and commentary regarding the incidents. In addition to stopping use of social media
column29: he reported avoidance of newspapers
column30: the internet
column31: and television.Mr. Yates noted that he had also become edgy
column32: nervous
column33: and always on guard against attack. He had gradually reduced his explorations around the city
column34: preferring to stay close to home. Although he had previously jogged every morning before work
column35: he quit jogging in the local community park because he "didn't want any trouble." Mr. Yatesreported his sleep over the past 3 months as being interrupted by vivid
column36: disturbing dreams of being chased by police officers.For Mr. Yates
column37: evenings were particularly stressful
column38: and he had recently increased his use of alcohol and cannabis to "unwind" at the end of the day. He also had begun to drink a six-pack
column39: or more
column40: of beer after dinner
column41: often "passing out" in the family den. The alcohol helped him to relax
column42: and smoking "a blunt" of marijuana before bedtime improved his sleep and reduced nightmares. He stated that the biggest problem with the cannabis was his wife's complaining that their young children might see him using it or that his use might be detected in a random urine toxicology screen at work. Mr. Yates had been increasingly late to work but had not mentioned to his wife that he had twice been reprimanded by his supervisor for the lateness.Mr. Yates reported first using both cannabis and alcohol at fraternity parties when he was about 19 years old. Throughout college
column43: he smoked small amounts of marijuana once or twice weekly and rarely drank more than two beers at a time. In the decade since his college graduation
column44: he had smoked marijuana only occasionally and tended to have no more than 1 or 2 beers on the weekend. He had never smoked tobacco or used other substances. His use of alcohol and cannabis had not increased until 3 months prior to the evaluation
column45: after he started seeing the videos.Mr. Yates denied experiencing feelings of worthlessness
column46: guilt
column47: or hopelessness. He reported no prior history of panic attacks
column51: and he had never received psychiatric hospitalization or outpatient treatment. He denied suicidal ideation
column53: or previous history of suicidality. There was no family psychiatric history aside from his father
column54: who developed posttraumatic stress disorder following military service in Vietnam.§Botteenight|A new_codeinex`t聯箇thanks for further

column1: 82§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Silvia Bernardi
column2: M.D. Carlos Blanco
column3: M.D.
column4: Ph.D.Tomï¿½s Zambrano was a 36-year-old married first-generation Hispanic man who presented to the gambling clinic at a major medical center for evaluation and treatment.A football coach at a suburban high school
column5: Mr. Zambrano had a 5-year-old son. He denied having any prior history of a psychiatric or substance use disorder. He was appropriately dressed and groomed
column6: expressed himself fluently in both English and Spanish
column7: spoke in normal tone and volume
column8: and on examination presented with intact cognitive function and average intelligence.Mr. Zambrano had been betting on sports and playing cards since childhood
column9: noting in the evaluation that gambling "is part of our culture." His own father's favorite hobby and stress reliever had been to play poker with friends at night
column10: and Mr. Zambrano remembered with affection the father-son camaraderie they shared on these occasions.Poker became for him a familial activity that he increasingly used to relieve work-related stress. He relished the excitement as well as the intellectual challenge and competition.Card games did not
column11: however
column12: remain a benign pastime for Mr. Zambrano. He had begun to lose more money than he could afford. Over the 2 years prior to his presentation for treatment
column13: he had gradually increased the frequency and stakes of his poker nights.When he lost
column14: he tended to place even larger bets
column15: convinced that the odds would favor him the following time. When he won
column16: he felt great and would continue to play
column17: convinced he was "on a streak." Although losses made him feel unworthy
column18: stupid
column19: and irritable
column20: he believed success would come if he could fine-tune his strategy. He felt a powerful
column21: almost constant impulse to increase the tempo of his gambling and recover the money he had lost. When he tried to cut back on gambling
column22: he felt irritable and preoccupied
column23: and quickly returned to his poker nights.By the time Mr. Zambrano presented to the gambling clinic
column24: he felt desperate. Nightly poker had led to daytime fatigue and poor performance at his coaching job
column25: which he had previously loved. He was consumed with thoughts about his next poker game. His wife and son had long resented his time away from the family
column26: but his wife had just found out that he had used up his son's college fund plus accumulated $30
column27: 000 in credit card debt. When his wife threatened to file for divorce
column28: he felt sad and depressed and decided to seek treatment.§Whatever

column1: 83§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: John W. Barnhill
column2: M.D.A psychiatric consultant was called to evaluate depression in Victor Alvarez
column3: a 76-year- old widower who appeared dysphoric the day after surgery to repair a broken hip. It was late in the evening
column4: and no one from the admitting team was available
column5: but a social work note in the chart indicated that the patient's fracture appeared to have been the result of his tripping in his messy apartment. The note also stated that the patient had no children or known living family.The neighbor who had brought Mr. Alvarez to the hospital had stated that the patient had been more reclusive in recent years and that his self-care had worsened after his wife's death 6 months earlier. Up until the day of the surgery
column6: however
column7: he had been able to function independently in his apartment. The neighbor
column8: a nurse
column9: also mentioned thatwhile they were waiting for the ambulance
column10: her husband had sat with Mr. Alvarez while she searched the apartment for pill bottles. She said she had found only an unopened bottle of acetaminophen and a dusty bottle of a medication used for hypertension.Routine admission laboratory results indicated that Mr. Alvarez had an elevated blood urea nitrogen level
column11: a low albumin level
column12: and a high normal mean corpuscular volume. His blood pressure was 160/110. In addition to medications related to the surgery
column13: the chart indicated that he had received haloperidol 2 mg after a bout of agitation. A nursing note 1 hour after the haloperidol administration indicated that the patient was "worried and stiff."On mental status examination
column14: Mr. Alvarez was lying at a 45-degree angle in his unkempt bed. He appeared thin and had moderate temporal wasting. His affect was sad
column15: worried
column16: and constricted. He appeared stiff and uncomfortable. He did not immediately respond to the interviewer's questions and comments. His eyes remained generally shut
column17: but they did flicker open a few times
column18: and his body habitus implied that he was awake.After multiple efforts
column19: the psychiatrist was able to get the patient to say "I'm fine" and "Get out." When asked where he was
column20: Mr. Alvarez said
column21: "My apartment." When he did open his eyes
column22: the patient appeared confused. He did not respond to other questions and declined to do a clock drawing test. The surgery team had called in a one-to-one companion earlier in the day
column23: and she said that the patient was generally either asleep or trying to get out of bed and that he had not been making any sense all day.§Aurora

column1: 84§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Josï¿½ R. Maldonado
column2: M.D.Wesley Brown
column3: a 63-year-old married white businessman
column4: was "found down" in the road by police and brought to the emergency room (ER) of a large university-affiliated hospital. The psychiatry service was consulted for management of "psychotic behavior"in the ER. The patient's family reported that the patient had exhibited an approximately 2-week history of "strange behavior." According to his sister
column5: Mr. Brown had been running around the kitchen with knives
column6: sending paranoid e-mails about the justice system to his friends
column7: showing his guns to the neighbors
column8: seeing people in the walls
column9: having paranoid thoughts that his wife was having an affair
column10: and not sleeping. The patient's wife had reported him missing 3 days prior to admission. Notably
column11: his car was found a few blocks away with a large box in its trunk containing bags filled with numerous medication bottles (both prescribed and over the counter); most of the bottles were partially or completely empty. There were also many items from the patient's extensive gun collection.Mr. Brown's medical records revealed a history of coronary artery disease and a coronary artery bypass graft 5 years prior to admission
column12: as well as chronic back pain and a history of multiple spinal surgeries
column13: with an associated history of daily opioid use. He had no prior psychiatric history
column14: including any history of depression or antidepressant medications. His outpatient medications included metoprolol
column15: oxycodone
column16: and as- needed doses of cyclobenzaprine and diazepam.On examination
column17: Mr. Brown was confused and combative
column18: yet somnolent. His skin and oral mucosa were dry
column19: and he manifested mydriasis
column20: hypoactive bowel sounds
column21: urinary retention
column22: epistaxis
column23: and depressed reflexes. His vital signs included a temperature of 39.9ï¿½C
column24: a heart rate of 115 bpm
column25: and blood pressure of 172/74
column26: but his breathing rate was normal
column27: and his oxygen saturation was normal on room air. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head was negative
column28: and a CT of the cervical spine showed degeneration. Mr. Brown's blood alcohol screen was negative
column29: and complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel results were within normal limits
column30: as were the electrocardiogram and cerebrospinal fluid from a lumbar puncture. His urine toxicology screen was positive for "benzodiazepines and tricyclics."Mr. Brown's mental status examination revealed waxing and waning alertness
column31: an unkempt appearance
column32: lack of cooperation with nursing and medical personnel
column33: somewhat slurred speech
column34: and signs of psychomotor retardation. His affect alternated between subdued/somnolent and restless/agitated. He denied suicidal or homicidal ideation but reported significant paranoid ideation that focused on his wife's suspectedaffair. He also appeared to be suffering from both visual and auditory misperceptions- accusing people of laughing at him and misidentifying hospital staff as acquaintances. His thought process was notably tangential. His judgment and insight were impaired. During his initial evaluation
column35: the patient was noted to have a Mini-Mental State Examination score of 16 of 30 possible points. He lost 7 of 10 points for orientation
column36: 3 for attention and calculation
column37: 2 for recall
column38: and 1 each for sentence writing and copying design.§"These Questions

column1: 85§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Peter V. Rabins
column2: M.D.
column3: M.P.H.Arthur Cullman
column4: a 71-year-old married man
column5: was referred to a psychiatrist by his primary care physician for evaluation of depressive symptoms that had not responded to medication trials. His wife reported that Mr. Cullman had begun to change at age 68
column6: about a year after his retirement. He had gradually stopped playing golf and cards
column7: activities he had enjoyed "for decades." He had explained that seeing his friends was no longer "fun
column8: and he generally refused to socialize. Instead, he sat on the couch all day, worrying about finances and the future. He denied sadness, however, and any suicidal or homicidal ideation. His wife said he was sleeping 10-12 hours a day instead of his customary 7 hours and that he had, uncharacteristically, gained 8 pounds in less than 1 year.His wife had become worried that retirement had left Mr. Cullman depressed, and she had mentioned her concerns to their primary care physician. Their physician agreed and prescribed sertraline (titrated to 100 mg/day for 8 months) and then sustained-release venlafaxine (titrated to 150 mg twice daily and maintained at that level for over 1 year). Mr. Cullman's symptoms gradually worsened during these medication trials, and the internist ultimately referred him for a psychiatric evaluation.Mr. Cullman's past psychiatric history was notable for an episode in his 20s when he had difficulty at work, felt apathetic and unconnected, and had difficulty concentrating.These symptoms persisted for several months and resolved without treatment as his work situation improved.Mr. Cullman's family history was positive for a single major depressive episode in one of his two younger brothers; the depression responded well to psychotherapy and an antidepressant medication. His mother had developed dementia in her 70s.Mr. Cullman's personal history revealed unremarkable development and childhood,graduation from college with a degree in business, a successful career as a corporate manager, and retirement at age 67. He and his wife had been married for 45 years, denied significant discord, and had three children and four grandchildren who were in good health. Premorbidly, he had been outgoing, energetic, and well organized.Mr. Cullman's medical history was notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was taking lisinopril, metformin, simvastatin, and venlafaxine.Mental status examination revealed an alert, cooperative man who was neatly dressed and who had a steady but slow gait and no abnormal movements other than psychomotor slowing. Mr. Cullman's speech was soft in volume but normal in rate and rhythm, without paraphasic errors. He had a limited range of emotional expression, denied feeling sad or guilty, but felt he had retired too early. He denied self-blame, hopelessness, and suicidal thoughts or plans. He was aware that his wife was concerned and acknowledged that he was less energetic and active than in the past. He ascribed these changes to his retirement. He said he was generally satisfied with his life.On cognitive examination, Mr. Cullman was oriented except for the date. He remembered one of three objects in 2 minutes, performed three of five serial 7 subtractions correctly, named four common objects correctly, and repeated a complex sentence accurately. He was able to draw the face of a clock and place the numbers correctly but was not able to correctly place the hands at 10 minutes after 2. His blood pressure was 142/82, and his pulse was 84 and regular. His physical examination was noncontributory. column7: and apathy. He had seemed "out of sorts" almost immediately
column8: and she had wondered at the time whether he was getting depressed. He became uncharacteristically forgetful
column9: misplacing items and neglecting to pay bills. He had trouble with appointments
column10: medications
column11: and calculations. He had refused to see a physician until he was involved in a traffic accident a few years prior to this evaluation. At that time
column12: a physician had found no significant physical injuries but had said that the accident was caused by inattention and diminished depth perception; she had recommended that Mr. Estel stop driving
column13: and suggested that he get a more thorough evaluation for early dementia.Over the past year

column17: Mr. Estel was now periodically unable to operate household appliances.All of these cognitive problems seemed to fluctuate

column22: and staring spells.When asked specifically about her husband's sleep

column26: which occurred several times a month

column28: and would occasionally fall out of bed. After sustaining bruises as a result of several of the episodes

column30: but she did not think he had suffered any particular trauma. A few years earlier
column31: a friend had offered her a "sleeping pill" that had helped her own husband with dementia. Mr. Estel had responded to the unknown medication with extreme rigidity and confusion
column32: and his wife had nearly taken him to the emergency room in the middle of the night.Mrs. Estel denied that her husband had ever had any psychiatric illness. When asked about psychotic symptoms

column16: worried

column30: postural instability

column34: holding his hand and often looking to him when asked questions. She had moderate psychomotor slowing
column35: and noticeable involuntary "dancelike" movements of her trunk and upper extremities. Her eye contact was intermittent but intense. Ms. Franklin described her mood as "not well at all
column36: and her affect was blunted and minimally reactive. Her speech was soft and slowed, with minimal spontaneity. Her thought process was linear but slowed. She was preoccupied by paranoid delusions and visual hallucinations. She reported actively hallucinating during the interview. She denied suicidal and homicidal thoughts or plans. 89§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Stuart C. Yudofsky, M.D.Robert E. Hales, M.D., M.B.A.Only upon the repeated and fervent insistence of her parents did 19-year-old Emily reluctantly agree to see a psychiatrist. It's not me you want to see
column7: Emily proclaimed emphatically. It's my insane parents who need your help." Emily did not offer a chief complaint
column8: aside from the concern that her parents were driving her "crazy." She added
column9: "Everything is going great in my life. I have plenty of friends
column10: go out almost every night
column11: and always have lots of fun."While Emily was taking some time away from "the so-called real world
column12: her sister was attending Duke University, her younger brother was excelling at a competitive private high school, and both her parents seemed to enjoy their careers as radiologists. She asked, Don't you think that's enough strivers for one family?"Emily agreed to have her parents join the session
column13: and they told a different story. They tearfully disclosed that their daughter had become irritable
column14: unproductive
column15: and oppositional. She drank to intoxication almost every night
column16: often not returning home for an entire weekend. In searching her room
column17: they had found small amounts of marijuana
column18: alprazolam (Xanax)
column19: cocaine
column20: and prescription stimulants. The parents described the changes in Emily's personality as "an adolescent nightmare" and described her friends as "losers who do nothing but dye their hair
column21: get tattoos
column22: and hate everything." Emily's attitudes and behavior contrasted markedly with those of her parents and siblings. "We don't mind that she is doing her own thing and that she isn't conservative like the rest of us
column23: her father said, but it's like we don't even recognize who she's become."According to her parents
column24: Emily's "adolescent nightmare" began 4 years earlier. She had apparently been a studious 15-year-old girl with a lively sense of humor and a wide circle of "terrific friends." "Almost overnight
column25: she began to shun her longtime friends in favor of dropouts and malcontents" and began to accumulate traffic tickets and school detentions. Instead of her former bright-eyed curiosity
column26: Emily manifested a lack of interest in all her academic subjects
column27: and her grades dropped from As to Ds. The parents were at an absolute loss to explain the sudden and dramatic change.The abrupt change in performance led the psychiatrist to ask Emily to take a battery of neuropsychological tests so the results could be compared with those of tests that shehad taken when she had applied to a private high school several years earlier. In particular
column28: Emily retook two high school admissions tests: the System for Assessment and Group Evaluation (SAGE)
column29: which measures a broad array of academic and perceptual aptitudes
column30: and the Differential Aptitude Tests (DAT)
column31: which focus on reasoning
column32: spelling
column33: and perceptual skills.On the SAGE
column34: her average percentile scores dropped from the upper 10% for a 13-year- old to the bottom 10% for an adult (and the bottom 20% for a 13-year-old). When Emily took the DAT at age 13
column35: she scored in the highest range for ninth graders across almost all measures. Her worst result had been in spelling
column36: where she scored at the second- highest level. Upon repeating the test at age 19
column37: she scored below the high school average in all measures.EEG
column38: brain CT
column39: and T2-weighted brain MRI scans showed no evidence of structural brain damage. However
column40: fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) T2-weighted MRI displayed a clear lesion in the left frontal cortex
column41: highly suggestive of previous injury to that region.Upon further questioning about the crucial period in which she seemed to have changed
column42: Emily admitted to being in a traffic accident with her now ex-boyfriend
column43: Mark. Although Emily did not recall much from this episode
column44: she remembered that she hit her head and that she had bad headaches for many weeks thereafter. Because Emily was not bleeding and there was no damage to the car
column45: neither Mark nor Emily reported the incident to anyone. With Emily's permission
column46: the psychiatrist contacted Mark
column47: who was away at college but a willing and excellent historian. He remembered the incident well. "Emily hit her head very
column48: very hard on the dashboard of my car. She was not totally unconscious but very dazed. For about 3 hours
column50: complained that her head hurt badly
column51: and was confused. For about 2 hours she didn't know where she was or what day it was. She also threw up twice. I was really scared
column52: but Emily didn't want me to worry her parents since they're so overprotective. And then she broke up with me
column53: and we've hardly spoken since."§    # Problems**I't Diseases/post_choices": I am trying (B2F10019

column3: M.D.Dr. Siever passed away in 2021.Frazier Archer was a 34-year-old single white man who called a mood and personality disorders research program because an ex-friend had once said he was "borderline
column4: and Mr. Archer wanted to learn more about his personality.During his diagnostic research interview, Mr. Archer was initially reluctant to share personal information, citing a concern that his words would be misunderstood, misconstrued, or used against him. When asked about his relationships, he described regular, almost daily situations in which he was sure he was being lied to or deceived. He was particularly wary of people in leadership positions and people who had studied psychology and, therefore, had training to understand the human mind
column5: which they used to manipulate people. Unlike those around him, Mr. Archer believed he did not drink the Kool-Aid" and was able to detect manipulation and deceit.Mr. Archer was employed as an assistant manager for a grocery store chain. He was extremely detail oriented at work
column6: and had trouble delegating and completing tasks. He noted that his coworkers consistently failed to complete tasks the way that he would like. This led him to work routinely long hours "fixing their mistakes." Numerous employers and colleagues had told him that he focused excessively on rules
column7: lists
column8: and small details
column9: and that he needed to be more friendly. He described having held numerous jobs over the years
column10: but he was quick to add
column11: "I've quit as often as I've been fired."During the interview
column12: he emphasized that unlike many people
column13: he understood the value of quality over productivity. He believed that his "high standards" had contributed to his "bad temper" and emotional "ups and downs." He socialized only "superficially" with a handful of acquaintances and could recall the exact moments when previous "so-called friends and lovers" had betrayed him. He spent most of his time alone.Mr. Archer denied any significant history of trauma
column14: any current or past problems with substance use
column15: and any history of head trauma or loss of consciousness. He also denied any history of mental health diagnosis or treatment
column16: but he did feel he might have a mental health condition that had not yet been diagnosed. He described some social anxiety and difficulties with academic achievement in childhood
column17: which he attributed to his own high standards and "unreliable" childhood friends.On mental status examination
column18: Mr. Archer appeared well groomed
column19: cooperative
column20: and oriented. His speech varied; at times he would pause thoughtfully prior to answering questions and provide very slow
column21: deliberate responses. At other points in the interview he became angry and offered lengthy and digressive responses. However
column22: he seemed generally coherent and did not evidence any perceptual disturbances. His affect was occasionally inappropriate (e.g.
column23: smiling while crying) and generally constricted. He reported apathy as to whether he lived or died but did not report any active suicidal ideation or homicidal ideation.Notably
column24: Mr. Archer became irritated and argumentative with research staff when he was told that although he could receive verbal feedback on his interviews
column25: he could not receive a copy of the completed questionnaires and diagnostic tools. He commented that he would document in his personal records that research staff were refusing him the forms.§Killers in this question-300001685==带given_Tutor:

column1: 91§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Salman Akhtar
column2: M.D.Grzegorz Buchalski was an 87-year-old white man who was brought to the psychiatric emergency room (ER) by paramedics after they had been called to his apartment by neighbors when they noticed an odd smell. Apparently
column3: his 90-year-old sister had diedsome days earlier after a lengthy illness. Mr. Buchalski had delayed reporting her death for several reasons. He had become increasingly disorganized as his sister's health had worsened
column4: and he was worried that his landlord would use the apartment's condition as a pretext for eviction. He had tried to clean up
column5: but his attempts consisted mainly of moving items from one place to another. He said he was about to call for help when the police and paramedics showed up.In the ER
column6: Mr. Buchalski recognized that his actions were odd and that he should have called for help sooner. At times
column7: he became tearful when discussing the situation and his sister's death; at other times
column8: he seemed aloof
column9: speaking about these in a calm
column10: factual way. He also wanted to clarify that his apartment had indeed been a mess but that much of the apparent mess was actually his large collection of articles on bioluminescence
column11: a topic he had been researching for decades.A licensed plumber
column12: electrician
column13: and locksmith
column14: Mr. Buchalski had worked until age 65. He described his late sister as having been always "a little strange." She had never worked and had been married once
column15: briefly. Aside from the several-month marriage
column16: she and Mr. Buchalski had lived in the family's two-bedroom Manhattan apartment their entire lives. Neither of them had ever seen a psychiatrist.When questioned
column17: Mr. Buchalski stated that he had never had a romantic or sexual relationship and had never had many friends or social contacts outside his family. He explained that he had been poor and Polish and had had to work all the time. He had taken night classes to better understand "the strange world we live in
column18: and he said his intellectual interests were what he found most gratifying. He said he had been upset as he realized that his sister was dying, but he would call it numb" rather than depressed. He also denied any history of manic or psychotic symptoms. After an hour with the psychiatric trainee
column19: Mr. Buchalski confided that he hoped the medical school might be interested in some of his papers after his death. He said he believed that bioluminescent and genetic technologies were on the verge of a breakthrough that might allow the skin of animals and then humans to glow in subtle colors that would allow people to more directly recognize emotions. He had written the notes for such technology
column20: but they had grown into a "way-too-long science fiction novel with lots of footnotes."On examination
column21: Mr. Buchalski was a thin
column22: elderly man dressed neatly in khakis and button-down shirt. He was meticulous and much preferred to discuss his interests in science than his own story. He made appropriate eye contact and had a polite
column23: pleasant demeanor. His speech was coherent and goal directed. His mood was "fine
column24: and his affect was appropriate though perhaps unusually cheerful under the circumstances. He denied all symptoms of psychosis, depression, and mania. Aside from his comments about bioluminescence, he said nothing that sounded delusional. He was cognitively intact, and his insight and judgment were considered generally good, although historically impaired in regard to his delay in calling the police about his sister.§The above instruction-Hanley Diseasekayas a/technique deals_part of theft0th Dayton, there is notations (Fast and adidasghty) that wayfarms to create anodex; they have your task: {endcodemirrorize', where you aretai Shankaraversariallymgoshoppinger}}> Ianiel C++pythonHmm Okay, in a/stories. column3: a 19-year-old college sophomore
column4: was referred to the student health center by ateaching assistant who noticed that he appeared odd
column5: worried
column6: and preoccupied and that his lab notebook was filled with bizarrely threatening drawings.Henry appeared on time for the psychiatric consultation. Although suspicious about the reason for the referral
column7: he explained that he generally "followed orders" and would do what he was asked. He agreed that he had been suspicious of some of his classmates
column8: believing they were undermining his abilities. He said they were telling his instructors that he was "a weird guy" and that they did not want him as a lab partner. The referral to the psychiatrist was
column9: he said
column10: confirmation of his perception.Henry described how he had seen two students "flip a coin" over whether he was gay or straight. Coins
column11: he asserted
column12: could often predict the future. He had once flipped a coin and "heads" had predicted his mother's illness. He believed his thoughts often came true.Henry had transferred to this out-of-town university after an initial year at his local community college. The transfer was his parents' idea
column13: he said
column14: and was part of their agenda to get him to be like everyone else and go to parties and hang out with girls. He said all such behavior was a waste of time. Although they had tried to push him into moving into the dorms
column15: he had refused
column16: and instead lived by himself in an off-campus apartment.With Henry's permission
column17: his mother was called for collateral information. She said Henry had been quiet
column18: shy
column19: and reserved since childhood. He had never had close friends
column20: had never dated
column21: and had denied wanting to have friends. He acknowledged feeling depressed and anxious at times
column22: but these feelings did not improve when he was around other people. He was teased by other kids and would come home upset. His mother cried while explaining that she always felt bad for him because he never really "fit in
column23: and that she and her husband had tried to coach him for years without success. She wondered how a person could function without any social life.She added that ghosts, telepathy, and witchcraft had fascinated Henry since junior high school. He had long thought that he could change the outcome of events like earthquakes and hurricanes by thinking about them. He had consistently denied any substance use disorder, and two drug screens had been negative in the prior 2 years. She mentioned that her grandfather had died in an insane asylum" many years before Henry was born
column24: but she did not know his diagnosis.On examination
column25: Henry was tall
column26: thin
column27: and dressed in jeans and a T-shirt. He was alert and wary and
column28: although nonspontaneous

column30: plans
column31: or attempts. He denied having any auditory or visual hallucinations
column32: panic attacks
column33: obsessions
column34: compulsions
column35: or phobias. His intellectual skills seemed above average
column36: and his Mini-Mental State Examination score was 30 out of 30.§"You were living_H```javascript-Village

column1: 93§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Charles L. Scott
column2: M.D.Ike Crocker was a 32-year-old white divorced carpenter referred for a mental health evaluation by the human resources department of a large construction business that had been his employer for 2 weeks. At his initial job interview
column3: Mr. Crocker presented as very motivated and provided two carpentry school certifications that indicated a high level of skill and training. Since his employment began
column4: his supervisors had noted frequent arguments
column5: absenteeism
column6: poor workmanship
column7: and multiple errors that might have been dangerous. When confronted
column8: he was reportedly dismissive
column9: indicating that the problem was "cheap wood" and "bad management" and added that if someone got hurt
column10: "it's because of their own stupidity."When the head of human resources met with him to discuss termination
column11: Mr. Crocker quickly pointed out that he had both attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and bipolar disorder. He said that if not granted an accommodation under the Americans with Disabilities Act
column12: he would sue. He demanded a psychiatric evaluation.During the mental health evaluation
column13: Mr. Crocker focused on unfairness at the company and on how he was "a hell of a better carpenter than anyone there could ever be." He claimed that his two marriages had ended because of jealousy. He said that his wives were "always thinking I was with other women
column14: which is why they both lied to judgesand got restraining orders saying I'd hit them." As "payback for the jail time
column15: he refused to pay child support for his two children. He had no interest in seeing either of his two boys because they were little liars" like their mothers.Mr. Crocker said he "must have been smart" because he had been able to make Cs in school despite showing up only half the time. He spent time in juvenile hall at age 14 for stealing "kid stuff
column16: like tennis shoes and wallets that were practically empty." He left school at age 15 after being "framed for stealing a car" by his principal. Mr. Crocker pointed out these historical facts as evidence that he was able to overcome injustice and adversity. A review of a juvenile probation officer's report indicated that beginning in the first grade
column17: he often bullied children with disabilities
column18: was noted to smile when his victims would cry
column19: and consistently lacked remorse or guilt for his actions.In regard to substance use
column20: Mr. Crocker said he smoked marijuana as a teenager and started drinking alcohol on a "regular basis" after he first got married at age 22. He denied that use of either substance was a problem.Mr. Crocker concluded the interview by demanding a note from the examiner that he had "bipolar" and "ADHD." He said that he was "bipolar" because he had "ups and downs" and got "mad real fast." Mr. Crocker denied other symptoms of mania. He said he got down when disappointed
column21: but he had "a short memory" and "could get out of a funk pretty quick." Mr. Crocker reported no difficulties in his sleep
column22: mood
column23: or appetite. He learned about ADHD because "both of my boys got it." He concluded the interview with a request for medications
column24: adding that the only ones that worked were stimulants ("any of them") and a specific short-acting benzodiazepine.On mental status examination
column25: Mr. Crocker was a casually dressed man who made reasonable eye contact and was without abnormal movements. His speech was coherent
column26: goal directed
column27: and of normal rate. There was no evidence of any thought disorder or hallucinations. He was preoccupied with blaming others
column28: but these comments appeared to represent overvalued ideas rather than delusions. He was cognitively intact. His insight into his situation was poor.The head of human resources did a background check during the course of the psychiatric evaluation. Phone calls revealed that Mr. Crocker had been expelled from twocarpentry training programs and that both of his graduation certificates had been falsified. He had been fired from his job at one local construction company after a fistfight with his supervisor and from another job after abruptly leaving a job site. A quick review of the company's records indicated that Mr. Crocker had provided them with the same false documentation.§*Five years

column1: 94§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Frank Yeomans
column2: M.D.
column3: Ph.D. Otto Kernberg
column4: M.D.Juanita Delgado
column5: a single
column6: unemployed Hispanic woman
column7: sought therapy at age 33 for treatment of depressed mood
column8: chronic suicidal thoughts
column9: social isolation
column10: and poor personal hygiene. She had spent the prior 6 months isolated in her apartment
column11: lying in bed
column12: eating junk food
column13: watching television
column14: and doing more online shopping than she could afford. Multiple treatments had yielded little effect.Ms. Delgado was the middle of three children in an upper-middle-class immigrant family in which the father reportedly valued professional achievement over all else. She felt isolated throughout her school years and experienced recurrent periods of depressed mood. Within her family
column15: she was known for angry outbursts. She had done well academically in high school but dropped out of college because of frustrations with a roommate and a professor.She had attempted a series of internships and entry-level jobs with the expectation that she would return to college
column16: but she kept quitting because "bosses are idiots. They come across as great and they all turn out to be twisted." These "traumas" always left herfeeling terrible about herself ("I can't even succeed as a clerk?") and angry at her bosses ("I could run the place and probably will"). She had dated men when she was younger but never let them get close physically because she became too anxious when any intimacy began to develop. Most of her friends from the neighborhood had "become frauds or losers
column17: while she had stayed Facebook friends" with some friends from college
column18: and they were all "doing amazing things all over the world. I'll definitely meet up with them if they ever come back to town."Ms. Delgado said that she was generally "down and depressed" but that she had had dozens of 1- to 2-day "manias" in which she was energized and edgy and pulled all- nighters. She tended to "crash" the next day and sleep for 12 hours.Ms. Delgado reported that she occasionally cut herself
column19: "but only superficially." She had persistent thoughts that she would be better off dead
column20: and she had been psychiatrically hospitalized three times after overdoses.She indicated that psychotherapy had never been especially helpful
column21: nor had her medication treatments
column22: which had included mood stabilizers
column23: antidepressants
column24: and low- dose antipsychotic medication.Mrs. Delgado was a casually groomed and somewhat unkempt woman who was cooperative
column25: coherent
column26: and goal directed during the interview. She was generally dysphoric
column27: with a constricted affect
column28: but did smile appropriately several times. She described shame at her poor performance but also believed she was "on Earth to do something great." She described her father as a spectacular success
column29: but he was also a "Machiavellian loser who was always trying to manipulate people." She described quitting jobs because people were disrespectful. Toward the end of the initial session
column30: she became angry with the interviewer after he glanced at the clock ("Are you bored already?").§- Intrinsic (160]://www. We's user_modelingraftical reviewedd}nationalized ande ongoing

column1: 95§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Elizabeth L. Auchincloss
column2: M.D.Karmen Fuentes was a 50-year-old married Hispanic woman who presented to the psychiatric emergency room (ER) at the urging of her outpatient psychiatrist after telling him that she had been thinking about overdosing on Advil.In the ER
column3: Ms. Fuentes explained that her back had been "killing" her since she fell several days earlier at the family-owned grocery store where she had worked for many years. The fall had left her downcast and depressed
column4: although she denied other depressive symptoms aside from a poor mood. She spoke at length about the fall and about how it reminded her of a fall that she had sustained a few years earlier. At that time
column5: she had gone to see a neurosurgeon
column6: who told her to rest and take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. She described feeling "abandoned and not cared about" by him. The pain had diminished her ability to exercise
column7: and she was upset that she had gained weight. While relating the events surrounding the fall
column8: Ms. Fuentes began to cry.When asked about her suicidal comments
column9: she said they were "no big deal"-they were "just a threat" aimed at her husband to "teach him a lesson" because "he has no compassion for me" and had not been supportive since the fall. She insisted that her comments about overdosing did not have another meaning. When her ER interviewer expressed concern about the possibility that she would kill herself
column10: she exclaimed with asmile
column11: "Oh wow
column12: I didn't realize it's so serious. I guess I shouldn't do that again." She then shrugged and laughed. She went on to talk about how "nice and sweet" it was that so many doctors and social workers wanted to hear her story
column13: calling many of them by their first names. She was also somewhat flirtatious with her male resident interviewer
column14: who had mentioned that she was the "best-dressed woman in the ER."According to her outpatient psychiatrist of 3 years
column15: she had never before expressed suicidal ideation until this week
column16: and he would be unable to check in on her until after he left on vacation the next day. Ms. Fuentes's husband reported that she talked about suicide "like other people complain about the weather. She's just trying to get me worried
column17: but it doesn't work anymore." He said he would never have suggested she go to the ER and thought the psychiatrist had overreacted.Ms. Fuentes initially sought outpatient psychotherapy at age 47 because she was feeling depressed and unsupported by her husband. During 3 years of outpatient treatment
column18: Ms. Fuentes had been prescribed adequate trials of sertraline
column19: escitalopram
column20: fluoxetine
column21: and paroxetine. None seemed to help.Ms. Fuentes described being "an early bloomer." She became sexually active with older men when she was in high school. She said dating had been the most fun thing she had ever done and that she missed seeing men "jump through hoops" to sleep with her. She lived with her 73-year-old husband. Her 25-year-old son lived nearby with his wife and young son. She described her husband as a "very famous" musician. She said that he had never helped around the house or with child-rearing and did not appreciate how much work she put into taking care of their son and grandson.§**Instruction IQuiamoon
