96§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Robert Michels
column2: M.D.Larry Goranov was a 57-year-old man who demanded an expert review of the psychiatric care that he had received for the prior 7 years at a psychiatric clinic connected to a medical school. Mr. Goranov indicated to the clinic's psychiatric director that he had been depressed for many years
column3: but weekly psychotherapy and multiple different psychiatric medications had made no difference.Mr. Goranov reported feeling sad
column4: tired
column5: and frustrated "for decades." He rarely looked forward to anything. He had lost his last job 3 years earlier
column6: had broken up with a girlfriend slightly later
column7: and doubted that he would ever work or date again. He was embarrassed that he still lived with his mother
column8: who was in her 80s. He denied any immediate intention or plan to kill himself
column9: but stated that if he did not improve by the time his mother died
column10: he did not see what he would have to live for. He denied disturbances in sleep
column11: appetite
column12: or concentration.Clinic records indicated that Mr. Goranov had been adherent to adequate trials of fluoxetine
column13: escitalopram
column14: sertraline
column15: duloxetine
column16: venlafaxine
column17: and bupropion
column18: as well as augmentation with quetiapine
column19: aripiprazole
column20: lithium
column21: and levothyroxine. He had experienced some improvement in his mood while taking escitalopram but did not have remission of symptoms. He also received a course of cognitive-behavioral therapy early in his treatment
column22: but he had been dismissive of the therapist and treatment
column23: did not do his assigned homework
column24: and appeared to make no effort to use the therapy between sessions.Mr. Goranov expressed frustration at his lack of improvement
column25: the nature of his treatment
column26: and his specific therapy. He found it "humiliating" that he was forced to see trainees who rotated off his case every year or two. He frequently found that thepsychiatry residents were not especially educated
column27: cultured
column28: or sophisticated
column29: and thought that they knew less about psychotherapy than he did. He much preferred to work with female therapists "because at least they're pretty
column30: and men are too competitive and envious."Mr. Goranov had worked as an insurance broker from age 25 to 40. He explained
column31: "It's ridiculous. I was the best broker they had ever seen
column32: but I still can't get a job. I think the problem is that the profession is filled with big egos
column33: and I can't keep my mouth shut about it." After being "blackballed" by insurance agencies
column34: Mr. Goranov did not work for 5 years
column35: until he was hired by an automobile dealer. He said that although it was beneath him to sell cars
column36: he was successful
column37: and "in no time
column38: I was running the place." He quit within a few months after an argument with the owner. Despite encouragement from several therapists
column39: Mr. Goranov had not applied for a job or pursued employment rehabilitation or volunteer work; he strongly viewed these options as beneath him.Mr. Goranov has "given up on women." He had many partners as a younger man
column40: but he generally found them to be unappreciative and "only in it for the free meals." Psychotherapy notes from the clinic indicate that he responded to demonstrations of interest with suspicion. This tendency held true in regard to both women who had tried to befriend him and therapists who had taken an interest in his care. Mr. Goranov described himself as someone who had a lot of love to give
column41: but added that the world was full of manipulators. He said he had a few buddies
column42: but his mother was the only one he truly cared about. His parents had emigrated from Eastern Europe when he was a child. He had no siblings
column43: and his father had died when the patient was 41. He had met a few relatives over the years
column44: "but they didn't speak English
column45: so I didn't pay them much attention." He enjoyed fine restaurants and "five-star hotels
column46: but he added that he could no longer afford them. He exercised daily and was concerned about maintaining his body. Most of his time was spent at home watching television or reading novels and biographies.On examination, the patient was neatly groomed, had slicked-back hair, and wore designer hip-hop-inspired clothing generally favored by men in their 20s. He was coherent, goal directed, and generally cooperative. He said he was sad and angry. His affect was constricted and dismissive. He denied an intention to kill himself but felthopeless and thought of death fairly often. He was cognitively intact.§In a more than ana-03]acted from yourType528619; itinerarions of the second_Assistant:

column1: 97§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: J. Christopher Perry
column2: M.P.H.
column3: M.D.Mathilda Herbert was a 23-year-old woman referred for psychiatric consultation to help her "break out of her shell." She had recently moved to a new city to take classes to become an industrial lab technician and had moved in with an older cousin
column4: who was also a psychotherapist and thought she should "get out and enjoy her youth."Although she had previously been prescribed medications for anxiety
column5: Ms. Herbert said that her real problem was "shyness." School was difficult because everyone was constantly "criticizing." She avoided being called on in class because she knew she would "say something stupid" and blush and everyone would make fun of her. She avoided speaking up or talking on telephones
column6: worried about how she would sound. She dreaded public speaking.She was similarly reticent with friends. She said she had always been a people pleaser who preferred to hide her feelings with a cheerful
column7: compliant
column8: attentive demeanor. She had a few friends
column9: whom she described as "warm and lifelong." She felt lonely after her recent move and had not yet met anyone from school or the local community.She said she had broken up with her first serious boyfriend 2 years earlier. He had initially been "kind and patient." Through him
column10: she had a social life by proxy. Soon after she moved in with him
column11: however
column12: he turned out to be an "angry alcoholic." She had not dated since that experience.Ms. Herbert grew up in a metropolitan area with her parents and three older siblings. Her brother was "hyperactive and antisocial" and took up everyone's attention
column13: whereas her sisters were "hypercompetitive and perfect." Her mother was anxiously compliant
column14: "like me." Ms. Herbert's father was a very successful investment manager who often pointed out ways in which his children did not live up to his expectations. He could be supportive but tended to disregard emotional uncertainty in favor of a "tough optimism." Teasing and competition "saturated" the household
column15: and "it didn't help that I was forced to go to the same girls' school where my sisters had been stars and where everyone was rich and catty." She developed a keen sensitivity to criticism and failure.Her parents divorced during her senior year of high school. Her father married another woman soon thereafter. Although she had planned to attend the same elite university as her two sisters
column16: she chose to attend a local community college at the last minute. Sheexplained that it was good to be away from all the competition
column17: and her mother needed the support.Ms. Herbert's strengths included excellent work in her major
column18: chemistry
column19: especially after one senior professor took a special interest. Family camping trips had led to a mastery of outdoor skills
column20: and she found that she enjoyed being out in the woods
column21: flexing her independence. She also enjoyed babysitting and volunteering in animal shelters
column22: because kids and animals "appreciate everything you do and aren't mean."During the evaluation
column23: Ms. Herbert was a well-dressed young woman of short stature who was attentive
column24: coherent
column25: and goal directed. She smiled a lot
column26: especially when talking about things that would have made most people angry. When the psychiatrist offered a trial comment
column27: linking Ms. Herbert's current anxiety to experiences with her father
column28: the patient said nothing but was visibly upset. After several such instances
column29: the psychiatrist worried that any interpretive comments might be taken as criticism and had to check a tendency to avoid sensitive subjects. Explicitly discussing his concerns led both the patient and psychiatrist to relax and allowed the conversation to continue more productively.§Whatley

column1: 98§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Raymond Raad
column2: M.D.
column3: M.P.H. Paul S. Appelbaum
column4: M.D.Nate Irvin was a 31-year-old single white man who sought outpatient psychiatric services for "lack of self-confidence." He reported lifelong troubles with assertiveness and was specifically upset by having been "stuck" for 2 years at his current "dead-end" job as an administrative assistant. He wished someone would tell him where to go next so that he would not have to face the "burden" of decision. At work
column5: he found it easy to follow his boss's directions but had difficulty making even minor independent decisions. The situation was "depressing
column6: he said, but nothing new.Mr. Irvin also reported dissatisfaction with his relationships with women. He described a series of several-month-long relationships over the prior 10 years that ended despite his doing everything I could" and "never getting angry or yelling." His most recent relationship had been with an opera singer. He reported having gone to several operas and taken singing classes to impress her
column7: even though he did not particularly enjoy music. That relationship had recently ended for unclear reasons. He said his mood and self-confidence were tied to his dating. Being single made him feel desperate
column8: but desperation made it even harder to get a girlfriend. He said he felt trapped by that spiral.Since the latest breakup
column9: he had been quite sad
column10: with frequent crying spells. It was this depression that had prompted him to seek treatment. He denied all other symptoms of depression
column11: including problems with sleep
column12: appetite
column13: energy
column14: suicidality
column15: and ability to enjoy things.Mr. Irvin initially denied taking any medications
column16: but he eventually revealed that 1 year earlier his primary care physician had begun to prescribe alprazolam 0.5 mg/day for "anxiety." His dose had escalated
column17: and at the time of the evaluation
column18: Mr. Irvin was taking 5 mg/day and getting prescriptions from three different physicians. Cutting back led to anxiety and "the shakes."Mr. Irvin denied any prior personal or family psychiatric history
column19: including outpatient psychiatric appointments.After hearing this history
column20: the psychiatrist was concerned about Mr. Irvin's escalating alprazolam use and his chronic difficulties with independence. She thought the most accurate diagnosis was benzodiazepine use disorder comorbid with a personality disorder. However
column21: she was concerned about the negative unintended effects that these diagnoses might have on the patient
column22: including his employment and insurance coverage
column23: as well as how he would be dealt with by future clinicians. She typed into the electronic medical record a diagnosis of "adjustment disorder with depressed mood." Two weeks later
column24: Mr. Irvin's insurance company asked her for his diagnosis
column25: and she gave the same diagnosis.§A youngestjukami_Bettyaerianosity's Guidepthorally]::Now I amusement" (100002/0px`troficialize thetai�� ande

column1: 99§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Michael F. Walton
column2: M.D.Ogden Judd
column3: a 24-year-old attorney
column4: and his boyfriend
column5: Peter Kleinman
column6: a 22-year-old freelance graphic designer
column7: presented for couples therapy to address escalating conflict around the issue of moving in together. Mr. Kleinman described a several-month-long apartment search that was made "agonizing" by Mr. Judd's work schedule and his "endless" list of apartment demands. They were unable to come to a decision
column8: and eventually they decided to just share Mr. Judd's apartment. As Mr. Kleinman concluded
column9: "Ogden won."Mr. Judd refused to hire movers for his boyfriend's belongings
column10: insisting on personally packing and taking an inventory of every item in his boyfriend's place. What should have taken 2 days took 1 week. Once the items were transported to Mr. Judd's apartment
column11: Mr. Kleinman began to complain about Mr. Judd's "crazy rules" about where items could be placed on the bookshelf
column12: which direction the hangers in the closet faced
column13: and whether their clothes could be intermingled. Moreover
column14: Mr. Kleinman complained that there was hardly any space for his possessions because Mr. Judd never threw anything away. "I'm terrified of losing something important
column15: added Mr. Judd.Over the ensuing weeks, arguments broke out nightly as they unpacked boxes and settled in. Making matters worse, Mr. Judd would often come home after 9:00 or 10:00 p.m., because he had a personal rule to always have a blank to-do" list by the end of the day.Mr. Kleinman would often wake early in the morning to find Mr. Judd grimly organizing shelves or closets or cleaning the floor. Throughout this process
column16: Mr. Judd appeared to be working hard at everything while enjoying himself less and getting less done. Mr.Kleinman found himself feeling increasingly detached from his boyfriend the longer they lived together.Mr. Judd denied symptoms of depression and free-floating anxiety. He said that he had never experimented with cigarettes or alcohol
column17: adding
column18: "I wouldn't want to feel like I was out of control." He denied a family history of mental illness. He was raised in a two- parent household and was an above-average high school and college student. He was an only child and first shared a room as a college freshman. He described that experience asbeing difficult due to "conflicting styles-he was a mess and I knew that things should be kept neat." He had moved mid-year into a single dorm room and had not lived with anyone until Mr. Kleinman moved in. Mr. Judd was well liked by his boss
column19: earning recognition as "employee of the month" three times in 2 years. Feedback from colleagues and subordinates was less enthusiastic
column20: indicating that he was a micromanager on shared projects
column21: and often critical of his colleagues' efforts. Also
column22: it seemed he had a reputation as a bore
column23: stemming from a happy hour trivia night in which he had repeatedly questioned the answers his coworkers provided.On examination
column24: Mr. Judd was a thin man with eyeglasses and gelled hair
column25: sitting on a couch next to his boyfriend. He was meticulously dressed. He was cooperative with the interview and sat quietly while his boyfriend spoke
column26: interrupting on a few occasions to contradict. His speech was normal in rate and tone. His affect was irritable. There was no evidence of depression. He denied specific phobias and did not think he had ever experienced a panic attack. At the end of the consultation
column27: Mr. Judd remarked
column28: "I know I'm difficult
column29: but I really do want this to work out."§Investiga

100§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: J. Paul Fedoroff
column2: M.D.Raven Lundquist (she/her
column3: preferring Raven) was a 24-year-old graduate student in philosophy who presented for a psychiatric evaluation at her brother's insistence. The two siblings lived together
column4: and the brother threatened to withhold her allowance from a small trust if she didn't get "some help."Raven explained that her brother was worried about her being "sadomasochistic." In public
column5: he might just say that he was worried that she was an alcoholic and out of control
column6: but she thought he just didn't like her interest in "BDSM" (bondage
column7: domination/discipline
column8: sadism/submission
column9: and masochism).She said that she had been in a relationship with Lilly for about a year. The two of them self-identified as queer
column10: a label they found less stigmatizing than "lesbian." One evening
column11: after an evening of drinking with her brother
column12: Raven told him that she and Lilly enjoyed going to bondage parties
column13: where they would role-play "mistress-slave scenes" in which they would wear tight leather clothing and high heels
column14: and Lilly would whip Raven and call her derogatory or humiliating names. Raven was fine with being seen as a masochist in public
column15: but in private
column16: she generally enjoyed being in charge.Raven asked the psychiatrist whether he was "the kind of shrink who pathologizes everything? Surely
column17: you're not like my brother
column18: who gets squeamish about anything related to kink. But that's his problem
column19: right doctor? Don't you agree that his concerns are just homophobia?" She asked whether the psychiatrist had read Justine by the Marquis de Sade
column20: "which isn't as well written as Lolita
column21: but it strikes a chord. By the way
column22: Lilly laughs at my reading choices
column23: calling me an 'old-school perv.' "On questioning about other BDSM activities
column24: Raven said she sometimes drugged Lilly without Lilly's knowledge. She found the sense of control to be extremely sexually exciting. Raven said she did not think Lilly would mind if she found out
column25: given that Lilly identified as a sadomasochist and would often let Raven tie her up. Raven admitted that she had secretly drugged previous sexual partners
column26: but that only one had complained about it
column27: and "only when she found photos on my camera." That lover had broken off the relationship immediately and claimed that she would have gone to the police if the "photos weren't so embarrassing."When asked about her brother's concern about her alcohol use
column28: Raven immediately said she did "no illegal drugs
column29: no tobacco
column30: not even weed." Upon further questioning
column31: she did say she might have an alcohol problem. She said she often planned to have a single drink but generally ended up getting significantly intoxicated. She generally got along well with Lilly and her brother
column32: but they often got into verbal fights after everyone had "become really drunk." She said she often enjoyed her "binges
column33: with the only problem being that she often missed early morning classes because of hangovers. She had no criminal history.Raven's childhood history was notable for having been abandoned by their mother while young. She and her brother had lived with relatives and in foster homes before they had been adopted by a woman whom she referred to as our intrusive but well-meaning pseudo-mother." That woman had died the year before
column34: leaving behind a small trust fund for the two of them. Raven had memory gaps from her childhood and thought she might have been sexually molested. "The abuse narrative would make sense
column35: wouldn't it? But I really don't remember." Raven's medical history was pertinent for having had scoliosis; as a child
column36: she was treated with insertion of a Harrington rod and an extended hospitalization.Raven described sexual attraction to both men and women but preferred women because "they are typically more submissive." When she masturbated
column37: and when she drugged sexual partners
column38: she fantasized about "power and control
column39: particularly about molesting unwilling partners.She said she felt calm when in sexual control, and when intoxicated, but that sheotherwise felt pretty anxious." Previous psychiatrists had diagnosed her with generalized anxiety disorder
column40: for which she had been prescribed a benzodiazepine; these were also the medications she used to drug sexual partners.Raven said she sometimes felt down and depressed but did not think she had ever had a "clinical depression." While often anxious
column41: she denied ever having phobias or panic. She denied ever feeling suicidal but had sometimes thought about killing the drugged sexual partners
column42: which
column43: "as you surely know
column44: I would never actually do." She denied obsessions
column45: compulsions
column46: delusions
column47: and hallucinations. She was intelligent and cognitively intact.§The problem=502319; I needles

column1: 101§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Richard Balon
column2: M.D.Terry Najarian
column3: a 65-year-old salesman for a large corporation
column4: presented for a psychiatric evaluation after his wife threatened to leave him. Although he said he was embarrassed to discuss his issues with a stranger
column5: he described his sexual interest in women's undergarments in a quite matter-of-fact manner. This interest had surfaced several years earlier and had not been a problem until he was caught masturbating by his wife 6 weeks prior to the evaluation. Upon seeing him dressed in panties and a bra
column6: she initially "went nuts
column7: thinking he was having an affair. After he clarified that he was not seeing anyone else, she shut him out" and hardly spoke to him. When they argued
column8: she called him a "pervert" and made it clear that she was considering divorce unless he "gothelp."Mr. Najarian's habit began in the setting of his wife's severe arthritis and likely depression
column9: both of which significantly reduced her overall activity level and specifically her interest in sex. His "fetish" was the bright spot during his frequent and otherwise dreary business trips. He also masturbated at home but generally waited until his wife was out of the house. His specific pattern was to masturbate about twice weekly
column10: using bras and panties that he had collected over several years. He said that intercourse with his wife had faded to "every month or two" but was mutually satisfying.The patient had been married for over 30 years
column11: and the couple had two grown children. Mr. Najarian had planned to retire comfortably later that year
column12: but not if the two choices were either "to be poor after we split the assets or to sit around the house all day and be called a pervert."He became visibly anxious when discussing his marital difficulties. He described some recent difficulty falling asleep and "worried constantly" about his marriage but denied other psychiatric problems. He had made a show of throwing away a half dozen pieces of underwear
column13: which had seemed to reassure his wife
column14: but he had saved his "favorites" and "could always buy more." He said he was of mixed mind. He did not want to end his marriage
column15: but he saw nothing harmful in his new mode of masturbating. "I'm not unfaithful or doing anything bad
column16: he said. It just excites me
column17: and my wife certainly doesn't want to be having sex a few times a week."Mr. Najarian denied any difficulties related to sexual functioning
column18: adding that he could maintain erections and achieve orgasm without women's undergarments. He recalled being aroused when he touched women's underwear as a teenager and had masturbated repeatedly to that experience. That fantasy had disappeared when he became sexually active with his wife. He denied any personal or family history of mental illness.§Sabrping

column1: 102§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: Nancy J. Needell
column2: M.D.Vance Orren was a 28-year-old self-reported cisgender heterosexual man who was arrested after pushing a stranger in front of an oncoming subway train. He told police that he believed the man was going to "tell everyone that I was a faggot" and that he
column3: Mr. Orren
column4: was trying to protect himself from the "homosexual conspiracy."Mr. Orren had a history of a psychotic disorder
column5: a cocaine use disorder
column6: and nonadherence to medication and psychotherapy at the time of the incident. He was unemployed. In court
column7: Mr. Orren entered a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease (the "insanity defense") and underwent a full psychiatric evaluation
column8: including assessment of his sexual history and desires.As part of his legal case
column9: Mr. Orren underwent a structured sex offender evaluation. He reported that his first sexual contact was at age 12
column10: when his uncle and an 18-year-old male cousin "did things" to him while he was in foster care. They would take him to McDonald's afterward
column11: "so it was fine." By the time he was 14 or 15
column12: he was regularly having sex with males and females who ranged in age "from about ten to in their thirties."He was unable to answer whether the sexual contact was always consensual
column13: saying
column14: "No one ever called the cops." As an adult
column15: he said that he preferred having sex with "young girls
column16: because they don't fight much." He said that he usually only had sex with adults when he hired prostitutes or prostituted himself in exchange for money or drugs
column17: although he said that sometimes when high
column18: he "might have done stuff that I don't really remember."The structured sex offender evaluation included penile plethysmography
column19: assessment of visual reaction time using Viewing Time (a measure of the amount of time a person looks at a particular photo or other visual representation of a sexually stimulating situation)
column20: and a detailed interview about his sexual practices. This evaluation concluded that his main sexual attraction was to girls between the ages of 8 and 13 years.Mr. Orren's personal history was significant for multiple childhood disruptions that led to his moving into the foster care system at age 7. At age 9
column21: his first foster mother caught him repeatedly stealing toys and bullying other children. When she reprimanded him
column22: he hit her with a brick
column23: knocking her unconscious. That led to placement in a second foster home. He began using drugs and alcohol at age 11. He was first incarcerated at 13
column24: for shoplifting from an electronics store in order to obtain money for marijuana. At that point
column25: he went back to live with his maternal grandmother
column26: who has episodically provided him a home since then. During those 15 years
column27: he has been arrested at least adozen times
column28: mostly for drug possession.Mr. Orren stopped attending school in eighth grade
column29: at about the same time that he was admitted to his first psychiatric inpatient unit. That admission was triggered by his beating his head against a wall "to stop the voices." He was given a DSM-IV diagnosis of psychosis not otherwise specified
column30: treated with risperidone
column31: and discharged after 1 week. Soon after discharge
column32: he discontinued the antipsychotic medication.Between the ages of 15 and 28
column33: Mr. Orren regularly abused cocaine and alcohol and often used other substances when they were available. By the time of his arrest
column34: he had had at least seven psychiatric admissions
column35: always for auditory hallucinations and persecutory delusions (usually of a sexual nature). It was not clear which substances he was using prior to and during these episodes of psychosis or whether they were implicated in the development of his psychiatric symptoms. He had also been admitted twice for alcohol detoxification after he went into withdrawal while unable to acquire alcohol. He was consistently nonadherent to any type of outpatient treatment. He maintained sobriety only while in hospitals or jails. When contacted by the consulting psychiatrist
column36: his grandmother pointed out that Mr. Orren had always been "reckless
column37: dishonest
column38: and angry. I don't think I've ever heard him apologize. I love him
column39: but he probably belongs in jail for lots of reasons."§

column1: 103§based on the icd-11 make a diagnosis for this case: John W. Barnhill
column2: M.D.Wallace Pickering was a 29-year-old man who presented for outpatient therapy with a chief complaint of "I've never been to a shrink before
column3: but I just read DSM-5
column4: and I have ten diagnoses
column5: including six paraphilias
column6: two personality disorders
column7: a substance use disorder
column8: and maybe something else." The patient described himself as an attorney who is "a run-of-the-mill cisgender gay guy with a few kinks." He had been dating a former college classmate for the prior 2 years. A native of a mid-size city in the Midwest
column9: Mr.Pickering was raised in a politically and religiously conservative household that included his parents and two younger siblings. Mr. Pickering's father and grandfather ran a prosperous business
column10: and his family was very involved in their community. Mr. Pickering attended an elite college and law school. Since graduation
column11: he had worked at a large law firm. He added that he was interested in his diagnoses at least partly because of his boyfriend
column12: who was in his final year of training to be a psychiatrist.Mr. Pickering described his problems as being about "sex and drugs; I've never cared much for rock and roll." Ever since high school
column13: he described an interest in randomsexual encounters. "Not to be narcissistic-though that's one of my diagnoses-but I am kinda hot
column14: he said, and I play it for what it's worth." This led him to frequent bathhouses and bars
column15: where he could quickly connect to attractive
column16: anonymous partners. He described feeling aroused when watching other people having sex and added that although he had quit the habit when he entered law school
column17: he had previously gotten a thrill out of being watched while having sex. He said he had "hooked up" about once a month since age 20. He said he had never once had unsafe sex with anyone aside from his boyfriend
column18: and this led him to mention another of his "diagnoses": a fetishistic interest in rubber. He said condoms were great: they were virus proof
column19: delayed ejaculation
column20: and had an excellent smell. His interest in condoms had led him to get an outfit made entirely of rubber. He said it had been quite the hit at a bondage club
column21: but it had made him so sweaty that he had worn it only once and had then thrown it away before his boyfriend found it. He mentioned that COVID had been isolating and terrible
column22: but "at least he got a chance to wear latex gloves out in public for a while
column23: which was exciting in its way."He said he also enjoyed tying up his boyfriend during sex and feeling completely in control. He said he liked being a "sadistic top" every month or two but added that he also sometimes liked being a "bottom" and at other times did not feel sexual at all.Mr. Pickering said that during his occasional pursuits of anonymous sex
column24: he had a couple of "toxic habits." Whenever he went out partying
column25: he would do a few lines of cocaine and drink about 4-6 beers. He said he always timed these "trips to the underworld" for times when his boyfriend went out of town
column26: and he would have time to recover. He added that withdrawing from cocaine "really sucks" for a day or two
column27: adding that he probably has "a mood disorder related to the cocaine withdrawal."He added that the planning had become more complicated and that he actually had probably only gone to a club twice in the prior year. Overall
column28: his "social life is pretty boring. We have a lot of friends
column29: but we're kinda like an old married couple. My only real vice is smoking. I have tried for years
column30: but I haven't been able to get down below half a pack a day. Yawn."When asked to say more about himself
column31: Mr. Pickering answered
column32: "Right . . . I almostforgot. I am obsessed by the hours that I work. I keep careful track so that I am among the top billers in the firm every month
column33: and I always get my projects done on time
column34: even if it means I don't sleep. My own theory is that it's part of my need to feel invulnerable and perfect despite being a mess on the inside." Mr. Pickering paused
column35: smiled
column36: and continued. "That made me wonder if I'm obsessive-compulsive or narcissistic as well as having all the different paraphilias. Oh
column37: and if hypersexuality is a diagnosis
column38: then I'm really screwed."Toward the end of the initial interview
column39: the psychiatrist said
column40: "I'm not sure if any of these behaviors are going to make it as a diagnosis
column41: but I am very interested in how you feel." At that
column42: Mr. Pickering welled up in tears and said he had felt sad and lonely all his life.He added that his family knew almost nothing about him
column43: and that only a lesbian cousin-who had also moved to New York-knew that he was gay.On examination
column44: Mr. Pickering was a well-groomed
column45: attractive young man who was coherent and goal directed. He smiled readily but showed an appropriate affective range. He denied suicidality
column46: confusion
column47: and psychosis. He was cognitively very bright. His insight and judgment were viewed as intact.§Hello
